Inflation? It Just Doesn't Add Up

Author: Nasar, Sylvia

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Aug 1999: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431227775?accountid=11752

Abstract: BARELY a year after a worldwide deflation scare -- when markets and currencies were crashing, banks and businesses in Asia, Russia and Latin America were failing, and prices of oil and raw materials were plunging -- inflation is back on peoples' minds. But what concerns Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Wall Street investors is the nagging suspicion that the stellar inflation record of the last two years was mostly the product of a few lucky, highly transitory breaks -- and therefore won't last. That suspicion is likely to propel the Fed's policy-making committee toward another interest-rate increase when it meets on Tuesday. Actually, there are solid reasons for thinking that a return to the bad old days, when upwardly spiraling prices seemed as inevitable as the sunrise, is highly unlikely. For one thing, some of those ''transitory'' factors are likely to persist for quite a while longer. For another, popular expectations about inflation -- low inflation, this time -- readily become self-fulfilling prophecies. And a host of structural and policy changes over the last couple of decades have made the United States economy less inherently prone to inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Inflation%3F+It+Just+Doesn%27t+Add+Up&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1999-08-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.1&amp;au=Nasar%2C+Sylvia&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00729127&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: BARELY a year after a worldwide deflation scare -- when markets and currencies were crashing, banks and businesses in Asia, Russia and Latin America were failing, and prices of oil and raw materials were plunging -- inflation is back on peoples' minds.
On the face of it, fretting about inflation when every major price gauge in the United States is rising just 2 percent or so a year seems a little like Uma Thurman obsessing over her weight.
But what concerns Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Wall Street investors is the nagging suspicion that the stellar inflation record of the last two years was mostly the product of a few lucky, highly transitory breaks -- and therefore won't last. That suspicion is likely to propel the Fed's policy-making committee toward another interest-rate increase when it meets on Tuesday.
Admittedly, the budding recovery in Asia and Europe has already blunted some of the forces that have helped push United States inflation down from 4 percent to 2 percent a year since 1997.
Energy prices -- indeed, most commodity prices other than farm products -- are already rebounding sharply after collapsing last year.
And the high-flying dollar, which helped to make imports cheaper, has recently weakened against the euro and the yen as global investors have begun to shift some of their mutual fund money away from the United States to foreign markets.
Sounds dire, right?
Actually, there are solid reasons for thinking that a return to the bad old days, when upwardly spiraling prices seemed as inevitable as the sunrise, is highly unlikely. For one thing, some of those ''transitory'' factors are likely to persist for quite a while longer. For another, popular expectations about inflation -- low inflation, this time -- readily become self-fulfilling prophecies. And a host of structural and policy changes over the last couple of decades have made the United States economy less inherently prone to inflation.
Even skeptics now say that the low inflation of the 1990's is not just a fluke, but rather a return to a norm that prevailed for a quarter-century, beginning in the late 1940's -- years when 4 percent inflation seemed scandalously high. As Alan S. Blinder, an economist at Princeton University and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said recently, ''To a substantial extent, we're back to the 50's.''
Jeffrey Frankel of Harvard University, until recently a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said of mainstream economists: ''A lot of us were real stick-in-the-muds. We said: 'No, no, no. Here are the equations.' But other people who knew less about equations had the sense to realize that things are a bit different.''
For starters, not all the good luck is evaporating. True, energy prices have jumped 24 percent since the beginning of the year. But energy wasn't a big factor in inflation's decline -- the economy uses a lot less energy than it did in, say, 1973 -- and this year's price increase isn't anything like the surges in 1973 or 1990. Most of the impact has already filtered through to consumer prices for gasoline, electricity, heating oil and air fares, adding at most a few tenths of a percentage point to the inflation rate.
The dollar's recent dip and the ballooning trade deficit have some economists, notably Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, warning of the possibility of a currency crisis. If the dollar were to take a big dive, that would indeed threaten to push inflation up sharply. But it would also provoke a sharp reaction from the Fed. And the dollar is still slightly stronger on a trade-weighted basis (that is, against a basket of currencies of America's trading partners) than it was at the start of the year.
More to the point, import prices, by far the biggest recent drag on inflation, are apt to remain under downward pressure. Their decline, it turns out, was due less to the strong dollar than to vast excess productive capacity in Asia, Latin America and elsewhere -- an excess that will not be mopped up soon, given the gradual pace of world recovery.
''It's not just the dollar, but economic incentives to increase production abroad,'' said Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University.
Domestically, health care costs have stopped skyrocketing and show few signs of resuming that course, despite increases over the last year in the fees that health maintenance organizations charge employers. Though the latest readings show consumer prices for medical care rising a bit faster than a year ago, few experts expect the pace to accelerate to twice the overall inflation rate, as it did in the early 1990's.
In any case, even temporary lulls in inflation can have long-term effects, by changing expectations. Americans who believed two decades ago that inflation would always rise are now expecting it to remain low.
According to the monthly University of Michigan survey of consumer expectations, ordinary Americans expect the inflation rate a year from now to be under 3 percent. (The Federal Reserve forecasts 2.5 percent or less.) ''You get this extra impact,'' Professor Gordon said. ''The biggest factor holding down inflation in the next couple of years is the lower inflation of the past couple.''
But perhaps the strongest reasons for optimism are sweeping changes in the economy that have been in the works for years.
Back in the bad old 1970's, temporary supply shocks tended to produce higher inflation automatically. Since then, some long-term trends -- globalization, deregulation, the computer revolution -- have made the economy less susceptible to bottlenecks and wage-price spirals.
''One story is that we are permanently able to run the economy hotter and labor markets tighter,'' Professor Krugman said, ''because we have a more flexible labor market, and monopoly and union power have been curbed by international competition.''
Consider deregulation, which began during the Carter Administration and has since radically transformed broad swaths of the sprawling service sector, including airlines, energy, banking, railroads, telecommunications and, most recently, electricity. More competition helps rein in inflation directly, and a new wealth of alternatives keeps strikes or other disruptions from creating bottlenecks. (Remember what life was like before faxes, cell phones and E-mail?) ''They all kind of connect the economy together,'' Professor Frankel said.
Then there's the computer revolution. Information technology helps companies do everything they do -- notably, managing inventory -- more flexibly and efficiently. But innovation is also driving down computer prices, and rapidly enough to take half a percentage point off the overall inflation rate, according to Professor Gordon.
More prosaic changes in the way the American labor market works may be as important as globalization. Alan B. Krueger of Princeton University and Lawrence F. Katz of Harvard recently published a study suggesting that a host of small, incremental changes -- including the decline of unions, the growing role of temporary-help firms, even welfare reform -- have made the labor market more efficient. That may be why an unemployment rate below the prevailing average of the 1950's and 1960's has yet to set off bidding wars among employers.
And though the labor market may be tight, American business is still operating with a lot of spare capacity, the product of an investment boom spurred by lower interest rates and a rush to embrace technology. Utilization rates remain relatively low even after eight years of economic expansion -- one reason that companies find it hard to raise prices. ''That could explain why inflation is lower than you'd think just looking at unemployment,'' Professor Frankel said.
That investment boom has had another powerful anti-inflation effect. Productivity has been growing at around 2 percent a year, double the rate that prevailed in the 1970's and 1980's. Greater efficiency, in turn, has made it possible for employers to increase compensation at a higher pace than the inflation rate without adding much to their costs.
''We've had an acceleration of productivity growth, and it takes a while before people build that expectation into wages,'' Professor Krugman said.
Of course, even the most open, flexible, productive economy can suffer inflation. Inflation, as Milton Friedman, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, has said, is ultimately a monetary phenomenon, and is therefore determined by policy makers in Washington, most notably the Fed.
Recall how the low-inflation post-war era ended: tax cuts and guns-and-butter spending under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and an accommodating central bank let the inflation genie out of the bottle even before the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries quadrupled oil prices in 1973.
Putting the genie back in the bottle cost the nation a couple of nasty recessions and years of high unemployment and lost output. Today, the memory of the high human and political costs of wringing inflation out of the system help keep inflation at bay, much as memories of the Great Depression have kept deflation at bay.
Three times in 10 years, Alan Greenspan has struck pre-emptively with interest-rate increases to ward off any acceleration before it could even begin, in 1989, 1994 and now -- strikes that so far, at least, seem to have served the economy well.
Chart ''The Exception, or the Rule?''
Inflation hasn't been this low this long for decades. Has this run been a fluke, or are Eisenhower-era inflation rates here to stay? Some of the forces that have helped bring down inflation into the 2 percent range are starting to reverse direction, but excess capacity at home and abroad, a more flexible labor market and faster productivity growth should keep inflation from rebounding.

With Assets Pumped Up, Few Worry About Inflation

Author: Uchitelle, Louis

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 May 1999: 4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431169132?accountid=11752

Abstract: INFLATION is back: Not rising prices, except for an uncharacteristic spurt in April, but the perennial debate about the sacrifices that must be made when inflation does turn into a problem. The debate is premature. The 0.7 percent jump in the Consumer Price Index last month appears to have been an anomaly, reflecting a set of circumstances not likely to be repeated in May. But the April jump was the largest for a single month in nine years. And the Federal Reserve compounded the alarm by announcing last Tuesday that, while it was not yet raising interest rates to slow the economy and head off inflation, it was leaning that way, ''concerned about the potential for a buildup of inflationary imbalances.'' Suddenly, then, a debate has revived that had lain dormant during more than two years of very modest inflation. But the terms of the debate have changed; the issues are different, and the public's perception of inflation is drastically altered.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=With+Assets+Pumped+Up%2C+Few+Worry+About+Inflation&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1999-05-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3.4&amp;au=Uchitelle%2C+Louis&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00718238&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: INFLATION is back: Not rising prices, except for an uncharacteristic spurt in April, but the perennial debate about the sacrifices that must be made when inflation does turn into a problem.
The debate is premature. The 0.7 percent jump in the Consumer Price Index last month appears to have been an anomaly, reflecting a set of circumstances not likely to be repeated in May. But the April jump was the largest for a single month in nine years. And the Federal Reserve compounded the alarm by announcing last Tuesday that, while it was not yet raising interest rates to slow the economy and head off inflation, it was leaning that way, ''concerned about the potential for a buildup of inflationary imbalances.''
Suddenly, then, a debate has revived that had lain dormant during more than two years of very modest inflation. But the terms of the debate have changed; the issues are different, and the public's perception of inflation is drastically altered.
The old alarm is missing, for one thing. The C.P.I. may have jumped in April, but Americans took no notice, according to the University of Michigan's consumer surveys. ''They don't think any price increases will stick,'' said Richard Curtin, director of the surveys. He added that people are more relaxed about inflation than at any time since the early 1960's.
That is a considerable change. Three years ago, there was talk among policy makers of reducing the annual inflation rate to zero, even if that meant suffering higher unemployment. And people listened respectfully.
Now that talk is gone. An inflation rate of 1.5 to 2 percent (the C.P.I.'s range for most of the past year) makes no one nervous today, and a rise to 3 percent seems tolerable to the public, if not to Wall Street. After all, no homeowner -- and most of the nation's families are homeowners -- is complaining about housing prices, which have been rising briskly in most regions. Or, as Mr. Curtin put it, ''An important element of the strong consumer confidence today is this rise in the value of physical assets.''
The revived inflation debate is also taking place in an altered context. Inflation in America is no longer viewed as a national phenomenon, but seen as a global one. The American economy can indeed operate full-blast without the shortages that push up prices, as long as enough other countries can supplement American production by diverting their unsold merchandise and their idle labor to America's needs.
The Asian crisis and its aftermath have forced that perception into everyone's consciousness. Faced with recession and weak consumer demand at home, companies in Asia, Europe and Latin America have been sending their wares to the United States at discount prices. And, gradually, officials and economists are coming to the view that without this flood of imports, the inflation rate in the United States could not have remained so low through three years of expansion and the labor shortages it produced.
Excess global capacity is the new buzz phrase, representing a concept that three years ago most economists and policy makers thought impossible. Supply used to be considered something that rapidly fell in line with demand. Now oversupply -- caused by excess capacity, if not in the United States, then somewhere else -- is recognized as a persistent problem. And deflation, a word shunned in the old inflation debate, is a common concern in the new one.
''The global economy has become the new wild card in making policy to control inflation,'' said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
This new emphasis showed itself last Tuesday in the reaction of the National Association of Manufacturers to the Fed's inflation concerns. The manufacturers, who often complain that they cannot raise prices because of global competition, urged the Fed to hold interest rates steady because of ''the general weakness of global growth.''
Two days later, when the Commerce Department announced that the trade deficit had widened in March, because of a big jump in imports, some Wall Street economists welcomed the news instead of wringing their hands as they once would have. The former thinking was that trade deficits pull the United States deeper into debt to foreign lenders who finance the nation's excess spending on imports. Eventually this borrowing can depress the dollar, and a weaker dollar then makes imports more expensive for Americans, pushing up the inflation rate.
That may yet happen. But it was not uppermost last week in the minds of the economists at Bankers Trust. They applauded. ''A burgeoning trade deficit continues to act as a safety valve for the U.S. economy,'' they told clients, ''siphoning production away from potentially overheating domestic industries and thus helping keep inflation tame.''
The new inflation debate is fundamentally altered in another way. Nothing used to be of greater concern than the trade-off between domestic unemployment and domestic inflation, a concept embodied in the acronym Nairu, short for nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment. When the unemployment rate fell too low, the theory said, labor shortages would put upward pressure on wages, forcing employers to increase prices. Nairu refers to the level of unemployment below which this effect kicked in.
But where is Nairu, exactly? The common wisdom as recently as 1996 put it at 6 percent, or perhaps a bit lower. But the jobless rate dropped below 5 percent nearly two years ago, and inflation kept falling.
Many explanations are offered for this uncoupling: job insecurity, weak labor unions, temporary workers, a more productive labor force, the global economy. Whatever the cause, Nairu has lost its clout in the new inflation debate -- ''sublimated by the marvelous combination of low unemployment and low inflation,'' as Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist, put it.
The Federal Reserve, in these new circumstances, is much more constrained. Labor shortages are no longer a persuasive reason for raising interest rates to head off inflation. And when the Fed does finally act, the communique will have to take a world view -- explaining convincingly how the global economy is now fomenting inflation in America instead of stifling it.
Graph ''Inching Up'' plots year-to-year change in the Consumer Price Index since 1990. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)
Drawing (David G. Klein)

Oil Is Rising, but Inflation Seems to Be in Check

Author: Fuerbringer, Jonathan

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Mar 1999: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431141383?accountid=11752

Abstract: But despite the oil price increase, economists are not predicting a new surge in inflation across the board. Rather, they are merely saying that the decline in inflation, which limited last year's increase in the Consumer Price Index to 1.6 percent, will be over if the oil price rises stick. This means, economists said yesterday, that the rate of inflation over all, which includes energy and food prices, is likely to move up toward the rate for what economists call core inflation. That rate, which excludes energy and food, is considered by some to be a better measure of the long-term rate of price increases. Last year, the C.P.I.'s core rate rose 2.3 percent. But, the economists agree, there is no upward spiral on the horizon. Oil ministers meeting at The Hague also announced that they had the outline of an agreement to cut oil production by two million barrels a day. That report pushed up the price of oil for delivery in April to $14.49 a barrel, its highest since October. The anticipation of some kind of new cut in output has been pushing up the price of oil steadily since mid-February, when it was $11.37 a barrel, just above a 13-year low.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Oil+Is+Rising%2C+but+Inflation+Seems+to+Be+in+Check&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1999-03-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;au=Fuerbringer%2C+Jonathan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00708627&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The oil price surge this year, which got another boost yesterday with a new agreement on cutting production, is beginning to sting consumers.
Gasoline pump prices began to creep up this month. Colder weather in the Northeast could add to the heating oil pinch. Higher prices for airplane fuel may make tickets more expensive quickly. The indirect ripple effects, in products, like plastics, that use oil, will take longer to bite, but will come.
But despite the oil price increase, economists are not predicting a new surge in inflation across the board. Rather, they are merely saying that the decline in inflation, which limited last year's increase in the Consumer Price Index to 1.6 percent, will be over if the oil price rises stick.
This means, economists said yesterday, that the rate of inflation over all, which includes energy and food prices, is likely to move up toward the rate for what economists call core inflation. That rate, which excludes energy and food, is considered by some to be a better measure of the long-term rate of price increases. Last year, the C.P.I.'s core rate rose 2.3 percent. But, the economists agree, there is no upward spiral on the horizon.
''I think we should notice but not worry,'' said Gail D. Fosler, the chief economist at the Conference Board. ''There is really nothing in the global environment or the United States environment that suggests that this is going to spread.''
Still, it remains to be seen whether consumers will get unnerved when they see reports that prices are moving up rather than holding steady or declining. Investors might also get disturbed and push the price of bonds down and interest rates higher. But there was no sign of this kind of concern in the bond market yesterday, as interest rates on Treasury securities fell and the Government's inflation-indexed bonds were virtually unchanged.
The changing outlook for inflation was reflected pointedly in two separate news events yesterday. First, the Labor Department reported that prices paid to producers fell four-tenths of 1 percent in February. Without energy and food, producer prices were unchanged. Throughout the report there were signs that the prices of many goods were still falling.
Oil ministers meeting at The Hague also announced that they had the outline of an agreement to cut oil production by two million barrels a day. That report pushed up the price of oil for delivery in April to $14.49 a barrel, its highest since October. The anticipation of some kind of new cut in output has been pushing up the price of oil steadily since mid-February, when it was $11.37 a barrel, just above a 13-year low.
There are several reasons that economists are not predicting another general price spiral. One is that the global economic growth is still sluggish at best. Even if Asia, which touched off a worldwide financial crisis in 1997 with a series of currency devaluations, is recovering, Latin America is in decline and Europe seems to be standing still or slipping.
Chase Manhattan Bank forecasts about 1.5 percent growth globally this year. Even if stronger-than-expected United States growth pulls that up to 2 percent, that will be significantly below recent years' pace, said James E. Glassman, Chase's senior United States economist.
''The main driver for all this good inflation news is that we are not growing at our potential globally,'' he said. The way to change his mind about the outlook for inflation, he said, is to have oil prices rising because global demand was picking up.
Another factor is that other commodity prices, from cotton to copper, are at or near their recent lows. The Commodity Research Bureau/ Bridge index of 17 commodities, which fell yesterday, is just 5 points above its 24-year low hit at the end of February.
''Until there is significant upward pressure on all commodities, we are not going to have any worrisome price impact,'' said Ms. Fosler of the Conference Board.
In addition, while oil prices have shot up 20 percent this year, they have risen from very low levels and are just back to where they were last summer or fall, when they were already low. The same is true for gasoline prices, which were at their lowest level, after adjustment for inflation, since at least the 1950's.
And there is the question of whether the production cuts will hold or have a significant impact. Oil producers are notorious for cheating, even after agreeing to pump less oil. After the last major effort to cut production began in March 1998, the price of oil dropped 36 percent to its low of $10.72 a barrel in December.
But while there is not a new inflation spiral in sight, the overall inflation rate will rise if the oil price increase holds.
Michael Rothman, senior energy analyst at Merrill Lynch, estimates that the price of oil could move up to $17 a barrel soon. And he said it could possibly move near $20 a barrel by the end of the year if there was a sustained reduction in production that made a meaningful dent in the current overload of oil inventories.
Cynthia Latta, principal United States economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass., ran an end-of-the-year oil price of $18 a barrel through her computer model and found the following: The DRI forecast of a 1.8 percent rise in the C.P.I., year-over-year, in 1999 inches up to 2.1 percent. And if the oil price held there, the C.P.I. would increase 2.8 percent in 2000 and 2.6 percent in 2001, before slipping back to 2.4 percent in 2002.
This is above the 1.6 percent increase for 1998. But the number is less startling when compared with the 2.3 percent increase in the C.P.I. in 1997 and the 3 percent rise in 1996. In addition, the forecasts are close to the increase in the core C.P.I., without the volatile elements of food and energy, which rose 2.3 percent in 1998, 2.4 percent in 1997 and 2.7 percent in 1996.
All this leads Ms. Latta to agree with the other economists on the recent rise in oil prices: ''It is not going to have much of an impact on inflation.''

January Inventories Up
WASHINGTON, March 12 (Reuters) -- United States businesses added to their stocks of goods on hand in January, with retailers in particular building inventories in anticipation of strong shopping, the Government said today.
Total business inventories increased one-tenth of a percent to a seasonally adjusted $1.088 trillion in January, reversing a one-tenth of a percent decrease in December. But overall sales were down for the first time in five months.
The report reflected booming consumer demand as retailers recorded strong sales and inventory building. The reverse was true for both wholesalers and manufacturers, whose January sales and inventories were lower than in December.
Retailers, enjoying robust sales, increased their goods on hand in January by eight-tenths of a percent, to $336.3 billion, after a seven-tenths of a percent rise in December. Retail sales increased 1 percent, to $234.35 billion, after a 1.1 percent surge in December.
Total sales by all levels of businesses -- retail, wholesale and manufacturing -- were down in January by three-tenths of 1 percent, to $791.09 billion, after a 1 percent jump in December.
It was the first decline in total monthly business sales since a two-tenths of 1 percent fall in August last year and was the biggest monthly drop since a half a percent dip in August 1997.
Manufacturers' inventories fell in January by three-tenths of 1 percent, to $465.57 billion, after a nine-tenths of 1 percent December fall. Sales by manufacturing companies declined eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $341.46 billion, after an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in December.

Nations That Export Commodities Feel Shock Waves

Author: Fuerbringer, Jonathan

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]11 July 1998: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/431011747?accountid=11752

Abstract: But the more powerful impact is working through a slower-moving and less visible force: the markets for basic commodities like oil, metals and timber. And that helps explain why the ripples from the Asian financial collapse are continuing to hit hard at countries as far-flung as Canada, Chile, New Zealand and Mexico, yet the effect has remained unexpectedly benign in the United States and Europe. Drops in the prices for copper have hit Zambia and Chile, while New Zealand has felt the impact of lower timber prices. Australia is suffering from a decline in wool prices; Canada bears the pain of lower coal and timber prices. But the United States and Europe are in significantly different positions than most other countries. Even though exports from Europe and America to Asia have dropped sharply and the United States also sells a lot of its own commodities abroad, their economies are far less dependent on them. In addition, generally affluent consumers in the world's two biggest economic entities have received a big boost -- similar to the effects of a substantial tax cut -- because of the decline in commodity prices. This has largely cushioned the Asian fallout so far here and in much of Europe.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Nations+That+Export+Commodities+Feel+Shock+Waves&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1998-07-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Fuerbringer%2C+Jonathan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/05120166&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Brace yourself. It's time for the Asian aftershocks.
When East Asia was hit by its economic earthquake a year ago, the shock waves quickly reverberated around the globe through the world's hair-trigger stock and currency markets.
But the more powerful impact is working through a slower-moving and less visible force: the markets for basic commodities like oil, metals and timber. And that helps explain why the ripples from the Asian financial collapse are continuing to hit hard at countries as far-flung as Canada, Chile, New Zealand and Mexico, yet the effect has remained unexpectedly benign in the United States and Europe.
For nations that depend heavily on selling raw materials and basic goods globally to generate growth and to support their government budgets, the pain has been sharp, contributing to job cutbacks, lower currency values, shortfalls in government revenues and ballooning trade deficits.
Over all, commodity prices are down almost 10 percent since February.
''There is no question that the weakness in certain commodities is reverberating in markets around the world,'' said Desmond Lachman, managing director of emerging markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney.
Drops in the prices for copper have hit Zambia and Chile, while New Zealand has felt the impact of lower timber prices. Australia is suffering from a decline in wool prices; Canada bears the pain of lower coal and timber prices.
But the United States and Europe are in significantly different positions than most other countries. Even though exports from Europe and America to Asia have dropped sharply and the United States also sells a lot of its own commodities abroad, their economies are far less dependent on them. In addition, generally affluent consumers in the world's two biggest economic entities have received a big boost -- similar to the effects of a substantial tax cut -- because of the decline in commodity prices. This has largely cushioned the Asian fallout so far here and in much of Europe.
Consider the impact of lower oil prices, which have fallen from a high of $22 a barrel in the last year to a low of $11.56 a barrel last month. While not all of this is a result of the crisis in Asia, a major portion is because the Asian economic engine has stopped racing ahead and has gone into reverse.
That has translated into about $14 billion in lost income this year to major oil producers like Russia, Mexico, Venezuela and the Middle East and a nearly equivalent bonus for energy consumers. For the United States, which produced 6.4 million barrels a day in April but also imported 10.4 million barrels daily, the positive gain for consumers has far outweighed the negative impact on oil drillers.
Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Primark Decision Economics, is forecasting that lost growth from American exports and the substitution of cheaper Asian imports for products made here could cut as much a one full percentage point off the increase in the gross domestic product this year.
But, at the same time, he estimates that the overall decline in oil prices, by putting more money into the pockets of American consumers, will add back much, though probably not all, of the growth lost through worsening foreign trade.
And this is not the only stimulus from Asia. The flight of foreign investors from Asia's problems and into the haven of Treasury bonds has bolstered the dollar and pushed American long-term interest rates to 30-year lows. The near absence of inflation has been helped by lower commodity prices and cheaper import prices. All that has allowed growth to perk along without the inflationary pressures that would have normally forced the Federal Reserve to put on the brakes.
Both low rates and low inflation have helped keep the stock market rally alive, adding to the ''wealth effect'' from the market rally that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, among others, believes has kept the economy strong by stimulating spending.
For the United States, Mr. Sinai said, ''It is possible that the positive byproducts could be more than enough to offset the negatives.''
But for major commodity producing nations, the cushion has been less comforting.
In Canada, where commodities make up about 40 percent of exports, the Canadian dollar has been bouncing off record lows, largely because of the weakness of commodity prices. While the economy is still forecast to grow around 3 percent this year, Ottawa has abandoned its policy of raising interest rates to support the Canadian dollar. That has helped offset some of the Asian impact, according to Ram Bhagavatula, the chief financial economist at Citibank.
Analysts are forecasting that New Zealand's commodity-sensitive economy could tip into a short recession because of the falloff in the sales of lumber, fish, fruits, vegetables and the like. And if Japan -- one of the principal buyers of New Zealand products -- remains mired in recession, prospects could worsen.
In Australia, the Aussie dollar plunged to a 12-year low in June as new forecasts showed that total commodity exports should fall by 1 percent over the next year, after rising more than 7 percent the previous year. Like Canada, Australia may have enough domestic demand to keep it out of a recession. But some economists are scaling back their growth forecasts.
The continued low level of commodity prices means that many countries -- along with their financial markets -- will probably remain vulnerable to further shocks for some time. Even in Canada and Australia, where no recession is in sight, the weakened currencies will mean growing trade deficits and inflationary pressure as import costs rise.
Money in stock markets around the world can move quickly, often in anticipation of fundamental economic changes expected in the future. But a meaningful rebound in commodity prices will probably wait until the economies of Asia actually turn around and begin to consume more oil, copper, coal, fish and vegetables.
In a recent study, two World Bank economists, Guillermo Perry and Daniel Lederman, discussed the fallout from declining commodity prices, which they called real effects, and the fallout from declines in equity and currency markets, which they called financial effects.
Looking at the impact of Asia's downturn on Latin America, they found that the weakness caused by the real effects from lower commodity prices ''may produce an increase in the financial vulnerability of countries.''
Sure, there are other factors that explain some of the drop in commodity prices: El Nino and a warm winter contributed to the softness in oil demand, for instance.
But the key factor remains Asia. The International Monetary Fund, in its recent World Economic Outlook, concluded that the drop in primary commodity prices as a group was ''to a large degree'' a result of the Asian downturn.
Asia has had this impact, the report said, because the region had stopped increasing its consumption of oil, copper, rubber, zinc, nickel, wool and timber. For example, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand, where the Asian crisis has hit hard, accounted for about a quarter of the growth of demand for copper between 1992 and 1996. With that demand now shrinking, copper prices have dropped almost 35 percent in the last year.
The copper fallout has been felt in Zambia, where the metal accounts for more than 80 percent of export earnings, and in Chile, where copper accounts for 42 percent of export earnings. A major share of Chile's exports go to Asia and the Government estimates that it has lost as much as $500 million in forgone Asian sales.
Last month Chile's Government announced $200 million in new budget cuts that bring the total for the year to $685 million. Interest rates have risen and the peso has fallen to record lows, forcing the central bank to drop policies that limited foreign investment and to use its dollar reserves to defend the peso.
In New Zealand, timber exports, which are about 10 percent of the country's total, collapsed with the weakness in the housing market in Japan, said Mark Benseman, an economist for Merrill Lynch in Auckland. He estimates that about 34 percent of the country's exports -- those going to Australia and Asia -- have been affected by the slump.
In Canada, the Japanese recession has had a stark impact. According to the most recent trade statistics, exports to Japan, measured in Canadian dollars, have fallen 43 percent since April 1997. The decline has been spread over most commodity groups, led by softwood lumber. In the first quarter, exports of coal and related products to Japan fell 84 percent. There also have been significant declines in commodity exports to South Korea and Taiwan.
Over all, the value of agricultural and fishing exports are down 8.5 percent since April 1997 while energy exports are off 17.5 percent and forestry products are down 2.7 percent.
But the biggest impact of all has occurred in the oil markets. Mike Rothman, Merrill Lynch's senior energy analyst, estimates that consumption of oil this year has been cut by as much 300,000 barrels a day in developing Asia and even more by the recession in Japan.
There are 25 countries that count on petroleum revenue for 20 percent or more of their foreign exchange earnings, according to the International Monetary Fund. There are also five oil exporters that count on oil revenues for 40 percent or more of their government budgets.
In Mexico, oil represents only 12 percent of total exports, but it supports 40 percent of Government spending, according to Merrill Lynch. In Venezuela, oil is a double whammy, accounting for 77 percent of exports and 57 percent of Government spending.
The value of the Mexican peso has fallen 10 percent this year. And even though the economy is growing briskly, the Government has just approved a third package of spending cuts, slicing $3.7 billion in all.
In Russia, which is a major exporter of commodities from oil to precious metals, the oil price drop hit in two ways. First, oil accounts for more than 20 percent of export earnings, but Russia has had to cut production by 350,000 barrels a day because the cost to extract and transport the oil is now more than the market price.
In addition, oil prices have foiled, so far, the sale of Rosneft, the last large state-owned oil company, undermining the Government's effort to raise needed cash.
Oil prices have shot up recently on the hope for significant cuts in production. But the two leading commodity indexes, the Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge index of 17 commodities and the Goldman Sachs index of 22 commodities, are only slightly above their recent lows.
And Japan, the key to the revival of the rest of Asia, has yet to prove it can get its economy or its currency back on track. So a commodity upturn is still more of a hope than a reality for the countries that sell them. ''The problem we face,'' said David Bassanese, senior economist at Bankers Trust in Sydney, Australia, ''is that the export recovery still hasn't arrived.''

Bond Prices Climb in Australia

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]02 Jan 1998: 8.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430922367?accountid=11752

Abstract: Australian bonds rose in the first trading session of 1998, amid optimism that cooling Asian economies will take the heat off domestic growth, and keep any risk of accelerating inflation at bay. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Bond+Prices+Climb+in+Australia&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1998-01-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.8&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00652546&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Australian bonds rose in the first trading session of 1998, amid optimism that cooling Asian economies will take the heat off domestic growth, and keep any risk of accelerating inflation at bay.
''The bond market will do well'' from Asia's financial turmoil, said Anthony Robson, chief fixed-interest trader at Westpac Bank in Sydney.
Asia, and the effect it is seen having on demand for Australian exports, ''is going to be the dampening spot for our economy,'' he said.
The benchmark October 2007 Government bonds added $6.04 Australian ($4 United States) today for each $1,000 Australian ($650 United States) face value. The yield fell 7basis points, to 5.98 percent.
The gains in Australian bonds were underpinned by a report in the United States this week that suggested that the American economy was growing with little inflation.
Even as Australian growth picks up -- aided by a jump in retail spending during summer vacations and more people finding full-time employment -- price increases by Australian producers and retailers are seen as restrained.
Helping to bolster optimism that inflation will be subdued were comments this week by the investor George Soros, who said the world was on the brink of international deflation as a result of the economic turmoil in Asia.
''What started out as a minor imbalance has become a much bigger one that threatens to engulf not only international credit but international trade,'' said Mr. Soros, chairman of Soros Fund Management and the primary investment adviser to Quantum Fund, in an article in The Financial Times on Wednesday.
Investors viewed Mr. Soros's comments as bullish for bonds.

Washington to Directly Contribute $5 Billion, at the Low End of Expectations

Author: Stevenson, Richard W

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]04 Dec 1997: 6.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430903894?accountid=11752

Abstract: The Clinton Administration said today that it would make as much as $5 billion available for the international bailout of South Korea, hoping to stabilize a country where the United States has considerable economic and security interests. The direct financing would back up $35 billion being provided through three international institutions to which the United States is the largest contributor: the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. The $5 billion commitment -- at the low end of what reports from South Korea had suggested Washington would contribute -- compares with $10 billion being offered for the South Korean package by Japan, and with the $3 billion in backup funds offered by the United States last month to Indonesia, whose economy is far smaller than South Korea's.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Washington+to+Directly+Contribute+%245+Billion%2C+at+the+Low+End+of+Expectations&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1997-12-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.6&amp;au=Stevenson%2C+Richard+W&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/00324804&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Clinton Administration said today that it would make as much as $5 billion available for the international bailout of South Korea, hoping to stabilize a country where the United States has considerable economic and security interests.
The direct financing would back up $35 billion being provided through three international institutions to which the United States is the largest contributor: the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
The $5 billion commitment -- at the low end of what reports from South Korea had suggested Washington would contribute -- compares with $10 billion being offered for the South Korean package by Japan, and with the $3 billion in backup funds offered by the United States last month to Indonesia, whose economy is far smaller than South Korea's.
The offer reflected a strategy adopted two weeks ago by the United States and many big Asian nations of calling on the I.M.F. and other international organizations to take the lead in dealing with financially troubled nations, but encouraging other governments with a stake in the region to offer supplemental aid when needed.
''We have a vital national economic and security interest in helping Korea restore market stability as soon as possible,'' Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said.
The American aid will be made available through a special fund under the Treasury Department's control, and does not require any Congressional authorization. Administration officials said they kept Congressional leaders informed about the situation, and said there were no signs the plan would run into serious opposition from Republican leaders.
But some Democrats and Republicans expressed misgivings, and said that when Congress reconvened next month they would raise questions about the Administration's request for even more funds for the I.M.F.
''It's very bad policy,'' said Representative Ron Paul, a Texas Republican, who has long argued that international bailouts put taxpayer money at risk and threaten the American economy by weakening the dollar and stimulating inflation, all to insulate banks and other investors from losses. ''With the exception of some bankers from Houston, I never hear from anyone who wants to sacrifice taxpayer dollars to go over there to bail someone out,'' Mr. Paul said today.
Democratic critics want to tie international bailouts and other financial aid to human rights issues and improved conditions for workers.
Administration officials defended both the I.M.F. package with South Korea and the American backup fund as effective ways to impose sweeping changes on the South Korean financial and economic systems. And they said that the last such American financing package -- a key element in the bailout of Mexico three years ago -- was fully repaid, with interest, helping close off the crisis there.
Officials said the United States agreed to provide additional financing only after determining that the I.M.F. package was tough enough on the Koreans to restore market confidence in their economy while reassuring American taxpayers that the Treasury Department was not throwing good money after bad.
A senior Treasury official said today that American aid would be released to South Korea only to fill any gaps in that country's financing needs between the release of I.M.F. installments. The American money would be provided for 60-day periods, with the possibility of extensions if needed. And it would be released only if Seoul continues to meet all the requirements of the I.M.F. program and if the Treasury Department thinks it will be repaid.
The money would come from the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a $40 billion pool administered by the Treasury Department and used at the discretion of the President. It was set up in the 1930'ss to give the Government ammunition to defend the dollar's value. It has been used increasingly, though, in maintaining the stability of global markets by helping beleaguered nations restore confidence in their currencies.
There have been periodic attempts by Congress to restrict the stabilization fund. Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, is currently pushing for legislation that would require that any disbursement of more than $250 million receive Congressional approval.
Mr. Faircloth said he would demand that the Administration accept such a restriction in return for Congressional approval of Mr. Clinton's request for $3.5 billion to bolster the I.M.F.'s finances. The Administration's request for that money was blocked last month by anti-abortion Republicans, who demanded restrictions on American support for international family planning programs in return for new I.M.F. support.
''I believe Robert Rubin needs to stop using the Exchange Stabilization Fund as a personal piggy bank for international bailouts,'' Mr. Faircloth said.
But Administration officials said that the problems in South Korea could impress on members of Congress the need to strengthen the I.M.F. The Administration won support on that today from four senior Republicans on the House Banking Committee, including the chairman, Representative Jim Leach of Iowa.
They sent a letter to Republican leaders urging them to support the additional funds for the I.M.F. and also for the United Nations, saying that the ability to halt global financial crises was in America's interest.
''With the financial future of Asia uncertain and the possibility of a full bailout of South Korea looming, a depleted I.M.F. may not be able to respond to a currency crisis that could have grave consequences in the United States,'' said Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey, the author of the letter.

O.E.C.D. Pleased With U.S. Economy

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]25 Nov 1997: 4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430871300?accountid=11752

Abstract: The United States economy looks well balanced in its seventh year of growth, with surprisingly low inflation despite tight labor markets, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report today. ''The United States has enjoyed a year of exceptionally good economic performance,'' the Paris-based group of 29 industrial countries said in its annual review. ''This is all the more remarkable in this, the seventh year of economic expansion.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=O.E.C.D.+Pleased+With+U.S.+Economy&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1997-11-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.4&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/04807196&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The United States economy looks well balanced in its seventh year of growth, with surprisingly low inflation despite tight labor markets, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report today.
''The United States has enjoyed a year of exceptionally good economic performance,'' the Paris-based group of 29 industrial countries said in its annual review. ''This is all the more remarkable in this, the seventh year of economic expansion.''
The O.E.C.D. forecast that gross domestic product in the United States in 1997 would grow by 3.8 percent, the fastest rate among the group's seven largest members and the highest since 1988.
The annual review, whose content was approved on Oct. 8, predicted that above-trend growth would continue through spring and said the inflation rate could increase to around 3 percent from its current level of just above 2 percent.
The O.E.C.D. said that keeping prices in check would probably require the Federal Reserve to raise short-term borrowing costs by as much as three-quarters of a percentage point ''to curb some interest-sensitive demand.''
The Fed last changed monetary policy on March 25, when it lifted the Federal funds overnight lending rate by a quarter-percentage point, to 5.5 percent. Despite the tightening, long-term interest rates and other market rates are lower since the spring. ''As a result, all of the restrictive effect of the March tightening has since been undone in the interim,'' the O.E.C.D. said. The group saw the biggest inflation risk coming from the labor market.

U.S. Wealth Gap Is Also a Vietnam War Legacy

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 Apr 1995: A.22.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430130812?accountid=11752

Abstract: Your timely April 17 article on wealth inequality in the United States ("Gap in Wealth in U.S. Called Widest in West," front page), closely following publication of Robert McNamara's book "In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam," prompts me to offer my opinion on the origin of the undesirable trend of extreme wealth inequality in the United States.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+Wealth+Gap+Is+Also+a+Vietnam+War+Legacy%3A+%5BLetter%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1995-04-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.22&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: To the Editor:
Your timely April 17 article on wealth inequality in the United States ("Gap in Wealth in U.S. Called Widest in West," front page), closely following publication of Robert McNamara's book "In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam," prompts me to offer my opinion on the origin of the undesirable trend of extreme wealth inequality in the United States.
In all the publicity that has accompanied Mr. McNamara's book, practically the only mention I've noted of the economic consequences of the Vietnam War was in your April 13 book review: "And McNamara faults President Johnson for failing to be more forthright with the American public about the growing expense of the war."
This understates the facts substantially! Lyndon Johnson deliberately lied to Congress and the American people and escalated the war by stealth, ignoring the warning of his advisers that the result of a failure to raise taxes to finance the war would be a dangerous increase in inflation. Prior to the escalation of the war the United States economy of the early 1960's was a practically utopian equilibrium combination of solid growth without inflation.
Johnson's policy set the stage for and began the inflation of the 1970's, which was made worse by the irrational economic policies of President Nixon and the unsound ones of Jimmy Carter. The dollar lost nearly half its purchasing power in the 1970's. This resulted in massive shifts of wealth toward upper-income groups, who are the owners of businesses and property. The real income of the lowest 20 percent income class declined substantially, while before 1967, income distribution among classes had been very stable.
I am of the strong belief that the trend to extreme wealth inequality in the United States has its origin in President Johnson's failure to finance the Vietnam War with a tax increase and that this result is one of the most serious enduring consequences of the ill-conceived Vietnam War. NEIL NAFTALIN Minneapolis, April 17, 1995 The writer is a stock market analyst.

Greenspan Reassures the G.O.P. on Planned Budget Cuts

Author: Sanger, David E

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 Feb 1995: D.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/430039106?accountid=11752

Abstract: Mr. [Alan Greenspan] also followed up on his suggestion last month that the Government's Consumer Price Index overstates inflation by recommending today that Congress appoint a special commission to pinpoint the upward bias in the inflation gauge. That way, he said, rather than altering the index itself, the Government could hold down the increase in the future cost of Social Security benefits, Federal pensions and other costs pegged to inflation in line with the commission's estimates. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Greenspan+Reassures+the+G.O.P.+on+Planned+Budget+Cuts&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1995-02-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.4&amp;au=Sanger%2C+David+E&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
Continuing his campaign for deep cuts in the Federal budget, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, reassured Republicans in Congress today that he would try to protect the economy from any damage that might be caused by their proposed spending reductions.
Mr. Greenspan also followed up on his suggestion last month that the Government's Consumer Price Index overstates inflation by recommending today that Congress appoint a special commission to pinpoint the upward bias in the inflation gauge. That way, he said, rather than altering the index itself, the Government could hold down the increase in the future cost of Social Security benefits, Federal pensions and other costs pegged to inflation in line with the commission's estimates.
In his second day of Congressional testimony, Mr. Greenspan echoed his statement on Wednesday that the economy shows signs of cooling off, hinting that the Federal Reserve would hold interest rates steady or even ease credit if there were signs of a sharp downturn.
Supporting that viewpoint were two economic indicators released today.
The Commerce Department said business investment in factories and equipment, a major source of economic strength for the last two years, should slow in 1995 to a much more moderate pace. American business plans to increase capital spending by 6.6 percent this year, to $592.9 billion, less than half the 13.7 percent jump recorded in 1994.
In the other report pointing to a slowing economy, the Labor Department said that first-time claims for unemployment benefits by newly laid-off Americans rose 2,000 last week, to 349,000. It was the highest since the week ended Jan. 7, which was skewed by holiday fluctuations. Excluding that week, it was the highest since last July.
These were the latest among several recent signs that the expansion is finally being braked by interest rate increases.
Mr. Greenspan, in his testimony today before the House Banking Committee, sought to reassure Congress that spending cuts would not make the slowdown any worse.
It is "unquestionable," Mr. Greenspan said, that in the long run, deep budget cuts would result in lower interest rates and better economic growth. But he added that if the cuts were so severe that they slowed the economy in the short term, "we obviously will respond to that."
Mr. Greenspan was clearly trying to head off an excuse for limiting budget cuts. If the absence of Government spending threatens to deflate the economy, he suggested, the Fed could offset the effect with lower interest rates. But he stopped short of supporting the Republican plan to pass a balanced budget amendment, and expressed doubts that tinkering with the Constitution was a wise way to set the nation's fiscal policy.

CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Prices Climb; 'Beige Book' Stirs Hope

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 Sep 1994: D.13.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429879195?accountid=11752

Abstract: "There's reason for optimism that inflation is not going to accelerate dramatically," said Steven Nothern, who manages $3.5 billion at Massachusetts Financial Services. Even so, "the inflation process is starting to move in fits and starts through the pipeline," he said. "We have seen a cyclical change in inflation," Mr. [Michael Strauss] said. "Is it dramatic? No." "Freddie Mac Yields" tracks average weekly yields on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 30-year and 15-year participation certificates since June. Yields track changes in fixed-rate mortgages. (Source: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.)

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS%3B+Treasury+Prices+Climb%3B+%27Beige+Book%27+Stirs+Hope&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1994-09-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.13&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: By Bloomberg Business News
Treasury prices were slightly higher yesterday after two economic reports met the market's expectations.
Trading was slowed by a computer glitch at the Chicago Board of Trade, where trading in bonds futures contracts was halted for nearly four hours.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 1/16 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.67 percent, from 7.68 percent on Tuesday.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales surged eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $186.56 billion for August. Despite the strong showing, analysts still see little reason for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates before its November policy meeting.
A report by the Fed, its so-called beige book survey of economic conditions, said that competition among companies was keeping retail price increases subdued as the economy slowly expanded.
"There's reason for optimism that inflation is not going to accelerate dramatically," said Steven Nothern, who manages $3.5 billion at Massachusetts Financial Services. Even so, "the inflation process is starting to move in fits and starts through the pipeline," he said.
Fed policy makers will consider the beige book report in deciding whether to push interest rates higher at their Sept. 27 meeting. The report suggests the Fed will not raise rates again until November, said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America).
"We have seen a cyclical change in inflation," Mr. Strauss said. "Is it dramatic? No."
The Government reported on Tuesday that consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, matching increases in June and July. Inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was at a 2.9 percent annual rate through August, up from 2.8 percent for the first eight months of last year and 2.7 percent for all of last year.
In its survey, the Fed said wage inflation was possible amid "more reports of tightening labor markets than before, though wage pressures are still described as modest."
Today, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia is scheduled to report on prices paid by 150 manufacturers in Pennsylvania, Delaware and southern New Jersey. Bonds tumbled after last month's Philadelphia Fed report, which said the bank's prices-paid index surged to a five-year high.
In the corporate bond market, seven businesses sold a total of $1.78 billion in bonds yesterday.
The Nissan Motor Company sold $642 million in bonds. First National Bank of Boston, a unit of the New England bank holding company the Bank of Boston Corporation, sold $200 million of 10-year notes. Bear Stearns Companies sold $200 million of five-year notes.
Other sales included a $175 million offering by the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Government-owned utility, and an $80 million sale by the Michigan Gas Corporation. TCI Communications Inc., a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., sold $300 million of 10-year debt. Chevy Chase Savings Bank sold $181.9 million of floating-rate securities backed by home equity loans, according to MCM Corporate Watch.
Bonds backed by mortgages of the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae, led mortgage-backed securities higher, following news of programs that will make the securities easier to trade.
Ginnie Mae 8 percent pass- throughs for October delivery rose as much as 1/4, to 985/32 , to yield 8.41 percent, three basis points less than yesterday. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Ginnie Mae and the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, said yesterday that they would begin bundling mortgage-backed bonds for investors.
Correction: September 16, 1994, Friday
A chart in Business Day yesterday, with an article about the credit markets, included incorrect figures supplied by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, for the average weekly yields on participation certificates. The yield for the 15-year certificate is 7.83 percent, not 8.18 percent, and the yield for the 30-year certificate is 8.31 percent, not 8.66 percent.

For the Nations of the Western Hemisphere, Renewed Growth: Canada; Strong Growth But Weak on Jobs

Author: Farnsworth, Clyde H

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]03 Jan 1994: C.6.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429436362?accountid=11752

Abstract: Steel, lumber, automotive parts, lead and zinc and other industrial products are in demand to support the economic expansion in the United States, which takes 80 percent of Canada's exports. In turn, exports are a quarter of Canada's gross domestic product. So, while the economy strengthens, the mood here is still morose. "Company downsizing spooks consumer spending," said Ranga Chand, senior economist at Burns Fry Ltd., Canada's leading investment house. Room for maneuver is relatively tight. The Federal deficit is 6 percent of the gross domestic product, double the 3 percent level in the United States. About 40 percent of Canada's debt is held abroad, meaning that unless a deficit-cutting program has credibility, foreigners are likely to dump Canadian securities and the Canadian dollar, which at around 75 cents to the United States dollar is already near its lowest levels in six years.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=For+the+Nations+of+the+Western+Hemisphere%2C+Renewed+Growth%3A+Canada%3B+Strong+Growth+But+Weak+on+Jobs&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1994-01-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.6&amp;au=Farnsworth%2C+Clyde+H&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Canada is struggling to get back on its feet economically after heavy-duty structural changes the last half-dozen years, including the painful redirection of resources in response to freer trade, disinflation, new technology and changes in the nation's tax laws.
The convalescence demonstrates how closely linked the patient is to its huge southern neighbor. The economy is growing again but not because of any quickening in the pace of domestic consumption. The engine is exports, chiefly to the United States, which are setting new monthly records.
Steel, lumber, automotive parts, lead and zinc and other industrial products are in demand to support the economic expansion in the United States, which takes 80 percent of Canada's exports. In turn, exports are a quarter of Canada's gross domestic product.
Cuts in inflation, now below 2 percent, and gains in productivity in most industries have sharpened competitiveness and led most forecasters to see steady improvement in growth over the next couple of years.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based agency that periodically rates industrialized countries' economic performance, predicts Canada will outpace every member but Turkey over the next two years, with a 3.7 percent expansion in 1994 and a 4.1 percent gain in 1995 -- up from 2.5 percent in 1993.
Yet because of continued corporate downsizing and increasing use of labor-saving technology, no significant drops are foreseen in unemployment, which has hovered around 11 percent over the past three years.
Many economists believe that growth must climb nearer 5 percent before unemployment starts falling; yet forecasts by the O.E.C.D. and others suggest there is not much chance of this any time soon.
So, while the economy strengthens, the mood here is still morose. "Company downsizing spooks consumer spending," said Ranga Chand, senior economist at Burns Fry Ltd., Canada's leading investment house.
Another problem is the huge Government deficit, forcing interest payments and debt ever higher. The new Liberal Government vows to do something about it, but people will not know what it has up its sleeve until the February budget.
Room for maneuver is relatively tight. The Federal deficit is 6 percent of the gross domestic product, double the 3 percent level in the United States. About 40 percent of Canada's debt is held abroad, meaning that unless a deficit-cutting program has credibility, foreigners are likely to dump Canadian securities and the Canadian dollar, which at around 75 cents to the United States dollar is already near its lowest levels in six years.
The question is whether the Government will cut spending or raise taxes. Either way will be a drag on economic growth, further postponing the end of double-digit joblessness.
On bright spot has been the stock market, which enjoyed a record 1993. The Toronto Stock Exchange 300-share index surged 29 percent to 4321.40, and many analysts foresee further advances of 10 percent to 20 percent this year, given the strength in both the economy and corporate earnings. CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

CREDIT MARKETS; Gamble That Inflation Stays Low

Author: FUERBRINGER, JONATHAN

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 May 1993: D.12.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/429065764?accountid=11752

Abstract: "Whether this turns out to be a good thing or a bad thing is whether they follow good economic policy or bad economic policy for the next several years," William Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said yesterday. "That is another way of saying that inflation stays low." Debt Mix Shift Applauded "As the Treasury finances short term, its financing costs are more variable," he said. "As inflation goes up, interest costs will go up, so Treasury has an additional incentive in the fight against inflation." "Tax-Exempt Yields" tracks average weekly yields for 20 general obligation bonds and 25 revenue bonds since January. (Source: The Bond Buyer); "Freddie Mac Yields" tracks average weekly yields on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 30-year and 15-year participation certificates over the same period. Yields track changes in fixed-rate mortgages. (Source: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.)

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETS%3B+Gamble+That+Inflation+Stays+Low&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1993-05-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.12&amp;au=FUERBRINGER%2C+JONATHAN&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Clinton Treasury is betting that the Clinton Presidency will succeed in creating a low-inflation environment over the next several years and that the President's successor will follow suit.
That is the gamble that the Treasury took this week when it announced that it would shift 45 percent of its longer-term borrowing to shorter- term maturities of from three years to three months. If the bet proves wrong and inflation does not stay low, taxpayers will be paying higher interest costs.
"Whether this turns out to be a good thing or a bad thing is whether they follow good economic policy or bad economic policy for the next several years," William Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said yesterday. "That is another way of saying that inflation stays low." Debt Mix Shift Applauded
The economist Henry Kaufman, who applauded the Treasury debt mix shift, added, "It is betting on your own economic policy."
But Mr. Kaufman also said that the shift, by helping to lower intermediate and long-term interest rates slightly, would assist the private sector, which he said should be a more important goal of the policy change.
"The Treasury should follow a policy that will be supportive of the economic recovery even if it is only in a marginal sense," Mr. Kaufman said. And, he said, borrowing more with short-term securities is a positive incentive for the Treasury.
"As the Treasury finances short term, its financing costs are more variable," he said. "As inflation goes up, interest costs will go up, so Treasury has an additional incentive in the fight against inflation."
Bringing the deficit under control, which has looked less likely in recent weeks because of the problems of President Clinton in getting his programs through Congress, is the kind of long-term repair the economy needs, analysts say. That would help foster confidence and help keep long-term interest rates coming down, making more investors believe that inflation will remain low.
Such a trend could lead to lower long-term interest rates and, at the same time, only small increases in short-term interest rates as the economy begins to pick up pace. In that case, it would be advisable to cut some long-term borrowing because long rates would be falling. And it would not be so risky to add to short-term borrowing because short-term interest rates would not likely rise enough to erase the savings gained by shifting from higher-interest-rate long-term borrowing to lower-interest-rate shorter-term borrowing.
But this blend of economic policies may also require that the economy grow at just a moderate pace, which would mean that the President's goal of creating millions of new jobs would be harder to attain.
There is another way to make the debt shift work, but that would be an even less desired condition for the Administration: a new recession that would bring both short- and long-term rates and inflation lower. Move Seen Well Considered
Analysts who do not support what the Treasury did on Wednesday -- which included a 40 percent reduction in the annual issuance of 30-year bonds; a shift to two, instead of four, 30-year auctions a year, and the elimination of the seven-year note -- do agree that the move was well considered. They say it was not just an all-out effort to cut borrowing costs and push interest rates lower by eliminating long-term borrowing. If this were the case, the Treasury could have eliminated the 30-year bond auction scheduled for next week and reduced the level of 10-year note borrowing.
"Given that they had made the bad decision to shorten the maturity of the debt, they went about it in a quite reasonable way." said Louis Crandall, the chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates. Treasury Market
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as traders and investors awaited the Labor Department report on April employment, which is to be released this morning.
In the last 16 months, the price of the 30-year bond has rallied and the yield has fallen eight times in the week ahead of the employment report. This week became the ninth time as the yield on the long bond fell to 6.80 percent, from 6.92 percent last Friday.
Forecasters are expecting a moderate increase in nonfarm payroll jobs in the range of 157,000, according to Bloomberg Business News. But what is more important is the impression about the strength of the economy that the report leaves with traders and investors. A feeling that the economy has bounced back from the weather-related slowdown in March would make it harder for yields to break out of their current trading range and move to new lows.
In secondary trading, the price of the 30-year bond was down 6/32 as the yield rose to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent Wednesday, which leaves the bond little changed since the debt announcement. The price of the seven- year note fell 5/32 , to yield 5.51 percent. But despite the shift to shorter-term borrowing, prices of two-and three-year notes were up marginally and the discount rates on Treasury bills fell.
