Zaire's Dictator Agrees to Share Power With Foe

Author: Noble, Kenneth B

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]30 Sep 1991: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428185735?accountid=11752

Abstract: "This is incredible -- [Mobutu Sese Seko] has committed political suicide," said Olivier Kasongo, an opposition leader who was among the hundreds who gathered this morning at the conference center where President Mobutu and opposition leaders held their talks. In particular, Zaire's role as a conduit for arms for United States-backed rebels in Angola led by Jonas Savimbi virtually assured continuing support for the Mobutu leadership. At the same time, President Mobutu has maintained strong ties with Belgium while developing relations with France and South Africa. Mr. [Nguza] has also had a checkered career. In the late 1970's after serving as prime minister, he became one of President Mobutu's severest critics and in 1980 was sentenced to death for treason. The sentence was later reduced to a long prison term. Mr. Nguza later testified before a United States Congressional committee investigating reports that President Mobutu had embezzled aid funds from the United States.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Zaire%27s+Dictator+Agrees+to+Share+Power+With+Foe%3A+%5BBiography%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-09-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Noble%2C+Kenneth+B&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has held absolute power in this impoverished Central African country for 26 years while amassing a personal fortune, today agreed to let an opposition leader form a new coalition government that could mark the end of his autocratic reign.
President Mobutu's agreement to share power was first announced Saturday night and confirmed when a deadlock in negotiations over the choice of a new prime minister was broken today.
The accord followed a week of looting and violence touched off by mutinous soldiers angered because they had not been paid. Discontent had been rising for months, however, as the country reeled from a severe economic crisis and as opposition leaders pressed to have Zaire join the democratic trend sweeping much of Africa. Mobutu to Keep Title
After 10 hours of talks today with opposition leaders, President Mobutu agreed to allow Etienne Tshisekedi, his fiercest adversary since 1980, to become Prime Minister and form what is being called a crisis government. Under this arrangement, General Mobutu would remain head of state with as-yet undefined but apparently diminished powers.
Five Mobutu loyalists would have posts in an 11-member coalition government under the accord, with the remaining posts going to the opposition.
The two sides are to meet again Monday for the third successive day to try to agree on Cabinet posts. Despite hope stirred by the developments, there appeared to be a strong prospect of further political chaos . Delegates to a democracy conference gathered outside the talks at Kinshasa's marble palace and vowed to kill any opposition leaders who allowed President Mobutu to remain in Government even as a figurehead.
The protesters blocked the entrance to the center where the talks were held and then swarmed around President Mobutu as he arrived. They shouted "dictator" and "thief" when he ventured into the crowd, wearing his trademark leopard-skin hat, and tried to explain the reasons for forming the coalition. Inside, the delegates did their best to ignore the turbulence, dining on smoked salmon and drinking Champagne for lunch.
The delegates were angered at being left out of the talks. They said the national conference, whose 3,000 delegates are scheduled to reconvene Tuesday in a continuing effort to chart a path to democracy, should instead manage the transition. Talks Began Seven Weeks Ago
The current political negotiating process started seven weeks ago, but because of a dispute over the selection of delegates, it bogged down. Opponents charged that President Mobutu filled the lists with his own supporters.
Only the major opposition parties are involved in talks on forming a new government. Many of the leaders of those parties have served under President Mobutu at one time but have since broken with him.
In an apparent effort to re-establish control over the military, President Mobutu announced the dismissal of his army Chief of Staff, Gen. Manzembe Mayibanga, and ordered a complete restructuring of the armed forces. The general was replaced by the current head of military intelligence, Gen. Mahele Liyeko, officials said.
Last Monday, about 3,000 Zairian paratroopers touched off widespread rioting and looting as they went on a rampage after the Government had failed to pay them for months. They closed Kinshasa's airport and Congo River port, looting stores and private housesmostly owned or rented by Zaire's wealthy expatriates.
As the pillaging and unrest spread, France and Belgium flew in hundreds of special troops to evacuate their citizens from the former Belgian colony.
The national radio station said today that 117 people had been killed and nearly 160 others injured in the wave of rioting that swept through this dilapidated city and elsewhere in the country. The streets were deserted at nightfall, with soldiers scattered along the roads enforcing a dawn-to-dusk curfew. Most stores and offices in the capital were shuttered, and the airport remained closed to commercial traffic. Figurehead Status Possible
Opposition figures and Western diplomats interviewed this weekend were reluctant to give a timetable for what many consider the inevitable downfall of President Mobutu. But several diplomats suggested that his fortunes had sunk so low that he might now be persuaded to remain in power as essentially a figurehead, presiding over a transitional government until elections are held.
"This is incredible -- Mobutu has committed political suicide," said Olivier Kasongo, an opposition leader who was among the hundreds who gathered this morning at the conference center where President Mobutu and opposition leaders held their talks.
A senior Western diplomat with extensive experience in Africa said: "It is not in our interest that Mobutu suddenly disappear. What may replace him is unclear, and meanwhile, the situation could prove chaotic."
Even if the differences between the President and the opposition can be bridged, it is not clear how the people of Zaire will react as they face an economic crisis of unprecedented proportions.
One sign of the continuing deterioration of the security situation here was the sudden and unexpected departure of the entire European staff of the Inter-Continental Hotel. Soon after the rioting began last week, troops from the presidential guard surrounded the hotel. Not long afterward, several hundred French, Belgian and other expatriates sought refuge there.
On Friday night, however, marauding soldiers from the presidential guard reportedly moved to the tree-lined streets near the hotel, using rifles or pistols to shoot out padlocks and smash down doors. Apparently fearing that the attacks might spread to the hotel, the foreign staff fled this afternoon.
In all of sub-Saharan Africa, Zaire has one of the worst reputations for official corruption and economic mismanagement. According to African and Western diplomats, as well as numerous scholars on Zaire, President Mobutu has used his position to make himself one of the world's richest men. Critics estimate his personal fortune at $4 billion.
Even his harshest critics, however, give him high marks for having woven together a nation out of nearly 250 often-feuding ethnic groups. He has achieved this through a mix of political acumen, personal appeal and strong-arm tactics. Economic Policy Faulted
But his economic leadership is held in far lower regard. In early 1990, the Government abandoned an economomic recovery program devised by the International Monetary Fund. At the same time, Government spending ballooned. The resulting budget deficit helped push annual inflation in Zaire to an estimated 900 percent to 1,000 percent, its highest level since 1960, the year of independence from Belgium.
Meanwhile, because of deficit spending and a sharp decrease in the availability of foreign exchange, the national currency, the zaire, has depreciated rapidly against the American dollar. In January 1990, the zairecq traded at about 300 to the dollar; the official exchange rate is now about 19,000 to the dollar.
Workers typically earn in a month the money needed to survive just one week, and many have second jobs. Many Zairians complain that they have no money to buy anything, and if they did, there is little in stores to buy.
When confronted with accusations of corruption and mismanagement, the 60-year-old leader has insisted that he is a victim of disinformation. He has also blamed external factors like weak commodity prices for the growing civil strife and the country's sharply deteriorating standard of living. Hundreds of Millions From U.S.
President Mobutu's Government has received hundreds of millions of dollars from the United States since he seized power in a 1965 military coup. The Central Intelligence Agency is said to haveworked closely with President Mobutu for years. Historians have written that American officials knew about, and some say even helped, his successful coup. The takeover followed five years of bitter factional fighting in the country among Marxists with Soviet ties, pro-Western moderate reformers, and a neo-colonial leadership in what was then Katanga province, in the nation's south.
In particular, Zaire's role as a conduit for arms for United States-backed rebels in Angola led by Jonas Savimbi virtually assured continuing support for the Mobutu leadership. At the same time, President Mobutu has maintained strong ties with Belgium while developing relations with France and South Africa.
But amid allegations of a massacre of 12 university students by security forces in May 1990, and possibly several times that number, the United States Congress voted in December to cut all military and economic aid to Zaire.
If President Mobutu should leave the political scene, the leading candidates to fill the vacuum are thought to be Mr. Tshisekedi, the head of the largest opposition group, the Union for Democracy and Social Process, and a former Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Nguza Karl-i-Bond. Both have been accused at various times of having been co-opted by President Mobutu; however, Mr. Nguza has also felt the President's wrath, serving years in prison when he fell from official grace.
In 1967, Mr. Tshisekedi was instrumental in writing a document that helped set up President Mobutu's one-party state, but in 1981, he was one of 13 members of Parliament who broke with the leader. They signed a letter accusing the Goverment of corruption, human rights abuses and the stifling of democracy.
Mr. Nguza has also had a checkered career. In the late 1970's after serving as prime minister, he became one of President Mobutu's severest critics and in 1980 was sentenced to death for treason. The sentence was later reduced to a long prison term. Mr. Nguza later testified before a United States Congressional committee investigating reports that President Mobutu had embezzled aid funds from the United States.
Nonetheless, in 1986 President Mobutu sent Mr. Nguza to Washington as Zaire's Ambassador to the United States.
Photograph President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has agreed to a governing arrangement that could mark the end of his autocratic reign. He talked with reporters before he met with opposition party members yesterday. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A6)

Venezuela Is Surging Again After a Period of Difficulties

Author: Brooke, James

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Sep 1991: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428202261?accountid=11752

Abstract: "We are back to the fastest-growing economy in the region," said Andres Sosa Pietri, president of Petroleos de Venezuela, S.A., the national oil company. "We lagged in the '80s, but now we are back on our feet." Michael Skol, the United States Ambassador here, predicted, "Venezuela is likely to have a sustained economic boom in the 1990's, with growth rates higher than Chile's." Venezuela ships two-thirds of its daily exports of 1.9 million barrels to the United States. With oil production plummeting in the Soviet Union and political uncertainty gripping the Middle East, Venezuela likes to portray itself as a "safe source." To meet growing demand from the United States, the oil company plans to increase production capacity by 20 percent, to 3.5 million barrels a day, by 1996.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Venezuela+Is+Surging+Again+After+a+Period+of+Difficulties&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-09-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=Brooke%2C+James&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Special to The New York Times
After a hiccup caused by low oil prices and a shift to free-market policies, Venezuela has reclaimed its position as the nation in the Americas with the highest economic growth rates.
The gross national product, which grew 5 percent in 1990, expanded by an annualized rate of 10 percent during the first half of this year, according to figures released here in late August.
Memories are now fading of 1989, the rough first year of President Carlos Andres Perez. That year, the economy shrank by 8 percent and a reduction of food and gas subsidies set off riots that killed 300 people.
"We are back to the fastest-growing economy in the region," said Andres Sosa Pietri, president of Petroleos de Venezuela, S.A., the national oil company. "We lagged in the '80s, but now we are back on our feet."
Michael Skol, the United States Ambassador here, predicted, "Venezuela is likely to have a sustained economic boom in the 1990's, with growth rates higher than Chile's."
Although annual inflation continues to hover around 37 percent, optimism is growing. American, European and Venezuelan companies are embarking on multibillion-dollar "megaprojects" involving Venezuela's highly profitable oil and minerals.
And President Perez's determined commitment to free-market policies appears to be bearing fruit, as trade tariffs drop, investment rules ease and the Government starts to sell money-losing state companies to investors.
In early August, the Government accepted a $145 million bid by a consortium led by Iberia, the Spanish airline, to buy a 60 percent stake in the state-owned international airline, Viasa. In October, private companies are to bid for the state telephone company, whose inefficiency has long hampered the economy.
During a visit to New York and Washington scheduled for late September, Mr. Perez plans to discuss with United States officials a timetable for establishing a free-trade agreement. Since taking office in February 1989, Mr. Perez has reduced import tariffs to 10 percent, on average, from 34 percent. In April, Venezuela signed a framework agreement with the United States for trade and investment liberalization.
Leading a Congressional delegation to Caracas in late August, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, said Mr. Perez had shown "great leadership in opening markets and in helping to develop trade between our two great countries." A 'Safe Source' of Oil
Accounting for about half the growth forecast through 1996 is a five-year, $48 billion expansion program by the national oil company.
Venezuela ships two-thirds of its daily exports of 1.9 million barrels to the United States. With oil production plummeting in the Soviet Union and political uncertainty gripping the Middle East, Venezuela likes to portray itself as a "safe source." To meet growing demand from the United States, the oil company plans to increase production capacity by 20 percent, to 3.5 million barrels a day, by 1996.
Foreign companies are entering new areas of the petroelum industry. In November, about 20 American and foreign companies are expected to submit bids to reactivate marginal fields that have been abandoned in eastern Venezuela. Total predicted production of these fields is expected to be 150,000 barrels a day. Natural Gas Project
In another project, Government approval is expected later this year for a $3 billion natural gas processing plant to be built with multinational control. Called Cristobal Colon, the project involves Mitsubishi, Shell Oil and Exxon.
"It will be the first time since the nationalization of the oil industry in 1975 that foreigners will have majority equities," said Mr. Skol, the American Ambassador.
The national oil company is also negotiating with American and European companies on multibillion-dollar joint ventures to exploit Venezuela's vast coal and bitumen reserves.
After the privatization of only three banks in two and a half years, efforts to sell state companies appear to have accelerated with the sale of Viasa in August. Fondo de Inversiones de Venezuela, a state agency charged with privatization, is accepting bids for a number of state companies -- a shipyard, a cement company, four hotels and several sugar mills.
But the most keenly awaited sale is that of the telephone company.
With half of Venezuela's demand for three million lines going unmet, it takes eight years to get a telephone installed. Some offices employ secretaries simply to dial and redial numbers. One United States company, Procter & Gamble, gave up and installed a $150,000 private microwave system after moving here in 1987, and other companies have shied away from Venezuela because of weak telecommunications.
"There are a lot of projects in tourism, trade and industry asking for services we can't offer," said Fernando Martinez Mottola, president of the phone company, Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela. Winning a $98 Million Bid
In a first step to privatize telephone service, a consortium led by BellSouth Enterprises and Racal Telecom submitted a winning $98 million bid in May to provide 20 years of cellular telephone service.
In October, eight international consortiums are to bid on buying the phone company, which has 20,000 employees, a $600 million debt and enormous growth prospects.
According to the tender, the buyer will have to install an average of 300,000 lines a year over the next five years, and by the end of the 1990's, the wait for a new phone must be no more than a week.
Photograph President Carlos Andres Perez's commitment to free-market policies appears to be bearing fruit, as Venezuela has reclaimed its position as the nation in the Americas with the highest economic growth rates. (James Brooke/The New York Times) (pg. D2)

Consumer Prices Rose 0.2% in July

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 Aug 1991: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428181076?accountid=11752

Abstract: "Inflation prospects are terrific," said Robert Brusca, an economist at Nikko Securities Company International Inc. But he added, "We do not have a recovery in the bag." Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher said: "Very low inflation is a welcome development for consumer purchasing power. This news creates the right environment for possible additional reductions in market interest rates." Fed Would Have Leeway Despite subdued price rises, the Labor Department also said today that Americans' purchasing power -- as measured by inflation-adjusted average weekly earnings -- slipped 1.4 percent in July after rising nine-tenths of 1 percent in June. The drop came from a large decrease in average hours worked and a slight dip in average hourly earnings.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Consumer+Prices+Rose+0.2%25+in+July&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-08-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: AP
Held in check by the sharpest drop in grocery costs in nearly four decades, consumer prices rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today.
The slight rise helped to hold the 1991 inflation rate so far to 2.7 percent, less than half last year's pace of 6.1 percent.
The small, seasonally adjusted rise in the Consumer Price Index was viewed as both a symptom of the recession and a necessary ingredient of a sustained recovery. It followed an identical rise in June.
The financial markets, which expected good news on inflation, were encouraged, and bond prices soared to levels not seen since early February. [ Page D17. ] The Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply early in the day when the data came out, although it fell back later to close 3.35 points down. [ Page D10. ] 1.2% Drop in Grocery Prices
The July data largely reflected a 1.2 percent drop in grocery prices, the largest one-month decline since 1953. The grocery numbers included a 12.7 percent drop in prices for fresh vegetables as crops rebounded from earlier weather problems.
In addition, energy prices fell for the seventh time in eight months.
Prices excluding the volatile food and energy items -- considered a good measure of core inflation -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the same rate as in June.
A senior Bush Administration official said subdued inflation would revive consumer spending and lower interest rates, but some private forecasters warn that the economy could suffer a relapse.
"Inflation prospects are terrific," said Robert Brusca, an economist at Nikko Securities Company International Inc. But he added, "We do not have a recovery in the bag."
Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher said: "Very low inflation is a welcome development for consumer purchasing power. This news creates the right environment for possible additional reductions in market interest rates." Fed Would Have Leeway
Dampened inflation gives policy makers at the Federal Reserve, who are scheduled to meet privately Tuesday, leeway to stimulate economic growth with lower interest rates if necessary, economists said. The last move by the Fed to push short-term interest rates down came Aug. 6, with a quarter of a percentage point cut in the Federal Funds rate.
Despite subdued price rises, the Labor Department also said today that Americans' purchasing power -- as measured by inflation-adjusted average weekly earnings -- slipped 1.4 percent in July after rising nine-tenths of 1 percent in June. The drop came from a large decrease in average hours worked and a slight dip in average hourly earnings.
In another report, the Commerce Department said business sales in June rose a weak two-tenths of 1 percent. Businesses still managed to shrink their inventories by three-tenths of 1 percent. That should pave the way for new orders, increased production and job gains when consumer demand strengthens.
Two private surveys showed business executives were not becoming more optimistic about the economy.
The United States Chamber of Commerce said only 40 percent of 7,057 businesses surveyed in August believed the economy is headed up, compared with 46 percent in June. Optimism Index Slips
The National Federation of Independent Business, which represents smaller businesses, said its optimism index slipped to 100 in July from 101 three months earlier.
The July inflation report reflected improving fruit and vegetable crops following severe weather earlier in the year. The price of both lettuce and tomatoes fell more than 20 percent for the month.
The various changes left the Consumer Price Index, before adjusting for seasonal variations, at 136.2 in July, compared with 130.4 a year earlier. That means a market basket of goods and services costing $136.20 last month would have cost $130.40 in July 1990.

An Exception to Rule of War: Inflation Threat Is Receding

Author: Nasar, Sylvia

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]10 Mar 1991: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/428009019?accountid=11752

Abstract: California's drought and recent freeze notwithstanding, food prices are also moderating. Prices had been climbing at close to a 6 percent rate for the last two years, faster than inflation. Now the Department of Agriculture's official forecast calls for advances of 2 to 5 percent, with the department's chief forecaster, Ralph Parlett, saying that "awful things would have to happen to hit the upper forecast range." Though the Fed has been loosening gradually since the spring of 1989 and more aggressively this winter, money growth on average has been far lower in the last four years than in the first half of the 80's. In particular, the Federal Reserve did not react to last summer's oil price shock by flooding the economy with money. "That was a very important decision," said Lynn Reaser, an economist at First Interstate Bancorp. "Very few companies were able to pass on the rise in energy costs." Sluggish Growth "Declining Indicators," tracks inflation, 1988-1990 (Source: Center for International Business Cycle Research); "The Cost of Labor is Declining," tracks percent change in compensation for labor over pervious 12-month period, March-Dec. 1990 (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics) (pg. 24)

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=An+Exception+to+Rule+of+War%3A+Inflation+Threat+Is+Receding&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1991-03-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Nasar%2C+Sylvia&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: From the Revolution to Vietnam, virtually every American war has sparked a round of inflation. But the Persian Gulf war looks as if it will be an exception. A barrage of signals -- including cheaper oil and raw materials, softer prices at factories, swelling cattle herds and shrinking bonuses for sales workers -- suggests that inflation may retreat.
The drop could be striking, and price increases could well stay low for years. The most compelling reason for thinking so is the Federal Reserve's four-year spell of stinginess in pumping cash and credit into the economy. Since 1987, the money supply has grown, on average, at just half the rate of the early 80's.
"We've built the foundation for lower inflation," said W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, noting that the Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, have been committed to nudging inflation down by gradually reducing money growth. Economy Would Gain
If inflation stays low, the economy would benefit. The United States would fall closer in line with such rich and powerful nations as Germany and Japan, whose inflation rates have averaged half of the United States rate, or less, in the last decade. And long-term interest rates could edge down as investors' fears of future inflation eased.
What is more, future recessions would probably be milder than the harsh downturns that ruptured the high-inflation years. One reason that most economists expect the current recession to be shorter and shallower is that inflation has not raced out of control.
Many forecasters, including those at the Federal Reserve, expect consumer price inflation to average 3 to 4 percent this year, compared with an annual rate of almost 7 percent in the second half of 1990. For the next few months, the rate could hover around 2 percent, forecasters at DRI/McGraw-Hill said, as the lower cost of a barrel of crude oil works its way into a broad spectrum of consumer prices. Last fall, spot oil prices shot toward $40 a barrel; now, oil is trading at about $18 a barrel.
That would give consumer buying power a welcome boost and help stabilize spending. "It's like a $16 billion personal tax cut and is worth $170 per household," said Roger E. Brinner, the chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
Among the reasons the Persian Gulf War seems not to have been inflationary are that it lasted only 42 days, quickly contained the threat to oil supplies, was financed in part by American allies and was fought with armstaken from inventory. Ordinarily, military spending overheats the economy as production surges to supply the war effort, leaving fewer goods available for civilian consumption. As a result prices rise. More Room for the Fed
The lower oil prices now give the Federal Reserve more room to fight the recession. "Because a lessening of cost pressures has improved the outlook for prices, the easing of policy has been possible without raising new concerns in the financial markets about inflation prospects." Mr. Greenspan testified before Congress on Wednesday. And on Friday, the Federal Reserve once again pushed down interest rates.
This low-inflation scenario could stumble if, for example, oil prices took off again, the dollar suddenly plunged, or state and local governments jacked up taxes sky high in an attempt to solve their budget problems. But the Federal Reserve's semiannual monetary policy report, issued on Feb. 20, alludes to the "downward tilt of the underlying inflation trend." That view is shared by Administration and Congressional economists, as well as many private forecasters.
There has already been a basic improvement in price trends -- as any driver who has recently pulled up to a gasoline pump can attest -- but it has been largely obscured in official inflation measures because of a rash of one-time events and statistical flukes. One-Time Hits
To take just one example: Higher Federal excise taxes on gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes will probably exaggerate this winter's inflation rate by more than one-third, John F. Peterson, an economist at the Congressional Budget Office, estimated. Other special factors were the 17 percent postal rate increase that went into effect last month and the second installment of the minimum wage increase. These onetime hits should be absorbed in a month or two.
Four forces are helping to beat down inflation, most economists agree: weaker commodity prices, especially for energy and food, which together account for about one-fifth of consumer spending; the recession, preceded by a year and a half of extremely sluggish economic growth; slackening wage gains, and, finally, signs that productivity outside manufacturing is holding up better than expected during the downturn. A major factor in each, most analysts say, is the Federal Reserve's monetary restraint in recent years.
The immediate source of relief is, of course, cheaper crude oil. At around $18, oil prices are back where they were in the first half of 1990. They should bobble around $20 in this year's second half, down from $24.40 in the comparable period last year, said Adam E. Sieminski, an economist at the Washington Analysis Group.
Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, commented, "Indirectly, that's slowing prices charged by metals and paper manufacturers, on the one hand, and airlines and hotels on the other."
And David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, said, "The prices of key industrial commodities are falling because the world economy is much weaker now."
California's drought and recent freeze notwithstanding, food prices are also moderating. Prices had been climbing at close to a 6 percent rate for the last two years, faster than inflation. Now the Department of Agriculture's official forecast calls for advances of 2 to 5 percent, with the department's chief forecaster, Ralph Parlett, saying that "awful things would have to happen to hit the upper forecast range."
Though the Fed has been loosening gradually since the spring of 1989 and more aggressively this winter, money growth on average has been far lower in the last four years than in the first half of the 80's. In particular, the Federal Reserve did not react to last summer's oil price shock by flooding the economy with money. "That was a very important decision," said Lynn Reaser, an economist at First Interstate Bancorp. "Very few companies were able to pass on the rise in energy costs." Sluggish Growth
The consequence of monetary restraint was sluggish growth even before Saddam Hussein toppled the economy into recession. "Spare capacity in factories and looser labor markets make it harder for business and workers to push for price and wage gains," Mr. Rippe of Dean Witter Reynolds said.
As a consequence, compensation costs are moderating. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' employment cost index rose 4.6 percent in December from a year earlier, down from an increase of 5.2 percent in June. Slow growth and recession pushed unemployment up to 6.5 percent in February from its low of 5.3 percent last June. As long as unemployment stays above what is considered full employment -- which most economists put at 5.5 to 6 percent -- employment costs should keep moderating.
The trend is especially evident among service companies that are squeezing some of their highest-paid help, salespeople, real estate agents and stockbrokers. "The upscale labor market is flabbier than it's ever been," said Stephen Strongin of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. Basic Change Seen
Smaller raises may reflect a fundamental change in the job market, suggested Daniel J. B. Mitchell, a professor of management at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Workers are less cushioned from market forces by union contracts or paternalistic employers; union membership is down to 12 percent of private, non-government workers. While small-business payrolls swelled by 15 million during the 80's, Fortune 500 companies shed 2 million jobs. In deciding how much to raise pay last year, Mr. Mitchell said, "employers looked to conditions in the labor market, not to some notion of protecting workers' purchasing power."
But permanent progress on the inflation front ultimately depends on faster productivity growth, almost everyone agrees. "The only way to have strong growth without inflation is to increase productivity faster," said Mr. Hale of Kemper Financial Services. Otherwise, he said, low inflation comes at the cost of stagnating living standards.
There has been an early sign that the productivity trend might be improving. Productivity rose slightly in the recession's first quarter, instead of declining along with output as it usually does at the start of a downturn. At the beginning of the 1981-82 slump, by contrast, productivity plunged at a 5.5 percent annual rate. Since companies laid off workers a lot sooner in the current slump, some economists say, once output picks up in a recovery, productivity gains could be sizable.

FEDERAL RESERVE SAID TO RULE OUT A RATE SHIFT NOW

Author: LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]25 Aug 1990: 1.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427753860?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''It is fairly well accepted that monetary policy, reacting to supply shocks, is not appropriate,'' a Federal Reserve official said. The rise in bond rates reflected in part a concern on Wall Street that the Middle East crisis might cause the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates in an effort to avoid a recession. In the Wall Street view, rather than warding off a recession, such action by the Federal Reserve might fuel inflation. ''People perceive that the Fed might be ready to cave in on interest rates, so the Fed has to maintain them longer than it might otherwise have wanted to do,'' said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in San Francisco. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=FEDERAL+RESERVE+SAID+TO+RULE+OUT+A+RATE+SHIFT+NOW&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-08-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.1&amp;au=LOUIS+UCHITELLE%2C+Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: The Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to make no changes in interest rates until the Middle East crisis quieted down and a clearer picture emerged of its effect on the economy.
The Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to make no changes in interest rates until the Middle East crisis quieted down and a clearer picture emerged of its effect on the economy.
Such a decision suggests that the Federal Reserve, for the time being, remains more concerned about controlling inflation than quickly trying to offset any potential recessionary effect of the Middle East crisis.
Perhaps more important, some officials said that if oil prices, after the crisis, were to settle at, say, $8 a barrel above their pre-crisis levels, or at about $26 a barrel, then the long-term effect on the economy would be minimal - perhaps shaving one-quarter or one-half a percentage point off economic growth.
Growth Rate Is Weak

The Commerce Department reported today that growth in the second quarter was at an anemic annual rate of 1.2 percent, after an also-weak 1.7 percent in the first quarter. That means the gross national product has grown at an annual rate of 1.5 percent so far this year. [Page 31.] The minutes of the closed-door meeting in Washington on Tuesday will not be released for six weeks. But some Federal Reserve officials, here for a conference, indicated in off-the-record conversations that a change in policy when no one knows what might happen in the Middle East could inject new uncertainty into the jittery bond and stock markets.
Annual Two-Day Event

The gathering here in Grand Teton National Park, at a lodge deep in the mountains and woods, is an annual two-day event that brings together Federal Reserve officials and economists from universities and from Wall Street.
The aim is to socialize, to exchange views and to attend five hours of conference sessions each morning, leaving the afternoons free for white-water rafting and hiking. The conference sessions today and Saturday center on controlling inflation in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe; a half-dozen central bank presidents and finance ministers from these countries traveled here to participate.
But the Middle East was clearly a distraction for the Federal Reserve delegation, led by Alan Greenspan, the chairman. There was much coffee-break talk about the latest reports from Wall Street and the Persian Gulf. And some Fed officials suggested that as long as the crisis continued and future oil supplies were uncertain, there was nothing that the Federal Reserve could or should do.
''It is fairly well accepted that monetary policy, reacting to supply shocks, is not appropriate,'' a Federal Reserve official said.
Largely as a result of war fears and oil-supply disruptions, the Dow Jones industrial average has lost nearly 13 percent of its value since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and long-term bond yields have climbed more than half a percentage point.
Regularly Scheduled Meeting

The Tuesday policy meeting in Washington was one that is held every six weeks. The presidents of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks gathered in the capital with Mr. Greenspan and the five Federal Reserve governors to review the state of the economy and decide whether to use their power to lower interest rates, thus stimulating buying and investing, or push up rates and thus reduce the odds of a higher inflation rate.
The Federal Reserve has been slowly pushing down interest rates for nearly a year, out of concern that the economy was weakening. The last drop came on July 13. Although Mr. Greenspan has not commented on the economy since Iraq invaded Kuwait, he maintained until then that while the economy was weak, the odds of a recession were low.
A day after the Washington meeting this week, Mr. Greenspan and two Federal Reserve governors, Wayne D. Angell and Edward W. Kelley Jr., traveled to Jackson Hole and were joined by 6 of the 12 presidents of the Federal Reserve regional banks.
Two Unwelcome Developments

In informal interviews, several Federal Reserve officials said the Iraq crisis had brought on two developments that the central bank had hoped to avoid. One was a fall in the value of the dollar, a potentially inflationary development because it makes imports more expensive. The other was the sharp rise in interest rates for long-term Government bonds to offset any erosion in the value of bonds from future inflation.
The rise in bond rates reflected in part a concern on Wall Street that the Middle East crisis might cause the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates in an effort to avoid a recession. In the Wall Street view, rather than warding off a recession, such action by the Federal Reserve might fuel inflation. ''People perceive that the Fed might be ready to cave in on interest rates, so the Fed has to maintain them longer than it might otherwise have wanted to do,'' said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in San Francisco.
Decisions Not Disclosed

None of the five or six officials who discussed informally the Middle East crisis and the American economy would disclose specific decisions made at the Tuesday meeting. But they said the nation would not know for a month or more what might happen in the Middle East: whether war would break out; whether oil shipments would be further disrupted, or how high oil prices might rise. In such an uncertain situation, the officials said, adjusting interest rate policy would be inappropriate.
But some said that if the price of crude oil was to stabilize at about $26 a barrel - it fell in trading today to about $31 a barrel - that would be a $25 billion to $50 billion ''tax'' on consumption. Economic growth would slow a bit, in this view, but not to the point of a national recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth in the gross national product.

Fed Voted in May Against Lower Rates

Author: AP

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]07 July 1990: 1.32.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427741036?accountid=11752

Abstract: Members agreed that ''current information on business conditions pointed on balance to relatively moderate but sustained economic expansion.'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Fed+Voted+in+May+Against+Lower+Rates&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-07-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.32&amp;au=AP&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their May meeting that inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, minutes of the meeting released today show.
Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their May meeting that inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, minutes of the meeting released today show.
The eight-week-old records were made available amid signs that the policy makers had decided at their most recent gathering on Monday and Tuesday to stand ready to shift their policy and nudge interest rates lower if the economy weakened further.
Unidentified Government officials outside the Fed were quoted in published reports today as saying they believed the directive adopted earlier this week allowed a relaxation of the tight credit policy if additional signs of economic sluggishness emerged.
Analysts were split over whether the June employment report released today by the Labor Department provided such evidence. The unemployment rate slipped to 5.2 percent, from 5.3 percent, but non-farm job growth was a weaker-than-expected 40,000.
In May, members of the Federal Open Market Committee voted by 10 to 1 to maintain the existing credit policy and directed central bank officials to be equally ready to raise or lower rates, depending on developments on inflation and economic growth.
Members agreed that ''current information on business conditions pointed on balance to relatively moderate but sustained economic expansion.'' At the same time, the members ''generally agreed that the prospects for significant reductions in inflation pressures during the quarters immediately ahead were not promising.''
W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and a prominent advocate of a tough anti-inflation policy, voted against the directive. He argued for a tighter credit policy ''to help assure that progress would be made toward a reduced rate of inflation.''
Mr. Hoskins said tighter credit would ''enhance the credibility and effectiveness of monetary policy in countering the persisting strength of inflationary pressures,'' according to the minutes.
Other members, who were not identified, went along with the directive but said that ''the need to contain and ultimately to reduce inflation might well require a firming of policy at some point.''
The Federal Reserve has been fighting inflation with higher interest rates since early 1988. In mid-1989 it began nudging rates down amid concern that the economy might topple into a recession. However, since late December, the Fed has held steady. The Federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans, has hovered around 8.25 percent since then.
The open market committee, which is made up of the seven Fed governors and five of the system's 12 regional bank presidents, meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. Minutes are released about six to eight weeks later, a few days after the next meeting. There was one vacancy among the governors at the time of the May meeting.

Believe It, the Deficit Affects Interest Rates

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]18 Apr 1990: A.24.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427621722?accountid=11752

Abstract: In ''Rostenkowski Plan: A G.O.P. Triumph'' (Op-Ed, March 15), Paul Craig Roberts again rejects sound economic science with his denial that budget deficits affect interest rates -specifically, in denying that balancing the United States budget would reduce interest rates. In rebuttal to this virtually self-evident thesis, he asks: ''Why do West Germany, with its trade surplus, and Britain, with its budget surplus,'' have higher interest rates than the United States?

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Believe+It%2C+the+Deficit+Affects+Interest+Rates%3A+%5BLetter%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-04-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.24&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: To the Editor:
To the Editor:
In ''Rostenkowski Plan: A G.O.P. Triumph'' (Op-Ed, March 15), Paul Craig Roberts again rejects sound economic science with his denial that budget deficits affect interest rates -specifically, in denying that balancing the United States budget would reduce interest rates.
In rebuttal to this virtually self-evident thesis, he asks: ''Why do West Germany, with its trade surplus, and Britain, with its budget surplus,'' have higher interest rates than the United States?
The simple answer is that interest-rate determinants are complex. Real inflation in Britain and feared inflation in inflation-phobic West Germany explain their higher interest rates. Since each national economy carries its own economic configurations, the scientific question is this: What happens, other factors assumed equal, to Britain's, or Germany's or America's, interest rates when budget deficits rise?
Economic logic decrees that, in strict accordance with the law of supply and demand, interest rates rise when budget deficits rise. This virtually axiomatic truth can be demonstrated by linear regression analyses of United States interest rates. Such analyses show definite correlations between mortgage rates, corporate bond rates, Treasury bond rates and Federal budget deficits.
Mr. Roberts tacitly recognizes the critical role of the law of supply and demand when he warns that ''raising taxes could put the economy in the tank.'' Why? Because the consequently reduced income could reduce demand for goods and services.
The same law operates in the money markets. When borrowers compete for a budget-reduced pool of lendable dollars, the price of money - i.e., the interest rate - tends to rise. Significantly, this basic economic truth is rejected only by the Reagan Administration's supply-side ideologues.
C. W. GRIFFIN

Phoenix, April 2, 1990

Business Diary/April 8-13

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]15 Apr 1990: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427624028?accountid=11752

Abstract: The battle between Harold C. Simmons and Lockheed could be one that both sides lose. Full text: LEAD:
COMPANIES

Soda for Ships

Now this is a floating exchange rate. American Pepsi for Soviet ships. In a $3 billion deal - the largest ever between an American company and the Soviet Union - Pepsico will vastly expand its sales there in return for a flood of Stolichnaya vodka and a fleet of freighters and tankers.

COMPANIES

Soda for Ships

Now this is a floating exchange rate. American Pepsi for Soviet ships. In a $3 billion deal - the largest ever between an American company and the Soviet Union - Pepsico will vastly expand its sales there in return for a flood of Stolichnaya vodka and a fleet of freighters and tankers. Since the ruble cannot be converted into Western currencies, companies operating in the Soviet Union have to look for other ways to take out their profits. Pepsico has been a leader in penetrating Soviet markets. Donald M. Kendall, the chairman of the company's executive committee, is ''Mr. U.S.-Soviet trade,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. Now other Western companies will be watching to see how much Pepsi can profit from perestroika.

From Low-Tech to High-Tech

In Japan, even low-technology companies are going high-tech. The Mitsubishi Mining and Cement Company has closed its last coal mine, while the Mitsubishi Metal Corporation has closed its last Japanese mine of any sort. The two announced on Wednesday that they would merge to concentrate on developing sophisticated new materials for industries like computers and electronics. The new company will have annual sales of $5.7 billion. Impressive, but not enough to make the new company more than a supporting actor within the powerful Mitsubishi Group of allied companies. Annual sales for Mitsubishi Electric Corporation alone are more than $19 billion.

Buying Safer Tankers

The American Petroleum Institute questions whether two hulls make an oil tanker less prone to oil spills than one. The issue needs more study, the trade group says. But Conoco Inc. has already reached its own conclusion. On Tuesday, the company, a subsidiary of Du Pont, broke with the industry by announcing an order for two new tankers with the extra hulls. ''We realize that double-hulled tankers are not the total solution, but they do offer an increased margin of protection against oil spills,'' said Constantine S. Nicandros, Conoco's president. ARCO appears to favor the double hulls as well. The extra protection raises the cost of a ship by 5 to 15 percent. A Coast Guard study cited by the Natural Resources Defense Council said that if the Exxon Valdez tanker had a double hull, it would have spilled 15 to 60 percent less oil onto Alaska's shores and seas last year. Congress is considering legislation to make double hulls mandatory.

Lockheed Wins - And Loses

The battle between Harold C. Simmons and Lockheed could be one that both sides lose. The Lockheed Corporation claimed victory on Tuesday in a proxy fight with Mr. Simmons for control of the company and its board. But Mr. Simmons won several shareholder rights measures, one calling for the abolition of a ''poison pill'' defense against a takeover and another for voluntary exemption from Delaware's anti-takeover laws. Mr. Simmons, who owns nearly 10 percent of Lockheed's shares, says he will continue pressing the company to improve shareholder value. But some analysts believe that Lockheed's value is more likely to go down. ''They're looking at a defense budget that's going to decline precipitously over the next three or four years,'' said Michael Rosen, an aeronautics analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''Major programs in the aeronautical systems division are winding down.'' Whatever the company's fate, Mr. Simmons has had enough success in budging an obstinate board to encourage others to wage proxy fights for control of major companies.

M.C.I.'s Growth Spurt

The MCI Communications Corporation plans to pick up another 1.4 percent of the long-distance telephone market - through an expensive acquisition rather than discounted service. MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, announced an agreement on Monday to buy Telecom USA Inc., the fourth largest, for $1.25 billion. Analysts lauded the deal, saying it would combine MCI's residential and big-business customers with Telecom's medium-size accounts in medium-size cities. But the new company, with more than 13 percent of the long-distance market, would still be dwarfed by A.T.& T., with 71 percent. The deal is subject to review by the Justice Department.

Clearing the Air

Men in a shadowy, smoke-filled room are plotting to woo new smokers to replace those who quit or die. They cackle with laughter as one of them says, ''Gentlemen, we're not in this for our health.'' The scene is from a paid television commercial in a new anti-smoking campaign that California launched on Tuesday. The state will spend $26.8 million over the next 18 months, much of it to show tart, pointed advertisements during prime time. Gone are the sober public-service announcements that aired at odd hours to an audience of insomniacs and night watchmen. ''The objective is to change the image that the tobacco industry has created for smokers,'' said Kenneth W. Kizer, director of the California Department of Health Services.

Boeing's Japan Connection

The Boeing Company plans to rely on three Japanese corporations for major components needed to develop a new commercial jet, the 300-seat 767-X. Boeing abandoned earlier plans for giving the companies equity in the project, which raised fears about whether the Japanese would gain enough expertise in aerospace to challenge American manufacturers.

CBS Bets on Sports

CBS Inc. found that betting on sports can pay off. First-quarter earnings, reported on Wednesday, rose 52 percent from the year before to $85.3 million. CBS profited by adding the Super Bowl and two games from the NCAA basketball semifinals to its first-quarter schedule. But its prime-time ratings continue to disappoint. And it paid so much for sporting events later this year that analysts predict weak earnings - unless the World Series involves a couple big-city teams that battle to six or seven games.

ECONOMY

Incompetence or Greed?

Last week's savings and loan horror story: William S. Sessions, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said on Wednesday that the institutions seized by the Government are shot through with fraud. His said his agency will have to spend years hiring and training investigators familiar with accounting, banking, real estate, energy and white-collar shenanigans; sorting through truckloads of documents, and then proving to juries that savings and loan executives lost billions not through incompetence alone, but also through thievery. The incompetence argument is strong, judging from the billions these units sank into ''junk bonds'' and even junkier real estate. The horror story from the week before, remember, was the General Accounting Office's estimate that the bailout would cost $325 billion to $500 billion..

More Bond Defaults

The darkest forecasts of corporate bond defaults soon come to seem far too optimistic. The Bond Investors Association predicted in January that defaults would rise to a record $15 billion this year from $11.9 billion in 1989. But bond issues totaling $5.7 billion defaulted in the first quarter alone, the association reported. Leave out the $3.5 billion Campeau default, and the total would still be 64 percent ahead of last year. Richard Lehmann, the association's president, lists Western Union, Southland and Ames Department Stores among the companies most likely to default.

Explaining the Drop in Prices

Cheaper clothing, vegetables and gasoline helped drive wholesale prices down two-tenths of 1 percent in March. Economists -surprised by Friday's report of the first drop in seven months - were all but consulting the Old Farmer's Almanac for explanations. A warm winter, said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia State University Economic Forecasting Center, meant ''tomatoes came on line more quickly than expected.'' The core rate of producer price inflation, excluding food and energy, rose three-tenths of 1 percent.

INTERNATIONAL

Investing in Japan Inc.

The Japanese keep spending on their corporations, if not on themselves. Last year, they invested $750 billion, about 24 percent of gross national product, in plants, equipment, and research and development. The United States spent $500 billion, or 10 percent of gross national product. Analysts say Japanese companies have enough cash to sustain investment despite higher interest rates and a falling stock market. American negotiators urge the Japanese to consume more. The response, from a recent book co-written by Akio Morita, the Sony chairman: ''We are focusing on business 10 years in advance, while you seem to be concerned only with profits 10 minutes from now. At that rate, you may well never be able to compete with us.''

Soviets Short on Cash

Can the Soviet Union pay for its grain? Shippers are complaining of late Soviet payments, which might amount to almost a half-billion dollars. Some grain dealers have stopped selling there on credit. Soviet payment problems extend to other areas; the Soviet Union reportedly defaulted on late charges for tankers waiting in the Black Sea to load Soviet oil. But Soviet oil exports appear to be holding up even if production and domestic consumption are off. Some economists say the trouble is less a lack of hard currency than bureaucratic confusion. But Thane Gustafson, a Soviet specialist for Cambridge Energy Research Associates, wonders whether the country is dealing with ''a succession of micro-crises, or the beginning of a macro-crisis.''

Americans in Brazil

American companies face losses from Brazil's economic turmoil. Johnson & Johnson announced a $125 million write-off on Wednesday; one reason is Brazil's radical new program to fight inflation, which its Congress approved on Wednesday. Measures imposed by President Fernando Collor de Mello have already pitched Brazil into a recession.

Rate Moves: No Firm Global Link

Author: UCHITELLE, LOUIS

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Mar 1990: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427591559?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Interest rates in one ocean bay are affected by rates in another bay,'' said Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science. ''But they don't mingle perfectly. There is considerable room for differences.'' There is such a worldwide pool of savings and it does move across borders, but not as easily as theory suggests and not in such single-minded response to the highest bidder, economists say. ''Rates can change in one country or another without any great demand for money.'' ''Right now, they expect the inflation rate to rise more in Japan and Germany than in the United States,'' said Nicholas Sargen, chief of bond research at Salomon Brothers.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Rate+Moves%3A+No+Firm+Global+Link%3A+%5BNews+Analysis%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-03-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=UCHITELLE%2C+LOUIS&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: When interest rates go up in one major industrial country, must they also do so in others? The recent rise of West German, Japanese and American rates, in tandem, has given that impression. But plenty of room still exists for the United States to control its own interest rates, even going against the trend in other countries.
When interest rates go up in one major industrial country, must they also do so in others? The recent rise of West German, Japanese and American rates, in tandem, has given that impression. But plenty of room still exists for the United States to control its own interest rates, even going against the trend in other countries.
The United States, in fact, has been quietly going against the global grain for over a week. While people buying German and Japanese bonds have insisted upon somewhat higher interest rates in return for their money, those buying American securities have settled for rates that have remained essentially unchanged since late February.
''Interest rates in one ocean bay are affected by rates in another bay,'' said Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science. ''But they don't mingle perfectly. There is considerable room for differences.''
The differences stem from such distinctly national phenomena as whether investors consider a particular country a safe place to put their money and whether a nation's inflation rate is rising or falling.
These differences, however, did not show themselves in January, when German and Japanese interest rates suddenly rose and American rates went up with them. The phenomenon seemed to confirm the often-cited ''pool of money'' thesis, which holds that a worldwide pool of savings exists, one that moves easily across borders, seeking the highest rate of return, as measured by interest rates. The rates are offered to attract money for such things as financing the American budget deficit or the rebuilding of East Germany.
There is such a worldwide pool of savings and it does move across borders, but not as easily as theory suggests and not in such single-minded response to the highest bidder, economists say. The problem is that the demand for loans is rarely as great as the worldwide supply of savings, so rates do not have to rise to compete for funds. ''Using the concept of funds flowing across borders to explain interest rate movements is a trap,'' said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant. ''Rates can change in one country or another without any great demand for money.''
Behind the Divergence

As if to demonstrate the point, American, German and Japanese rates have begun to decouple, marching once again largely to their own tunes. Economists cite two major reasons for the divergence.
One is safety or, more specifically, whether investors feel sure that money invested in one country's securities will not suddenly disappear or suffer an accident. Right now, concern is growing about the safety of money in Japan and Germany. Japanese stock prices have plunged in recent weeks, suggesting that the Tokyo stock exchange might be flirting with a crash. And investors are nervous about the economies in Eastern Europe.
In these uncertain situations, American securities are often thought of as a safe place to park money, even though Japanese and German interest rates keep rising, as they have in recent days to lure the money to Tokyo and Europe.
Inflation Concerns

The second reason why interest rates go in different directions is the most important, involving a distinctly national phenomenon that money brokers everywhere refer to as their ''expectations'' about inflation. ''Right now, they expect the inflation rate to rise more in Japan and Germany than in the United States,'' said Nicholas Sargen, chief of bond research at Salomon Brothers.
The mechanics are plain enough. When inflation seems to threaten in Germany, for example, an investor thinking of buying German bonds reasons this way: Why purchase a bond that yields 9 percent when inflation in that country might rise to an annual rate of, say, 6 percent or 7 percent, diluting most of the income's purchasing power, not only in Germany but probably elsewhere as well. Better to buy an American bond that pays 8.5 percent interest and count on the American inflation rate of 4.5 percent to remain unchanged.
If the expectation about the American inflation rate turns out to be correct, then only about half the purchasing power of the income from the Treasury note would be eaten up. The ''real'' return would be 4 percent (the 8.5 percent yield minus the 4.5 percent loss to inflation) while the real return on the German bond would be only 2 or 3 percent.
Seeking the 'Real' Return

Just this sort of thinking is now in evidence. Interest rates on German and Japanese 10-year bonds have risen by one-quarter to one-half a percentage point since Feb. 22, reaching 7.12 percent yesterday in Japan and 8.97 percent in Germany. But the rate on 10-year United States Treasury notes has held steady at just above or just below 8.5 percent, closing yesterday at 8.63 percent. Americans, and also foreign investors, have gone for the higher ''real'' return on American securities, and as they bought the dollars needed to purchase them, the dollar rose in value.
Never mind that actual inflation is less of a problem in West Germany and Japan today than it is in the United States. The annual inflation rate in the United States is now 4.5 percent, compared with rates in Germany and Japan of less than 3 percent. But the expectation is that inflation will get worse in Japan because of its booming economy and in West Germany because of the financial strain in rebuilding East Germany.
A third factor that makes interest rate movements a national rather than global phenomenon is the power of the major central banks to manipulate interest rates on short-term securities. Changes in these rates usually influence long-term rates, independently of international forces.
'Large Exaggeration'

Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, weighed in on this point in Congressional testimony last week. He said that while there is influence from rising rates in Germany and Japan, ''the presumption that it ties our hands and makes our monetary policy ineffective is a very large exaggeration.''
If all this is true, why then did American, German and Japanese rates rise in unison from early January through mid-February? Some economists, among them A. John Steigmann, research director at the Ford Motor Company, call what happened ''largely a coincidence.'' Three factors came together in December to create the global rise in rates.
One was the view that the American economy had finally gotten as weak as it was going to get and would rebound in the new year, pulling up the American inflation rate as the demand for goods intensified. Suddenly, a 7.7 percent yield on the 10-year Treasury note did not seem so appetizing, and it rose to offset the expected erosion from a higher inflation rate, reaching 8.66 percent last month before expectations changed again. Fresh data about the American economy have convinced the bond market, for the moment, that last year's 4.5 percent inflation rate might continue unchanged, after all, into 1990.
Simultaneously in December, rates rose in Japan because a new chief of the Bank of Japan called attention to the potential for a higher inflation rate in that country, and tried to head it off by pushing up Japanese interest rates. That was a classic tactic of central banks. Higher rates discourage spending financed with loans, thus reducing the demand for goods.
Also in December, expectations changed in West Germany. The Berlin wall was breached and suddenly there was talk of extending the West German currency to East Germany, giving 15 million East Germans, in one fell swoop, the wherewithal to buy West German goods. That is potentially inflationary.
What's more, the expectation arose that West Germany would need higher interest rates to attract billions of dollars from the world's pool of savings to finance the rebuilding of East Germany. ''Markets run in anticipation of real events that might never materialize,'' said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economic consultant.

CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN JANUARY BY A SHARP 1.1%

Author: ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Feb 1990: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427532509?accountid=11752

Abstract: Yet the increase in the underlying rate also reflected special factors, involving automobile and tobacco prices, and analysts said they doubted that any worrisome surge in inflation is under way. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CONSUMER+PRICES+ROSE+IN+JANUARY+BY+A+SHARP+1.1%25&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-02-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=ROBERT+D.+HERSHEY+Jr.%2C+Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Heavily affected by harsh early-winter weather, consumer prices soared 1.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly advance in more than seven years, the Labor Department reported today.
Heavily affected by harsh early-winter weather, consumer prices soared 1.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly advance in more than seven years, the Labor Department reported today.
The increase in the Consumer Price Index was at the upper edge of the range of expectations, and analysts said it appeared to extinguish any remaining chance that the Federal Reserve Board would seek further cuts in interest rates anytime soon.
Until recently the widespread assumption among analysts was that the Federal Reserve was inclined to nudge rates down to counter weakness in the economy. But the latest economic reports suggest that the risk of recession has abated. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told Congress on Tuesday that 1990 is likely to be a year of moderate expansion.
Banks Feeling Rate Pressure

Pressure is even building in the banking system to reverse the half-point cut in the prime lending rate, to 10 percent, made in early January. Since then some rates that banks pay to attract short-term funds, like those on certificates of deposits, have climbed significantly. At the same time, however, the overnight loan rate, which is closely controlled by the Federal Reserve, has remained steady at about 8.25 percent.
Japan and West Germany are raising their interest rates to combat the threat of inflation, and these increases in turn tend to pull up rates here. Further easing of credit by the Federal Reserve, analysts agree, could cause an unwanted drop in the dollar if interest rates in the United States become relatively unattractive to investors.
Core Inflation Also Jumps

Without the categories of energy and food, which were influenced the most by supply shortages resulting from the record cold in late December, the January increase was six-tenths of 1 percent. This is the largest increase in this important gauge, which economists call the underlying, or core, inflation rate, since January 1984.
Yet the increase in the underlying rate also reflected special factors, involving automobile and tobacco prices, and analysts said they doubted that any worrisome surge in inflation is under way. ''We are starting to see it beginning to nose up a little bit, but it's not anything too disturbing,'' said John D. Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. He said it was clear that the outlook for the core rate is not anything like the January level.
Traders said the price jump contributed to a decline in both stock and bond prices as the two markets opened. But the Dow Jones industrial average managed to regain some of its losses and finish the session off 13.29 points, to 2,583.56. And the Treasury's benchmark long bond, which had plummeted in price on Tuesday, managed a gain on the day.
At the White House, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, called today's report ''disappointing news,'' but in accord with the views of most private-sector economists, he said inflation would probably not continue at such a rate.
''We are hopeful that this is a bulge that will be temporary in nature,'' he said. ''But inflation requires eternal vigilance.''
In his Congressional testimony on Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan said that he expected inflation to remain steady in 1990 at 4 to 4.5 percent but that an inflation rate in that neighborhood was too high and the Fed was determined to bring it down.
Prices for heating oil and other products that surged in January have already receded, analysts said.
Prices in the New York metropolitan area, one of five city tabulations made on a monthly basis, jumped 1.4 percent in January, with an increase in transit fares accounting for a bit more than 10 percent of the advance.
Prices in Urban Areas

Prices climbed 1.3 percent in Chicago, 1.1 percent in Los Angeles, 1 percent in Philadelphia and nine-tenths of 1 percent in San Francisco.
The rise of 1.1 percent in the overall Consumer Price Index - which covers all urban consumers, or about 80 percent of the population - was the biggest since June 1982 and followed a 1.8 percent jump reported earlier this month in January's Producer Price Index for Finished Goods.
The Labor Department said energy and food accounted for more than 60 percent of the increase as fuel oil soared 26.3 percent and fruits and vegetables jumped 10.2 percent, both records. Gasoline climbed 7.7 percent after falling in November and December. The price of tomatoes rocketed 75.6 percent, bringing the retail price to more than $1 each in some stores.
Many consumers no doubt refused to pay such a price and bought something else instead, but this is not captured by the price index because it measures a fixed market basket of goods and services. The Consumer Price Index makes no allowance for consumers shifting buying habits, such as switching from steak to hamburger.
Transportation Costs

Among the main statistical categories, transportation showed the biggest increase, 2.1 percent, with motor fuels accounting for nearly 75 percent of it. Public transportation rose 1.9 percent because of increases in airline fares and intracity charges, like the rise in New York City transit prices, which included increases in taxi and commuter railroad fares and a subway and bus fare jump from $1 to $1.15. The transportation category rose three-tenths of a percent in December.
Somewhat surprising to some analysts was another rise, six-tenths of 1 percent, in prices of new cars. Analysts had expected a drop, largely because auto makers had resumed incentive programs, but a Labor Department official explained that the 1990 models were introduced more slowly than usual and thus their higher prices are still being incorporated into the figures.
Food and beverage prices climbed 1.8 percent, with grocery-store foods up 2.9 percent, the biggest increase since a 7.1 percent surge in August 1973. About two-thirds of the advance was in fruits and vegetables, but dairy products were up 2.4 percent and the category that includes meats, poultry, fish and eggs were up 1.9 percent. Egg prices themselves leapt another 9.1 percent. In December, the food and beverage category rose four-tenths of a percent.
Housing, which accounts for 42 percent of the consumer price index, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after three straight months with advances of four-tenths of 1 percent. Nearly half the rise reflected fuel and other utilities. Prices of hotel and motel rooms rose 2.9 percent.
Other Categories

Apparel prices were unchanged last month, compared with a decline of three-tenths of a percent in December, and medical care and other goods and services rose by the same amounts as in December, six-tenths and eight-tenths of 1 percent, respectively.
Other goods include tobacco, which posted a 1.3 percent increase that analysts had not expected in light of a big jump in December. An official said a tobacco price increase at the end of the year was partially reflected in the January figures because of the way data are collected and that state and local tax increases would take effect at the beginning of a year.
The entertainment category rose six-tenths of 1 percent in January with increases for reading materials, club memberships and tickets to cultural, sporting and entertainment events accounting for the bulk of the advance. This category rose four-tenths of a percent in December.
Before rounding, the consumer price index for all urban consumers rose 1.1084719 last month, to 127.4 percent of its 1982-1984 base. This means that a group of goods and services that then cost $10 now costs $12.74. Without seasonal adjustment, the index rose 1 percent last month.
A second index, which covers urban wage earners and clerical workers, or 32 percent of the population, also rose 1.1 percent when seasonally adjusted and 1 percent without such adjustment.
