Why the Fed Is Largely Uncriticized

Author: DAVID E. ROSE NBAUM, Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]22 Jan 1990: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427517027?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''I enjoy the absence of Fed-bashing,'' one governor said a few days before the President spoke. But he added, perhaps prophetically, ''I don't think it's a long-term phenomenon.'' In 1980, a repeated theme of President Jimmy Carter's re-election campaign was his attacks on the Federal Reserve for its ''ill-advised'' policy of raising interest rates to retard inflation. Mr. Carter's Treasury Secretary, G. William Miller, himself a former Fed chairman, complained that the central bank was ''not communicating'' sufficiently with the Administration. ''I admire [Alan Greenspan],'' he continued. ''That doesn't mean we don't have our differences; we do. The Fed has a special view about the containment of inflation, and at the same time it is not unmindful of the necessity for growth. We have a special feeling about growth, but we have a very strong eye on inflation. I would say the differences are between the 40-yard lines.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Why+the+Fed+Is+Largely+Uncriticized&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1990-01-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=DAVID+E.+ROSENBAUM%2C+Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: President Bush and his spokesman last week broke his Administration's policy of keeping quiet about the policies of the Federal Reserve.
President Bush and his spokesman last week broke his Administration's policy of keeping quiet about the policies of the Federal Reserve.
But the statements of the President and his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, about the need for lower interest rates were mild compared to the sharp attacks on the Fed by officials in previous administrations when the economy was flagging in an election year.
At the week's end, senior Administration officials said the Bush and Fitzwater remarks were not meant as a direct challenge to the central bank but as a reminder that the Bush Administration wants interest rates as low as is possible, consistent with restraining inflation.
Rates Remain High

Although the Fed has allowed interest rates to fall somewhat in the last seven months, they remain abnormally high in relation to the rate of inflation.
Until last week, the central bank had received unusually little criticism from the White House and Congress as an election year begins, given the weakness of the economy and the fact that interest rates are unusually high by historical standards. Three-month Treasury bills are paying about 7.75 percent and 30-year Treasury bonds are around 8.25 percent, while the inflation rate has held steady for years at about 4.5 percent.
The reluctance of politicians to take on the Fed is in large part a result of the high regard they have for Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and of their hope that Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues can perform the extraordinarily delicate feat of slowing the economy enough to avert high inflation without causing a recession.
No Political Pressure

The relative absence of criticism also reflects the acknowledgement in the White House and Congress that elected officials have let the budget deficit get out of hand and, for better or worse, have surrendered economic policy to the central bank.
Even legislators from states and districts that for all intents and purposes are in a recession say they are under no pressure from constituents or interest groups to take on the Fed.
The view of the Federal Reserve governors and top staff members is that a lack of political arm-twisting gives them freedom to fine-tune the economy that they would not otherwise enjoy.
But, gun-shy from past experience, they fear the statements by Mr. Bush and Mr. Fitzwater are the first signs that the truce flags are coming down.
''I enjoy the absence of Fed-bashing,'' one governor said a few days before the President spoke. But he added, perhaps prophetically, ''I don't think it's a long-term phenomenon.''
In his first public statement on the matter in almost a year, Mr. Bush told the National Association of Homebuilders in Atlanta on Friday that ''low and stable interest rates'' were essential to a growing economy. He did not specifically mention the Federal Reserve.
Fitzwater's Remarks

The day before, Mr. Fitzwater said the Administration hoped that new statistics showing a steady inflation rate and a faltering housing industry would persuade the Fed to loosen credit.
Some politicians suggested that Mr. Fitzwater's remarks laid the groundwork for the Administration to shift blame to the Fed if the economy slides into a recession. But top Administration officials disputed that view. One observed that Mr. Greenspan resented political pressure and would be less likely to loosen the reins on credit if the Administration kept speaking out.
In any case, the mood now is quite different from that in 1980 and 1982, the last times the economy was weak in an election year.
In 1980, a repeated theme of President Jimmy Carter's re-election campaign was his attacks on the Federal Reserve for its ''ill-advised'' policy of raising interest rates to retard inflation. Mr. Carter's Treasury Secretary, G. William Miller, himself a former Fed chairman, complained that the central bank was ''not communicating'' sufficiently with the Administration.
Reagan's Complaint

Similarly, in early 1982, President Ronald Reagan blamed the Fed for a monetary policy that caused capital investment to decline. Speaking of interest rates as the midterm election drew near, he told an audience, ''If that string hadn't been pulled for so long and so hard, we might not have had the depth of the recession that we've had.''
Reagan Administration officials like Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, were even harsher in their criticism, and many lawmakers campaigned on platforms of seeking lower interest rates.
By contrast, President Bush and his top economic policy makers agreed early in the Administration not to attack the Fed in public, a senior official said. They have generally stuck to that agreement, even though most economists believe the economy is growing little, if at all.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady explained the reasoning behind not challenging the Fed. ''People in the United States and around the world generate a higher level of confidence, which leads to economic growth, if they don't feel that there's a big war going on between the economic authorities inside the United States,'' he said.
'Inflation Genie'

Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said, ''The Administration realizes that while the goal is to maximize growth, letting the inflation genie out of the bottle is very costly later on.''
Once or twice before last week, the Administration's vow was broken. In his first week in office, President Bush told an interviewer, ''I don't want to see us move so strongly against fear of inflation that we impede growth.''
Even that mild comment raised eyebrows in the markets. ''There was a suspicion that this Administration, dominated by Texans and with all the Texas real estate and energy problems, would be less anti-inflation than Reagan,'' said Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. ''People were waiting for signs that they would turn on the printing press.''
Then in August, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, pointedly criticized the Fed for keeping credit too tight. ''If we do have a recession,'' he said, ''I think it will be because they erred on the side of caution.''
Darman Pulls Back

That caused a stir for a few days. Mr. Darman said later he had not intended to use such strong words. He has not spoken out publicly on the subject since.
Asked in an interview today on the ABC News program, ''This Week,'' what policies the Fed should be following, Mr. Darman replied, ''I would like to stay out of that debate in the theory that they will do something wiser if I stay out of the swirl.''
This does not mean the Bush Administration and the Fed have not at times been at odds. Early last year, they disagreed over how to deal with the third world debt and the problems of the savings industry. Over the summer, one official said, Administration economists tried hard to convince Mr. Greenspan that signs of inflation were largely the result of one-time increases in oil and food prices and not a general overheating of the economy.
Then, in October, the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the central bank, decided not to lower interest rates immediately after the meeting of finance ministers of the seven leading industrial countries because Fed officials did not want to be perceived as succumbing to Administration pressure to drive down the value of the dollar.
Value of Socializing

Those differences were smoothed over in private. Mr. Greenspan knew many officials in the Administration from when they worked together for President Gerald R. Ford, and they continue to socialize together.
Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Brady meet nearly every week for breakfast, often joined by other officials. Mr. Boskin said staff relations between Administration economists and those at the Fed were smooth and cooperative.
''I do express my views to the chairman,'' Mr. Brady said. ''I do it forcefully and privately, and I intend to keep it that way.''
''I admire Alan Greenspan,'' he continued. ''That doesn't mean we don't have our differences; we do. The Fed has a special view about the containment of inflation, and at the same time it is not unmindful of the necessity for growth. We have a special feeling about growth, but we have a very strong eye on inflation. I would say the differences are between the 40-yard lines.''
Greenspan Is Careful

For his part, Mr. Greenspan has been careful not to criticize President Bush's policies in public, although, according to colleagues, he believes strong measures including tax increases are needed to lower the budget deficit.
In Congress, where lawmakers with strong interests in farming, small business and construction railed in years past against high interest rates, Mr. Greenspan is treated with respect bordering on reverence.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee, has led the drive to make Federal Reserve procedures more accountable. But he precedes every discussion with strong praise of Mr. Greenspan and the current Fed policy.
And the Democrats who control Congress say they prefer to blame President Bush for the economic slowdown. They fear that too much talk about the Fed's role would give the President an escape hatch.
A Positive Influence

Many lawmakers also concede that Mr. Greenspan may be the only official in Washington with a positive influence on the economy, and they are grateful that times are not worse.
''Can you imagine, if it was the President or Congress who had control of monetary policy?'' asked Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who sits on the Banking and Budget Committees. ''Look at how Congress and the President have handled the budget deficit.''

O.E.C.D. Opposes Unilateral Trade Steps

Author: STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]02 June 1989: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427257957?accountid=11752

Abstract: In the polite language of diplomacy, the ministers' final communique said, without mentioning the United States specifically, that the governments ''reject the tendency toward unilateralism'' and ''will avoid any discriminatory or autonomous actions which undermine'' the ''integrity of the multilateral trading system.'' Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=O.E.C.D.+Opposes+Unilateral+Trade+Steps&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-06-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=STEVEN+GREENHOUSE%2C+Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: A week after the United States named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, the world's industrial nations said today that they rejected unilateral measures that undermine the world trade system.
A week after the United States named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, the world's industrial nations said today that they rejected unilateral measures that undermine the world trade system.
The United States joined in the statement, issued by finance and foreign ministry officials from 24 industrial nations at the end of the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
In the polite language of diplomacy, the ministers' final communique said, without mentioning the United States specifically, that the governments ''reject the tendency toward unilateralism'' and ''will avoid any discriminatory or autonomous actions which undermine'' the ''integrity of the multilateral trading system.''
Last week Washington, exercising Section 301 of the trade act, cited Japan, Brazil and India as unfair traders, which subjects them to special negotiations and possible penalties unless they lower several import barriers.
At the two-day meeting, Washington had lobbied for watered-down language on unilateral actions, while Japan wanted to make sure the issue was hit hard. Both said they were satisfied with the final wording.
At a news conference today, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said that Washington's use of Section 301 was consistent with the spirit of the O.E.C.D. ministers' statement. She argued that Washington was using the legislation as a tool to open up the multilateral trade system, not undermine it.
''If we were a smaller nation we could sit by perhaps and watch,'' she said. ''But we are the largest nation and we have historically taken a leadership role'' to knock down trade barriers.
Many officials at the annual ministerial meeting of the O.E.C.D. said they hoped their condemnation of unilateral trade actions might persuade Washington not to retaliate single-handedly against the countries it has branded as unfair traders.
Japan devoted most of its energy at the two-day meeting to rallying other nations to join it in criticizing the American action. ''I have no doubt that they have the message,'' said John Crosbie, Canada's Trade Minister, referring to the United States. ''But they also have the Congress.'' The O.E.C.D. is a Paris-based organization that industrial democracies formed in 1960 to foster economic growth and cooperation.
In their communique today, the countries also pledged to resist inflationary pressures and to strengthen efforts to reduce trade imbalances.
But the meeting was marked by disagreements over steps to fight inflation, whether interest rates should be raised or lowered and how aggressive the United States should be in cutting its budget deficit. With the dollar soaring to levels that most finance officials here said was too high, some in attendance suggested that international cooperation to spur noninflationary growth and stabilize exchange rates was proving unsuccessful.
But United States Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said he thought the efforts were succeeding. ''In my opinion, the process is working,'' he said. ''We will always have moments in time when the process is creaky.''
The ministers called for stepped-up efforts to cut the American trade deficit and the trade surpluses of Japan and West Germany.
The ministers said the United States needed ''continued moderation of domestic demand and further decrease of public deficits'' to contain inflationary pressures and cut the trade deficit.
The communique urged Japan to adopt measures aimed at increasing consumption and imports. The steps would include reforming its stringent land policies, opening up its distribution system and further liberalization of its financial sector.
As for the third world debt crisis, the communique suggested that commercial banks and multilateral organizations act to reduce the debt burden of many African and Latin American nations.
''The ministers stressed that lower interest rates and sustained economic growth might mean more help to developing countries than any debt strategies we have seen,'' said John Sigurdsson, Iceland's Minister of Industry and chairman of the ministers' meeting.
For the first time, the O.E.C.D. ministers devoted much of their communique to an appeal for more cooperation to protect the environment.

LIMA JOURNAL; Starting Over, the Ex-Peruvian Way

Author: ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]21 Jan 1989: 1.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/427036035?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Every time there is a round of sharp price increases, we get a wave of new visa requests,'' a Latin American diplomat said. ''Most people say they're going on vacation because they know it's hard to get immigrant visas, but they all want to leave here for good.'' #500,000 in 3 U.S. States With an estimated half million Peruvians already living in Florida, New York and California, the United States is the preferred destination. Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=LIMA+JOURNAL%3B+Starting+Over%2C+the+Ex-Peruvian+Way&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1989-01-21&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.4&amp;au=ALAN+RIDING%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: In a crowded airport lounge in full view of tearful emigrants bidding farewell to friends and relatives, the message written in black letters on a white marble wall looked singularly out of place.
In a crowded airport lounge in full view of tearful emigrants bidding farewell to friends and relatives, the message written in black letters on a white marble wall looked singularly out of place.
''I am proud to be Peruvian,'' it said. But with well over 100,000 Peruvians expected to flee this country's acute economic crisis this year and many more dreaming of doing so, pride in Peru seems to be in desperately short supply here today.
''You can put me on the list of those leaving,'' said Esteban Garcia, a 24-year-old book salesman who now drives a taxi. ''What has my country given me? What can it give me? If I stay, all I'm doing is making the rich richer.''
With Peruvians battered into pessimism by falling living standards, food shortages, blackouts, transportation strikes and growing terrorism, the idea of seeking a better life abroad has therefore become almost a fad here in recent months. 'I'm Going to Miami'
''I handed in my passport this morning,'' said a young man who declined to give his name. ''My father is a general, and the army is going to ask for a United States visa for me. In any event, I'm going to Miami. I have relatives who run a restaurant there.''
Government statistics show that 38,000 people emigrated in 1986, 66,000 in 1987 and about 120,000 last year. ''If this trend continues, one million of Peru's 20 million inhabitants will have left by 1992,'' Enrique Bernales, a leftist Senator, said.
Still more alarming for a backward country, many of the migrants are professionals, technicians or skilled workers. ''Can we criticize them?'' Senator Bernales asked. ''In a way, the country is pushing them out because they can't find jobs, salaries are low and they see no future for themselves here.''
For Latin America as a whole, this kind of exodus is also new. Excluding Cuban exiles, the vast majority of Latin migrants have traditionally been poor. But the region's economic crisis in the 1980's has brought a new wave of white-collar migrants from Mexico, Brazil and Argentina as well as Peru.
Peru's crisis, though, is the most dramatic. While its economy has been struggling since 1983, it went into a tailspin last year when the gross domestic product shrank by 9 percent, inflation exceeded 1,700 percent and average real wages fell by more than half. The prospects for 1989 are even bleaker.
''Every time there is a round of sharp price increases, we get a wave of new visa requests,'' a Latin American diplomat said. ''Most people say they're going on vacation because they know it's hard to get immigrant visas, but they all want to leave here for good.'' #500,000 in 3 U.S. States With an estimated half million Peruvians already living in Florida, New York and California, the United States is the preferred destination. And since even tourist visas to the United States are increasingly hard to come by, some travel agencies are now charging $2,500 to smuggle in migrants through Mexico.
But there is also a steady flow of Peruvians moving to Chile, Paraguay and Venezuela. ''I don't want to go to the United States because Latinos are treated as second-class citizens there,'' said an engineering student who gave his name only as Carlos. ''I won't feel so foreign in a Latin country.''
At the Migration Department, prospective migrants start lining up well before midnight to beat the crowds scrambling to pay $55 to obtain a passport every morning. ''Once I have my passport, I'll visit the American, Australian and Canadian Embassies,'' a 34-year-old agronomist said. ''I'm still young enough to start a new life.''
Significantly, while there is anxiety about an escalating war between the armed forces and Maoist guerrillas of the Shining Path, this conflict is still centered in the Andean highlands, and almost without exception migrants-to-be give economic reasons for their decision to leave.
Tens of thousands of peasants have fled to Lima's shantytowns to escape political violence over the past eight years but, in contrast to poor Mexicans and Central Americans who can travel overland to the United States, the cost of leaving here has limited the option of emigrating to Peru's middle classes. 'It Costs a Lot'
''Even for them, it is not easy,'' a foreign diplomat said. ''It costs a lot to settle a family in another country, and many people have to sell their homes and cars and even borrow to raise the money necessary. But they go anyway. It's dramatic. You'll have respectable senoras willing to cross the desert to get into the United States.''
Many of Peru's wealthy minority, on the other hand, already have savings and own property in the United States and Western Europe. ''People have so much money abroad that they could pack up and leave in a couple of days if the situation got out of hand,'' a prominent industrialist said.
For the wealthy and, for different reasons, for many leftists, political uncertainty rather than economic hardship is in fact the main reason for planning an escape route abroad. While the wealthy fear the steady advance of Shining Path revolutionaries, leftists are alarmed by growing speculation about a rightist coup.
''You'd better leave me your address,'' a left-leaning academic told a foreign visitor. ''You never know when I'll come knocking on your door. I know that if there's a coup, there's going to be a flood of political exiles. There'll be massive repression of the left.''
But while economic problems have prompted many Peruvians to lose faith in their country, the phenomenon is now feeding on itself. ''People pass on rumors as fact and cause panic,'' said Reynaldo Gubbins, president of the Peruvian Confederation of Industries. ''They hear of friends and relatives leaving the country and they wonder why they're staying. At times, I think we have a strong self-destructive streak in us.''

LARGE BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE TO 9% ON INFLATION FEAR

Author: PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]12 May 1988: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426847923?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''They're pleased with the level of growth,'' said Elliott Platt, economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, ''and their concern has shifted to inflation.'' ''We have no objection to what they're trying to do,'' Beryl W. Sprinkel, the President's chief economic adviser, said today. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, an informal adviser to the Presidential campaign of Vice President Bush, expressed similar views Tuesday. Mr. Sprinkel, for one, says the Federal Reserve is right to raise rates to bring the money supply into line, but he says the market's assumptions about inflation and low unemployment will be soon be disproved. ''I don't believe for a moment that at these levels of employment, inflation has to take off,'' he said.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=LARGE+BANKS+RAISE+PRIME+RATE+TO+9%25+ON+INFLATION+FEAR&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-05-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=PETER+T.+KILBORN%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Many of the nation's major banks raised their important prime lending rate today, a decision prompted by growing fears at the Federal Reserve Board and on Wall Street that inflation is now a greater threat than recession.
Many of the nation's major banks raised their important prime lending rate today, a decision prompted by growing fears at the Federal Reserve Board and on Wall Street that inflation is now a greater threat than recession.
The banks, including Citibank, Chase Manhattan and Chemical in New York, lifted the prime rate half a percentage point, to 9 percent. That was its level in mid-October, just before the stock market collapse, when the economy looked as robust as it does now.
Banks use the prime rate as a base for all their loans to small and medium-size businesses and to consumers, so the increase in the prime means an immediate rise in many interest rates. A Domino Effect Looms
For consumers the higher prime rate, which generally lags behind the movements of other interest rates, signals increasing costs for mortgages, home equity loans, auto loans and other loans. Last Friday the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said rates on fixed-rate mortgages moved up slightly in April, ending the decline that began after the October crash.
The increase in the prime rate sent tremors through the already jittery stock market, contributing to a substantial drop of 37.80 points, or 1.9 percent, in the Dow Jones industrial average. It closed at 1,965.85. [ Page D1. ] In the credit markets, prices dipped slightly, but the rate increase was largely ignored. The move came as no surprise because of the recent rise in short-term rates. [ Page D16. ] The dollar's value was bolstered in currency trading by the higher interest rates. But there was conjecture that other nations might raise their interest rates, which could weaken the dollar.
Many economists said the increase in the prime rate confirmed a tentative but important shift in the policy of the Federal Reserve Board, from trying to help the economy avoid a recession to trying to prevent a surge in inflation.
They pointed out that in February the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the risks of inflation and a recession were about even. But recent statements by Mr. Greenspan and his fellow governors, they said, indicate that the risk of inflation now dwarfs the likelihood of a slowdown.
On Monday, for example, one of the governors, Martha R. Seger, said she was readjusting her forecast for the economy in view of the signs of faster growth. At another point, she said the Federal Reserve would not let inflation become a problem.
''They're pleased with the level of growth,'' said Elliott Platt, economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, ''and their concern has shifted to inflation.''
The prime rate increase is likely to spread throughout the banking industry. It was foreordained by a recent rise in the Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, from a little below 7 percent to about 7 1/8 percent today. Increases in this rate, which the Federal Reserve controls, often force other rates to climb.
Economists see the Federal Reserve's moves more as preventative steps against a surge of inflation than as attempts to arrest the relatively low current inflation. And they say the rate increases could be reversed in a month if Government reports show consumer prices and other gauges of inflation to be stabilizing.
Most of these economists also doubt that the Federal Reserve will take a second step in an aggressive assault on inflation by raising the discount interest rate, , although that is a major concern in the financial markets. The discount rate, which is what the central bank charges on loans it makes to financial institutions, has been 6 percent since last September. Discouraging Borrowing
Higher interest rates invariably slow the economy by discouraging people from borrowing. This slowing helps relieve the pressure from workers and businesses seeking the wage and price increases that speed up the rate of inflation. The interest increases resulting from Federal Reserve policy have been so small, however, that they have aroused little concern in the Reagan Administration.
Some Administration officials seem to think that thwarting a little inflation now, even at the risk of slowing economic growth slightly, is better than hitting the economy with big rate increases to try to brake even faster inflation shortly before the Presidential election in November.
''We have no objection to what they're trying to do,'' Beryl W. Sprinkel, the President's chief economic adviser, said today. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, an informal adviser to the Presidential campaign of Vice President Bush, expressed similar views Tuesday.
Some other experts, however, contend that the Federal Reserve's intervention is so cautious and so tentative that it reflects more confusion than conviction about the course of the economy.
The one-quarter point rise in the Federal funds rate does not seem a very forthright assault on inflation, said Scott E. Pardee, a former senior Federal Reserve official who is now vice chairman of Yamaichi International on Wall Street. ''What it looks like is a big fudge,'' he said. Confusing Signals
But the behavior of the economy invites some confusion, analysts say. The unemployment rate has dropped to 5.4 percent, its lowest level in 14 years. At such a level, some economists assume, industry has to bid up wages to recruit workers and then charge higher prices to pay the higher wages.
Hourly wages rose last month at an annual rate of 6 percent, or two percentage points more than the current inflation rate of about 4 percent. Prices of the commodities that industries buy to make their products have also picked up a bit in recent days, putting additional pressure on prices.
Meanwhile, the economy strikes some economists as out of balance. While the economy might be growing at a sound enough annual rate of 3 percent, consumer spending is accounting for too much of the growth, they complain. With the long decline of the dollar's value, lowering the prices of American exports, exports had been expected to provide most of the economy's strength.
Some sectors of American industry are showing strains in meeting the demands of both the domestic consumers and the foreign markets, and as industry approaches the limits of its productive capacity it tends to raise prices. And the money supply, whose growth the Federal Reserve tries to control, has been growing faster than the central bank desires, possibly signaling higher inflation. The Oil Factor
On the other hand, wage increases, though strong in April, have not been nearly as strong as they were when the economy was showing similar strength in the past. Oil prices are softening, too, which helps keep all prices down. With all these developments, the financial markets have concluded that inflation is heading up and have pushed up long-term rates.
Mr. Sprinkel, for one, says the Federal Reserve is right to raise rates to bring the money supply into line, but he says the market's assumptions about inflation and low unemployment will be soon be disproved. ''I don't believe for a moment that at these levels of employment, inflation has to take off,'' he said.
One Federal Reserve economist, who declined to be named, said: ''What the Fed has to do is make a judgment about whether the old assumptions about inflation and unemployment persist or whether we're in a new era of labor docility.
''We've reached a point where historical relationships would suggest some increase in wage growth. We haven't seen it yet. Are historical relationships going to prevail, or have they broken apart?''
Given the uncertainty, he implied, the Fed is prudent to let interest rates rise a bit.

Moderately Higher Inflation Forecast

Author: ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]25 Apr 1988: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426788337?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''We are going to get more inflation,'' said William C. Dunkelberg, dean of Temple University's School of Business and Management. He cited increasing tightness in the labor market - at 5.5 percent the national unemployment rate has not been lower since 1974 - and the fact that the paper, chemical and certain other industries are now running at virtually full capacity. ''You've got to get some price pressure out of that,'' he added. 5 Percent Called Likely A similar view was expressed by Kathryn L. Kobe, a vice president at Joel Popkin & Company, a consulting firm headed by a former top specialist on prices at the Department of Labor. ''We are looking at 5 percent by the end of this year,'' Ms. Kobe said, adding that this was likely even if the economy stumbled into a recession. ''I'd say the dollar's the predominant culprit'' in the inflation outlook, said Robert C. Holland, a former Fed governor and now head of the Committee for Economic Development, an industry group. ''We've been fortunate to have had as little effect as we've had so far.'' Leverage on Auto Prices Weyerhaeuser's Mr. [Lynn O. Michaelis], for one, thinks this is a risky policy. ''They may be doing a little bit too much of this fine-tuning,'' he said. ''We don't yet think we're launched into the kind of inflationary pressures of the 1970's.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Moderately+Higher+Inflation+Forecast&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-04-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=ROBERT+D.+HERSHEY+Jr.%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: The United States appears to be entering a period of moderately higher inflation in which the general price level could rise 5 percent or more a year into the early 1990's, many economists and business executives maintain.
The United States appears to be entering a period of moderately higher inflation in which the general price level could rise 5 percent or more a year into the early 1990's, many economists and business executives maintain.
This acceleration, which is seen as pushing a bit higher and arriving a bit earlier than was expected as recently as last winter, is a result of the decline in the international value of the dollar, the probable end of falling oil prices and the accumulating pressures of an uninterrupted business expansion that began more than five years ago.
''We are going to get more inflation,'' said William C. Dunkelberg, dean of Temple University's School of Business and Management. He cited increasing tightness in the labor market - at 5.5 percent the national unemployment rate has not been lower since 1974 - and the fact that the paper, chemical and certain other industries are now running at virtually full capacity. ''You've got to get some price pressure out of that,'' he added. 5 Percent Called Likely A similar view was expressed by Kathryn L. Kobe, a vice president at Joel Popkin & Company, a consulting firm headed by a former top specialist on prices at the Department of Labor. ''We are looking at 5 percent by the end of this year,'' Ms. Kobe said, adding that this was likely even if the economy stumbled into a recession.
At the same time, however, the various analysts and decision-makers expressed little fear of a return to the highly worrisome and disruptive inflation levels that averaged in double digits from 1979 through 1981. ''There's no sign of that type of wage-price spiral now,'' said Lynn O. Michaelis, chief economist for the Weyerhaeuser Company, the forest-products company.
Although recently reported jumps in both the Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods in March prompted waves of selling in the securities markets, these statistics by themselves did not make a persuasive case for a higher inflation level.
Analysts pointed out, for example, that half the difference between February's increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the consumer index and March's five-tenths rise reflected a temporary bulge in apparel prices related to the semiannual introduction of new lines. They also noted that the Producer Price Index for Crude Goods posted its fourth decline in the last five months. Nothing Unusual Seen
''I don't see anything in them that's all that unusual,'' said Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and a voting member this year of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee. He added that the 4.2 percent consumer index inflation rate over the latest three months was not meaningfully higher than the 3.9 percent rate over the latest 12 months.
Nonetheless, the March increases did tend to focus attention on the prospect that various forces do seem now to be converging to raise the country's inflation rate a notch or two - to probably 4.5 to 5 percent or perhaps somewhat more for the second half of this year.
One important factor is the dollar's three-year decline against the currencies of Japan and most European trading partners. Assuming foreign producers have about exhausted their ability to protect hard-won markets here by accepting progressively slimmer profit margins, they will be seeking to add to what in some areas have already become substantial price increases. While some analysts believe that much of this impact has already been absorbed, others insist that the sizable effects still lie ahead.
''I'd say the dollar's the predominant culprit'' in the inflation outlook, said Robert C. Holland, a former Fed governor and now head of the Committee for Economic Development, an industry group. ''We've been fortunate to have had as little effect as we've had so far.'' Leverage on Auto Prices
With the economy running short of capacity in some areas, various restrictions on the importing of steel, textiles and other goods are having more price ''bite,'' economists note. Even in cars, where there is little production constraint, the limit on Japanese imports has given Detroit more leverage to raise its prices.
Oil is another likely force for higher inflation. After four years in which the consumer index's rise was held to just under 4 percent, the collapse of world oil prices in 1986 shriveled inflation that year to 1.1 percent. With a relatively steady oil price last year, inflation rebounded to 4.4 percent and many analysts now assume that the stepped-up fighting in the Persian Gulf insures that oil prices will be driven up this year.
Although upward pressure on wages has been modest so far, some suspect that the United States may be losing this as an inflation suppressant. In a draft of a special report on inflation to be published shortly, the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University notes that the percentage of the working-age population who already have jobs ''has been moving along a path similar to previous inflation upswings.'' This is unsettling in an economy in which employee compensation accounts for about 73 percent of national income and is thus the biggest factor in business costs and pricing. Fewer Younger Workers
Demographic changes that have resulted in smaller pools of younger workers seem likely to aggravate wage pressures, other analysts said.
But these pressures seem to be concentrated outside the normal domain of organized labor. Rudy Oswald, an economist for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said he saw little sign of any basic new inflation surge. ''There's no indication'' of this, he said, noting, for example, that an alternate Labor Department consumer index in March rose only three-tenths of 1 percent compared to the five-tenths rise in the more popular version.
Ms. Kobe, on the other hand, said she expected the Government to report this week a sizable increase for the first quarter in its key employment cost index, one of the best gauges of wage pressures.
Another skeptic about inflation is Elizabeth A. Bossong, a Pittsburgh steel consultant. Calling current inflation fears ''more in the eye of the financial community'' than justified by the ''real'' world, she said it was premature to worry about serious inflation even in steel where many kinds of products are already in tight supply.
''I still don't see the old-type cost pressures that would suggest inflation on the industrial side,'' Ms. Bossong insisted. Evidence of Many Increases
Nonetheless, there is evidence that many prices are, in fact, being raised. A survey by the National Federation of Independent Business found last month that 27 percent of its respondents planned to raise prices in the next six months, the highest since early 1984, and that 30 percent had raised prices in the last six months, the highest since late 1981.
Many of those who believe that the nation's underlying inflation rate is indeed heading for, say, 5 percent from 4 percent, maintain that this should not be cause for alarm.
''It doesn't mean we have a serious inflation problem and, in fact, it's not necessarily a bad thing at all,'' Temple's Mr. Dunkelberg said. Higher prices and higher profits are the ''signals'' needed for the economy to shift resources from consumer goods into its increasingly export-oriented industrial sector so that the country can cut its huge deficit in international trade, he added.
Higher inflation will also tend, other economists said, to keep the dollar at low enough levels to sustain the current export boom. Fears on Action by Fed
Many analysts said that one of their main fears was that the Federal Reserve, which they see as having little analytical cohesiveness these days, will misinterpret the threat and over-react to slow the economy, possibly tipping it into a recession.
Indeed, the Fed may have already begun to ''fight the wrong war,'' some maintain. One piece of evidence cited is a recent address by H. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.
''Because the Federal Reserve has been credible in fighting inflation in the 1980's,'' Mr. Hoskins told Seattle business economists, ''it should be possible to contain inflation by using very small policy changes as long as these changes are initiated in advance of rising inflation.''
Weyerhaeuser's Mr. Michaelis, for one, thinks this is a risky policy. ''They may be doing a little bit too much of this fine-tuning,'' he said. ''We don't yet think we're launched into the kind of inflationary pressures of the 1970's.''

PROSPECTS; Will Lower Unemployment Fuel Inflation?

Author: Kurtzman, Joel

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Mar 1988: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426767148?accountid=11752

Abstract: The Phillips curve didn't take into account commodity or food shortages, which were behind a lot of the inflation of the 1970's. You have to remember that through much of the 1970's and 80's, there was recession, inflation and declining employment in the manufacturing sector. These economic conditions made people cautious about pushing for higher wages. The unions, in particular, have been cautious in their wage demands and are more interested in job security. Only if there is no recession this year, and the expansion continues, will there be any real push for higher wages. For the rest of the year, unemployment will continue at its 5.6 percent level, or dip slightly, and inflation will continue at 4 1/2 percent. MARVIN KOSTERS Director of Economic Policy Studies at the American Enterprise Institute.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=PROSPECTS%3B+Will+Lower+Unemployment+Fuel+Inflation%3F&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1988-03-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Kurtzman%2C+Joel&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Unemployment has fallen to 5.6 percent, the lowest rate in 8 1/2 years. Will increased tightness in the labor market push up inflation? The Phillips curve - an economic relationship which shows that inflation grows as unemployment shrinks, and vice versa - would suggest the answer is yes. But most economists say the curve is not an accurate guide.
Unemployment has fallen to 5.6 percent, the lowest rate in 8 1/2 years. Will increased tightness in the labor market push up inflation? The Phillips curve - an economic relationship which shows that inflation grows as unemployment shrinks, and vice versa - would suggest the answer is yes. But most economists say the curve is not an accurate guide. BARRY BLUESTONE Professor of political economy, University of Massachussets at Boston.
Inflation has various roots and labor is certainly one. But so are energy prices and the weather. The question today is whether the labor market has become so tight that it is bidding up wages. In the major unionized sectors of the economy, the wage settlements have been very modest. Wage increases relative to productivity have been small. And unit labor costs rose no more than 2 percent in 1987, compared with more than 6 percent a year during the 1970's. This means there doesn't seem to be any indication of a rise in labor costs and none of increased inflation. We'll have sluggish economic growth this year - about 2 percent - with unemployment at about 5.5 percent. Inflation will stay between 3 1/2 and 4 percent. JANET L. NORWOOD Commissioner, Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Many economists have difficulty with the Phillips curve. The overall rate of inflation is moved not just by labor, but by things like oil prices, which are affected by external causes, and food, which is affected by the weather. These two factors have played a large role in the inflation picture over the last two decades. So far food and energy prices have been behaving well. What we don't know is the effect on inflation of the lower dollar and the probable increase in import prices. FRANK LEVY Economist, University of Maryland School of Public Affairs.
The Phillips curve didn't take into account commodity or food shortages, which were behind a lot of the inflation of the 1970's. You have to remember that through much of the 1970's and 80's, there was recession, inflation and declining employment in the manufacturing sector. These economic conditions made people cautious about pushing for higher wages. The unions, in particular, have been cautious in their wage demands and are more interested in job security. Only if there is no recession this year, and the expansion continues, will there be any real push for higher wages. For the rest of the year, unemployment will continue at its 5.6 percent level, or dip slightly, and inflation will continue at 4 1/2 percent. MARVIN KOSTERS Director of Economic Policy Studies at the American Enterprise Institute.
During most of the 1980's, wages grew by progressively smaller amounts each year. Last year was the first year wages grew at a greater rate than the year before - and this doesn't include bonuses to hourly workers, which are increasingly common.
But what happens to inflation this year will depend on public policy - such as the legislated increase in the minimum wage or new laws requiring employers to increase employee health care benefits. Without these policy changes, we will see a slight uptick in the inflation rate. But with these changes, there very well might be a large increase in inflation in 1988 and 1989. Don't forget that labor costs account for two-thirds of the total gross national product and without productivity gains, increases in wages translate into higher prices.

When the World's Growth Slows

Author: Greenhouse, Steven

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]27 Dec 1987: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426688142?accountid=11752

Abstract: Many economists are clearly chagrined that leaders of the industrial world do not seem terribly alarmed about the slowdown. ''The most dangerous thing is the gradual acceptance that if all we have is 2 percent growth, that's O.K., without thinking that for many people real earnings will remain basically unchanged throughout their lifetimes,'' said Jean Baneth, director of the World Bank's international economics department. ''That will be very different from the societies we built in the 1950's and 1960's, where there were expectations of improvement.'' ''In the 1960's, governments were willing to push against capacity more than they are today, and there was a kind of optimism about the inflationary consequences, a feeling that inflation could be limited or that it could be lived with,'' said Georges de Menil, an economics professor at Paris's Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales. ''That feeling has changed profoundly throughout the industrial world. That is one reason why growth is not faster than it is today.'' The end of American hegemony means Washington can no longer singlehandly correct the world's economic ills. ''After World War II, the U.S. had 50 percent of the world G.N.P. and could play locomotive for the world whenever growth slowed,'' said M.I.T.'s Dean Thurow. ''Now the U.S. is down to 23 percent of world G.N.P. and can't play locomotive.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=When+the+World%27s+Growth+Slows&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1987-12-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Greenhouse%2C+Steven&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: WORLD economic growth has been shrinking and shrinking, but so gradually - and so inexorably - that economists have grown accustomed to the numbers. Yet a stark tale emerges when those numbers are added together year after year and their impact is examined.
WORLD economic growth has been shrinking and shrinking, but so gradually - and so inexorably - that economists have grown accustomed to the numbers. Yet a stark tale emerges when those numbers are added together year after year and their impact is examined.
There is an academic ring to the words ''slower international economic growth.'' But translated into human terms, these words lose their textbook abstraction. They mean longer unemployment lines from the north of England to northern Ohio and fewer opportunities for 16-year-olds from Pasadena to Paris. In the developing world, they mean something even more painful: malnourished children, ramshackle housing, high rates of infant mortality. Together, they weave a quilt of many interconnecting colors, and that is the only way they can be looked at: Economists have long recognized that slower world growth hurts everyone, from the richest nations to the poorest and that all are bound together.
The numbers are telling: In the 1950's and 1960's, the global economy grew by about 5 percent a year, sending living standards galloping forward in much of the world. In the 1970's, growth fell to slightly above 3 percent, and in the 80's it has slipped to about 2.3 percent. The outlook for the next few years is for a continued slide.
The slowdown is having serious effects on expectations and living standards in much of the world. For the average American worker, the slowdown in growth has meant that real income has not risen since 1973. In Europe, growth has been so slow that the jobless rate has soared to over 11 percent. For the debt-plagued nations of Africa and South America, this slowing trend has pushed per capita income 15 percent below the levels of 1980.
Yet, as 1988 dawns, many economists believe the world faces a rare opportunity in economic history. For the first time, they say, the leading industrial nations might have the power to reverse the slowdown, mainly because of an unusual confluence of circumstances. Inflation and budget deficits have been tamed in many nations. Corporate profits are healthy and interest rates are lower than they were a few months ago. Several important technological breakthroughs, such as fiber optics and superconductors, are waiting to be spread through the world; big technological advances often push growth by creating new opportunities and jobs.
''The conditions for going back to 3 to 4 percent growth in the world economy are actually better now than they have been at any time since the 1960's,'' said Stephen Marris, senior economist with the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
YET if the leading industrial nations fail to work together to help reduce trade imbalances and push growth upward, some economists warn of serious trouble ahead. The world's fragile financial markets could take another deep plunge, they say, dragging down the world economy. If growth rates continue sliding, the trend could usher in an era of downward mobility, forcing people to work harder just to stay in the same place economically. If economic growth falls below the 1 percent population growth in much of the industrial world, people will have to struggle to keep their living standards from falling.
Such an era of frustrated expectations could heighten tensions in the industrial world and political instability in the third world. In developing countries, it could exacerbate an already grave situation: As per capita income declines, poverty increases from one year to the next.
''This slowdown makes it particularly difficult for the really poor countries to grow,'' said Angus Maddison, author of several books on world growth rates and professor of economics at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands. ''Their growth is intertwined with the industrial world. They should be catching up to us and growing faster, but they are having problems because our growth has slowed.''
TECHNICALLY, growth is defined as the increased output in a nation's goods and services, covering everything from housing to hospital care. Many factors - from technology to economic policies - can help growth, or hinder it. Just as it seemed natural that growth would take off after World War II, as consumer demand was unleashed and economies were rebuilt, it also seemed inevitable that growth would fall from those heady levels.
But in recent years, other, more political factors have contributed to the further slowdown. Today, some economists argue that a few nations - particularly West Germany - have been overzealous in their fight against inflation, and that, in the process, they have sacrificed global economic growth.
Many economists are clearly chagrined that leaders of the industrial world do not seem terribly alarmed about the slowdown. ''The most dangerous thing is the gradual acceptance that if all we have is 2 percent growth, that's O.K., without thinking that for many people real earnings will remain basically unchanged throughout their lifetimes,'' said Jean Baneth, director of the World Bank's international economics department. ''That will be very different from the societies we built in the 1950's and 1960's, where there were expectations of improvement.''
Although some economists say the 25-year period after World War II was extraordinary because growth levels far exceeded historic norms, they say there is no reason why growth rates in the 1990's cannot move closer to levels of the 1960's.
Getting there from here will not be easy, however. In the last five years, a stubborn third world debt crisis has slowed growth in both developing and industrial nations. The United States, once an all-powerful locomotive that pulled weaker economies along with it, has been plagued by huge trade and budget deficits that it seems unwilling to reduce as fast as the rest of the world would like. And West Germany, Europe's most powerful economy, is so nervous about increasing inflation that it does not want to stimulate its economy nearly as much as other nations want.
In recent years, many governments tried to fight inflation at the expense of growth. Now, economists say, they must shift gears and focus more on promoting growth - using policy vehicles that could range from more government spending to investment incentives - while keeping inflation under control.
The huge trade imbalances, which have roiled stock and foreign exchange markets since mid-October, must be cut before the world can move into a smoother - and faster - growth period.
MANY economists say that unless stronger steps are taken to slash America's $155-billion trade deficit and Japan's and West Germany's huge trade surpluses, markets will remain unstable and interest rates will rise. That could lead to a sharp economic downturn, making it hard for growth in the 1990's to outpace growth in the 1980's.
''What is holding us back from achieving faster growth,'' Mr. Marris said, ''is we have to correct this incredible disequilibrium, and it will be very difficult to do that while avoiding a recession.''
Mr. Marris was one of 33 prominent economists from 13 countries who signed a statement earlier this month calling on Washington, Bonn and Tokyo to take more decisive actions to reduce trade imbalances. The economists said Washington should try to cut domestic demand and imports further, and must go beyond its recent deficit reductions. It must, they say, cut its $150 billion deficit by an additional $40 billion a year for several years.
The economists also urged West Germany to raise imports and accelerate and expand tax cuts scheduled for 1990. And they urged Japan to push domestic demand growth above 4 percent a year.
Although most economists agree on what these three nations must do, they say improved world economic growth could become a hostage to domestic political constraints. Bonn and, to a lesser degree, Tokyo, fret that greater stimulus will mean increased inflation and angry voters. In an election year, Washington worries about how voters will react to higher taxes or more budget cuts.
''Coordination means each would have to do what's good for the world economy, but they don't want to do it,'' said Lester Thurow, an economist and dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The oil shock of 1973 is often called the turning point when world economic growth started to slow. But other forces were already at work.
Consumer demand was explosive after World War II. In North America, Europe and Japan, families rushed to buy homes, cars and televisions, helping to create a golden era of sustained growth. Europe's economy forged ahead as it rebuilt. And Europe and Japan bounded ahead as they adopted many of the advanced technologies that the United States had monopolized. This meant huge investments as well as great strides in productivity and growth.
Simultaneously, major tariff reductions, brought about by successive rounds of multilateral negotiations, produced a trade boom that was a catalyst for growth. By the early 1970's, however, the factors that fostered strong growth were largely played out.
Then came 1973. OPEC nations quadrupled the price of oil, and the oil shock cut into purchasing power, hit corporate profits and created a wave of uncertainty that slowed investment. It also produced a recession in the United States and the first post-war recession in Europe.
''That created a globalization of economic problems,'' said Rudiger Pohl, professor of economics at Hagen University in Germany.
About the same time, the world was rocked by another economic shock: the decision to abandon fixed exchange rates in favor of floating ones. Many economists said companies began hesitating before they invested, even when demand and profits were strong, because they feared future exchange rate fluctuations.
Many conservative economists - and even some liberal ones - say the development of the so-called welfare state in many industrialized nations also placed a brake on growth. Productivity growth and investment were discouraged, they say, by the increase in regulations on industry as well as higher taxes that supported more generous social programs.
Higher taxes, higher inflation, greater uncertainty from oil shocks and exchange rate volatility all contributed to a declining rate of investment. Business investment had long served as a powerful flywheel that kept growth humming even when consumer spending slowed. Sluggish investment reduced the flywheel effect, cutting growth and raising the volatility of the world economy. That provided another disincentive to investment, which hurt productivity growth. Rising productivity is vital because it allows for faster economic growth without inflation.
DURING the 1970's, governments began an about-face, trying to slow growth in order to stamp out inflation.
Then came the 1979 oil shock. Creeping inflation began galloping; fighting it became a priority worldwide. Governments slammed the brakes on growth - in ways that ranged from curbing spending to raising interest rates.
''In the 1960's, governments were willing to push against capacity more than they are today, and there was a kind of optimism about the inflationary consequences, a feeling that inflation could be limited or that it could be lived with,'' said Georges de Menil, an economics professor at Paris's Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales. ''That feeling has changed profoundly throughout the industrial world. That is one reason why growth is not faster than it is today.''
But according to Professor de Menil, today's slower growth - provided growth continues - might be smarter that the go-go growth of yesteryear because it is less inflationary and therefore more sustainable.
Nevertheless, many economists see several underlying problems with the slow-growth, anti-inflation approach. In particular, they say, the fight against inflation is causing economic growth to fall short of its potential. ''There have been restrictive fiscal policies in many countries, especially Germany,'' said Professor Pohl. ''That has made global demand weak, and that has been one of the causes of the growth slowdown over the past five years.''
In the 1960's, the United States, Japan, France and many nations embraced policies to keep demand strong. In the United States, the Vietnam War contributed to big spending at the same time that the nation was spending heavily on social programs.
Now many countries - especially West Germany - seem to be trying to keep demand modest to help hold down inflation. For many governments, the emphasis has been on the supply side - reducing regulations, taming unions, lowering taxes - in order to encourage investment. Some economists say that even with supply side stimulus, companies still may not feel enough incentive to invest because they do not expect much growth in demand.
''There is a vicious cycle,'' said Mr. Baneth of the World Bank. ''Business does not have confidence in long-term growth, and because of their lack of confidence, they're not creating the capacity which would allow long-term growth in a stable, non-inflationary environment.''
Professor Maddison, who used to be one of the top economists at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said conditions were right for pushing the world economy to perform closer to what he says is its growth potential of 4 percent a year.
''One thing is clear: The world economic situation is much less inflationary now that it had been,'' he said. ''The time is ripe to experiment with more active demand management.''
Another problem that many economists see with the anti-inflation fight is that Europe and Japan have taken one approach and the United States took another. After the 1979 oil shock, Europe and Japan adopted policies of fiscal consolidation, slashing budget deficits and cutting the ratio of their budgets to their gross national product. Meanwhile, in Washington, the Federal Reserve Board jacked up interest rates to help whip inflation and the Reagan Administration pushed through huge tax cuts that produced gargantuan budget deficits.
Taken together, these disparate approaches sent the dollar soaring and generated a huge American trade deficit and enormous German and Japanese trade surpluses.
''These policy mess-ups create much more skepticism about the power of government to do anything good about the economy and about long-term growth in demand,'' said Andrea Baltho, an Oxford University economist who has written extensively on world growth.
Many economists say that reconciling the disparate approaches to fighting inflation, thereby reducing trade imbalances, would help lead to faster growth. Resolving the third world debt crisis would also be a boon to growth, they say.
''Brazil, Argentina, a lot of these countries used to be very dynamic economies,'' said Richard Portes, director of the Center for Economic Policy Research in London. ''But because everyone is worried about having to bail out a few banks, we have not yet taken the bold steps needed to bring the less developed countries back to being dynamic contributors to world growth.''
EFFORTS to correct all these problems - to pave the way for faster growth - have been made harder by another pronounced change in the world economy: the decline of the United States as the world's premier economic power. This has been caused by many factors: the economic rise of Japan and the Pacific Rim, America's huge borrowings, the once-strong dollar's damage to America's manufacturing base, and the increasing ease of transfering manufacturing technology from industrial countries to developing ones.
The end of American hegemony means Washington can no longer singlehandly correct the world's economic ills. ''After World War II, the U.S. had 50 percent of the world G.N.P. and could play locomotive for the world whenever growth slowed,'' said M.I.T.'s Dean Thurow. ''Now the U.S. is down to 23 percent of world G.N.P. and can't play locomotive.''
As a result, there is a greater need for the three leading industrial powers - United States, Japan and Germany - to work together to furnish the leadership that Washington once provided. But how likely is that?
''Coordination,'' Dean Thurow said, ''is very easy to say, very easy to praise, but very difficult to do.''

Subject: ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; FORECASTS

People: Marris, Stephen GREENHOUSE, STEVEN

Economic Spotlight Is on Bonn

Author: STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]05 Nov 1987: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426678559?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''Some people in the Bundesbank say we have to be careful because the domestic-made rate of inflation is about 1.5 percent and may be rising,'' said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist for Commerzbank. ''In my view, 1.5 percent is no inflation at all.'' A Call to Stimulate Consumption ''We are not neurotic about inflation,'' Mr. [Karl Otto Pohl] said Monday in a speech defending German policies. ''Experience has taught us not to wait until prices go up, because then it is mostly too late.'' ''The rise of the mark against the dollar shouldn't hurt us that much because only one-tenth of Germany's exports go to the United States,'' Mr. Ramm said. ''Besides, about 50 percent of Germany's imports are dollar-denominated.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Spotlight+Is+on+Bonn&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1987-11-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=STEVEN+GREENHOUSE%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: LEAD: Wherever the Germans turn, someone is telling them what to do.
Wherever the Germans turn, someone is telling them what to do.
If it is not Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d agitating for lower interest rates, it is Edouard Balladur, France's Finance Minister, calling on Bonn to spur economic growth.
The Germans do not quite understand why so much attention is focused on their economy, which has had steady if unspectacular growth and minuscule inflation. They are perplexed by the anger directed at them over the dollar's recent plunge to only 1.70 German marks, a development the Germans say has been caused not by Bonn, but by Washington's failure to rein in its budget and trade deficits.
''We did not cause all the imbalances - they're mainly the fault of the Americans - and we are not very eager to change what we think is a solid economic course,'' said one German economic policy maker. Germans Seen as Disingenuous
Many West Germans may feel that their country is being unfairly singled out, but the country's trading partners, particularly the United States, view this response as disingenuous.
America and others say that Germany - Europe's largest economy and the world's leading exporting nation - is such an important player on the international scene that it needs to take a more active role to reduce the world's trade imbalances. Last year, Germany's merchandise trade surplus totaled $57 billion while the United States trade deficit was $147 billion. Germany's economy is a quarter the size of the United States'.
Washington, like numerous international organizations, says that Germany could contribute in two ways. One, it could cut interest rates. This would permit the United States to keep its own rates down and would help to stimulate a world economy that some worry may face a recession because of the recent stock market collapse. Two, the Germans could take strides to consume more - buying more from abroad, for example -to help to reduce the gargantuan American trade deficit.
All this would mean stimulating the economy, which could increase inflation, the Germans' traditional nemesis. But signs of positive action by Germany might help to calm the financial markets, which have been roiled, at least in part, by the split between Bonn and Washington.
More and more Germans, albeit still a minority, are urging their leaders to worry less about inflation and more about economic growth. On Monday, Germany's five leading economic institutes called on the Government to speed up tax cuts to help increase growth beyond its lackluster annual rate of 1.5 percent, a rate likely to be hurt by the rise of the German mark. Ending the Market Turmoil
Whether Germany helped to cause the trade imbalances is not the issue, many economists say. In their view, the issue is how best to end the turmoil in the stock and foreign exchange markets, and to most economists, the answer is more international cooperation, including a lot of cooperation from Germany.
Indeed, Treasury Secretary Baker thought German action was so essential that in mid-October he threatened to let the dollar drop if the Germans did not lower their interest rates. It was a threat that many say helped to spur the worldwide stock plunge.
The Germans fret that what may be good medicine for the world economy could be bad medicine for their country. German officials and economists are quick to point out that a decade ago, their nation relucantly bowed to foreign pressure to increase the budget deficit to speed up economic growth. Today, the Germans still grouse about the economic hangover: a budget deficit one year of about $33 billion and an inflation rate of almost 7 percent, a rate the Germans consider suffocatingly high.
Moreover, the Germans often recall the hyperinflation that afflicted their nation in the late 1920's and late 1940's. Memories of people carting wheelbarrows full of money to do their shopping still live vividly in the German mind.
''This is a country where people think 2 percent inflation is already too high,'' said Hermann Rempsberger, chief economist for Berliner Handels- und Frankfurter Bank.
Many economists say that Bonn is silly to worry that pump priming will produce inflation. The nation's inflation rate this year is about 1 percent. The soaring mark will help hold down the price of imports. And with a jobless rate of 8.3 percent, there is plenty of slack in the economy.
''Some people in the Bundesbank say we have to be careful because the domestic-made rate of inflation is about 1.5 percent and may be rising,'' said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist for Commerzbank. ''In my view, 1.5 percent is no inflation at all.'' A Call to Stimulate Consumption
Officials in Washington and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have long urged Bonn to stimulate consumption. On the fiscal side, they say that Bonn should cut taxes to put more money in the hands of consumers and increase Government spending.
But Bonn officials say they have already moved to satisfy Washington. In the spring, the Germany Parliament increased a tax cut, scheduled for Jan. 1, from $5.3 billion to $8.2 billion. In addition, Bonn has scheduled another $11.8 billion in tax cuts to take effect in 1990.
These would help increase Bonn's budget deficit to $19 billion in 1990, from about $12 billion in 1985. ''If you take our budget deficit as a measure for expansionary policies, we're clearly on the path of expansion in absolute and relative terms,'' said one Finance Ministry official.
German officials note that one of the main reasons that the Social Democratic Party was voted out in 1982 and Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition was voted in was displeasure about the Government's lack of fiscal discipline. Rising Budget Deficits
''Budget deficits have been rising in Germany and will be increasing and it's very difficult for our Government to do more,'' said Mr. Rempsberger, the economist.
In addition, German economists estimate that their nation's domestic demand will grow by about 3 percent.
With regard to monetary policy, Bonn's critics say that since Oct. 19, when stock prices collapsed, it has not done enough to lower interest rates. American officials say that since the German mark is arguably the world's second most important currency, Germany's interest rates be significantly below American rates so the United States does not have problems attracting investors to finance its huge budget deficit.
''The Germans have done less to reduce interest rates than anyone else since Oct. 19,'' said Ian Harwood, an economist with Warburg Securities in London.
At the Bundesbank in Frankfurt, officials boast that they have lowered interest rates since Secretary Baker made his demand and since the stock market's plunge. The central bank has lowered an important market rate to 3.80 percent, from 3.85 percent, and some economists predict the Bundesbank will reduce it to 3.65 percent in the next few weeks. Although the decline is small, some participants in the financial markets place more immediate importance on the general direction of interest rates.
Economists in Frankfurt say there is a split within the Bundesbank between the pragmatists, who are willing to pare interest rates, and the hard-liners. The latter group, said to be in the majority, is headed by Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank vice president, and seems to care more about fighting inflation than accommodating the demands of Germany's trading partners. Their main concern seems to be that the German money supply has risen by 7.8 percent so far this year, which in their view could mean an upsurge in inflation next year.
Karl Otto Pohl, the Bundesbank's president, is said to favor reduced interest rates, but is occasionally outvoted by the hard-liners.
''We are not neurotic about inflation,'' Mr. Pohl said Monday in a speech defending German policies. ''Experience has taught us not to wait until prices go up, because then it is mostly too late.''
Many foreign economists cannot understand why Germany is so reluctant to stimulate its economy, especially when the soaring mark is expected to slow Germany's economic growth. But German economists say the dollar's plunge from 3.2 marks in 1985 to only 1.70 German marks will not make much difference to their economy. Germany's Growth Estimates
Two weeks ago, Mr. Ramm of Commerzbank predicted Germany's economy would grow by 2 percent in 1988, but now he has cut that forecast by one- or two-tenths of a percentage point.
''The rise of the mark against the dollar shouldn't hurt us that much because only one-tenth of Germany's exports go to the United States,'' Mr. Ramm said. ''Besides, about 50 percent of Germany's imports are dollar-denominated.''
Some economists say that the overall economy could end up better off because a lower dollar means Germany in effect pays less for its oil and raw materials, which are often priced in dollars.
Many economists say that with their widespead affluence, long vacations and declining population, the Germans feel no compulsion to have a go-go growth policy. But the German attitude upsets economists who think Germany should be not a brake for Europe's growth, but an engine.
