NEW LIFE FOR A 'LAME DUCK'

Author: HERSHEY, ROBERT D, Jr

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]21 Dec 1986: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/426361090?accountid=11752

Abstract: Some of Mr. [Paul A. Volcker]'s strongest admirers, while hoping he remains on the job, believe that he might be wise ''to declare victory,'' as one put it, ''and leave town.'' For one thing, they say, the current economic situation is about as good as it's going to get for a while. Down the line, a crisis could erupt from the heavy trade deficit or the budget deficit or from the build-up of third world debt. Why not, then, use this relatively calm moment, they say, to turn over the reins to somebody else, perhaps Secretary of State George P. Shultz or Wall Street consultant Alan Greenspan, who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the mid-70's. IT seems odd, at least on the face of it, that the Reagan Administration would even think of saying farewell to the man most responsible for the pre-eminent economic achievement of the past six years, one that Republicans are sure to boast about in the election of 1988. Some say they already detect a certain disengagement by Mr. Volcker. ''Paul seems somewhat more distant from the job today than I've ever seen him before,'' a senior New York bank economist commented. ''You can build a case that he assumes - or knows - he's going and he's already started his preparations for leaving.'' ''Volcker's less interested now in putting up a fight for it than he was in 1983,'' summed up Jude Wanniski, an economic consultant who knows the chairman. ''If they ask him to stay on he would, but I don't think he's going to campaign.'' [Reagan]'S 'GANG OF FOUR'

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=NEW+LIFE+FOR+A+%27LAME+DUCK%27&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1986-12-21&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=HERSHEY%2C+ROBERT+D%2C+Jr&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: UNTIL about six weeks ago, those who profess to know who's who in this town said that Paul A. Volcker had become a lame duck - a man whose chances of being reappointed head of the Federal Reserve had fallen well below 50-50 and who had begun to weigh seriously some of the juicy seven-figure-a-year offers dangling before him.
Some observers even said they detected a certain detachment in Mr. Volcker's performance in the world's mightiest financial job. He had, they said, not engaged in the subtle lobbying that would have signaled his eagerness to remain in power.
Mr. Volcker's departure, in many eyes, would be a sharp blow to confidence in American economic policy making and could lead, among other things, to a run on the dollar. Like two of his modern predecessors, William McChesney Martin Jr. and Arthur F. Burns, Mr. Volcker has come to be seen as an almost impossibly tough act to follow.
But in the wake of the Administration's problems over selling arms to Iran, the odds seem to have shifted abruptly. Mr. Volcker now appears at least as likely to stay as to go, prompting many on Wall Street and in central banks and ministries around the world to heave some tentative sighs of relief.
''Given what's happening in Washington, his chances of being reappointed are probably pretty good,'' asserts Sam Nakagama, head of the economic advisory firm of Nakagama & Wallace Inc. ''You could even have a situation in which the White House needs Volcker more than he wants to stay.''
William F. Ford, a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta and now a savings and loan executive in Cleveland, agreed. ''The odds are good he'll be around,'' he declared.
''I think it's at least 60-40 he stays,'' estimated James F. Smith, a former Fed staff member now at the University of Texas.
The will-he-or-won't-he speculation about the Fed leader heated up last week with the resignation of Henry C. Wallich, the longest-serving of the Federal Reserve Board's seven members, who has been ill since the fall of 1985. Mr. Wallich and Emmett J. Rice, who is also retiring from the board this month, have been Mr. Volcker's stoutest anti-inflation allies.
Some of Mr. Volcker's strongest admirers, while hoping he remains on the job, believe that he might be wise ''to declare victory,'' as one put it, ''and leave town.'' For one thing, they say, the current economic situation is about as good as it's going to get for a while. Down the line, a crisis could erupt from the heavy trade deficit or the budget deficit or from the build-up of third world debt. Why not, then, use this relatively calm moment, they say, to turn over the reins to somebody else, perhaps Secretary of State George P. Shultz or Wall Street consultant Alan Greenspan, who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the mid-70's. IT seems odd, at least on the face of it, that the Reagan Administration would even think of saying farewell to the man most responsible for the pre-eminent economic achievement of the past six years, one that Republicans are sure to boast about in the election of 1988.
Although the nation paid the price of a major recession, Mr. Volcker's Fed has managed to chop double-digit inflation by two-thirds and preside over a business expansion now entering its fifth year.
''They delivered him the wild horse of raging inflation and he turned it into a household pet,'' said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
There are various reasons, however, why the Administration is not eager to reappoint Mr. Volcker chairman and why it sought to ease him out in late 1984 by offering him the presidency of the World Bank. One is that he is a nominal Democrat, first named to the board by President Jimmy Carter, and a vigorous anti-inflationist who might be less likely than a replacement to provide enough money to finance a pre-election boom.
''Volcker is just not part of their team,'' observed one politically attuned banker. While Fed chairmen are not formal members of any ''team,'' the central bank has never been entirely immune from political pressures of the day.
A second argument against reappointment is that Mr. Volcker is not the committed deregulator of financial markets that many conservatives would like. He constantly worries, for example, that a fragmentation of the financial system would make it more vulnerable to shocks.
A third argument against reappointment is that Donald T. Regan, the President's chief of staff is known not to like him.
But the latter problem may have become irrelevant in recent weeks. Mr. Regan appears to be badly wounded by the Iran arms disclosures, and could be departing himself. If he stays, Mr. Regan is less likely to be the deciding voice either in filling the two immediate vacancies on the Fed board or in the chairmanship itself.
The result, many believe, could be a desire by an embattled President to keep Mr. Volcker on, with Mr. Regan unable to prevent it.
''Volcker stands as a symbol of real integrity,'' asserted Robert V. Roosa, a former Fed and Kennedy Administration official. The world financial system is ''just brittle enough'' to require a Fed chief of unquestioned rectitude and of proven international stature, Mr. Roosa observed, and few candidates seem to fill the bill.
Yet the Administration may have a tough job convincing Washington's most powerful economist to stay on at a post that he has obviously relished since 1979. One close friend reports that Mr. Volcker, who will turn 60 in September, is now ''struggling'' with the decision.
Throughout a career spent almost entirely in the Government, Mr. Volcker has seemed almost oblivious to the financial blandishments of the private sector. At the pinnacle of world finance he earns a relatively paltry $75,100 a year. In the private sector he could easily command 20 times that, or more. He is clearly aware of the monetary sacrifice he has made - one source says he even refuses presents of fine cigars for fear he'll become hooked on higher-quality smokes than his 30-cent Antonio y Cleopatra Grenadiers. He may be tiring of his spartan rumpled-suit-and-spaghetti life style and the drain of maintaining households in Washington for himself and in New York for his ailing wife.
One intimate says he has personally relayed to Mr. Volcker two propositions offering what he called ''unbelievable'' compensation. One would pay $2 million for a year of lecturing; the other would combine an investment firm partnership with a university professorship.
The friend reports, however, that Mr. Volcker offered in response a ''Buddha expression'' that gave no hint of his intentions.
Some say they already detect a certain disengagement by Mr. Volcker. ''Paul seems somewhat more distant from the job today than I've ever seen him before,'' a senior New York bank economist commented. ''You can build a case that he assumes - or knows - he's going and he's already started his preparations for leaving.''
Some observers say that a major factor in his decision would be Mr. Volcker's relations with the board. As of Jan. 1, all the other governors will have been chosen by President Reagan (see Box).
But Fed watchers say the chances are small that serious intramural friction will erupt. If it did, Mr. Volcker would almost certainly continue to dominate the Federal Open Market Committee, a 12-member body that sets monetary policy. AT the first hint that Mr. Volcker might leave, intense speculation began to arise as to who might take his place. A survey of 371 investment decision makers taken by Drexel Burnham's Mr. Hoey last month before the Iran controversy heated up ranked E. Gerald Corrigan, the Volcker protege who is president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as the man in whom they had the ''most confidence'' as successor.
Mr. Corrigan was favored by 26.2 percent of the respondents, followed by Mr. Greenspan, president of Townsend-Greenspan Inc., with 18.4 percent and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d with 8.9 percent.
However, when asked to name the most likely successor, the group listed Fed vice chairman Manuel H. Johnson, followed by Mr. Baker, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Regan. Mr. Corrigan ranked fifth. Those who know Mr. Baker best insist that he has no interest in the job. Washington hands, in fact, believe a more likely choice - provided that Mr. Johnson does not become the first No. 2 to be elevated - is Mr. Shultz. This assumes both that Mr. Shultz, an economist by training, is not tainted by the Iran arms episode and that he is willing, at age 65, to take the post.
A dark horse is Paul W. McCracken, a former Fed official and a chief economic adviser to former President Nixon. He will turn 70 this week.
Whether a post-Volcker Federal Reserve would prove much different from today's central bank is almost pure conjecture.
''As far as monetary policy goes, the answer is flatly no,'' declared a top former Fed official. But others disagree, suggesting that Mr. Johnson, for one, would probably be inclined toward faster money expansion than Mr. Volcker. The latter is known to believe that 3 percent annual economic growth is quite acceptable in current circumstances, while the Reagan appointees tend to think this too modest a goal.
But many, including Mickey D. Levy, an economist at Philadelphia's Fidelity Bank, put little stock in such neat characterizations. ''The Federal Reserve,'' he declared, is ''very human'' both in the independence of its members and in their tendency to be heavily influenced by the latest economic statistics.
The biggest change, many say, could come in the Fed's approach to its role as supervisor. Mr. Volcker has resisted proposed liberalization in banking powers, arguing that a further blurring of the distinction between commercial and investment banking, for example, risked the integrity of the financial structure.
Of this, the former top Fed official declared: ''A new chairman might have a very different attitude, might seek to break new ground.''
It is also possible, if reappointment is offered to Mr. Volcker, that his decision could hinge on his assessment of the caliber, rather than the economic views, of the other board members. One clue to watch is the identity of the two new members to be designated shortly. One vacancy is reported likely to be filled by either George W. Douglas, a deregulation-minded former commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission, or Edward M. Kelley, a Houston businessman. (Since both are Texans, only one can be chosen.) A high-quality, nonideological board might serve to convince Mr. Volcker that he could safely turn over the reins.
''Volcker's less interested now in putting up a fight for it than he was in 1983,'' summed up Jude Wanniski, an economic consultant who knows the chairman. ''If they ask him to stay on he would, but I don't think he's going to campaign.'' REAGAN'S 'GANG OF FOUR'
Last February, when Reagan-appointed governors became a majority on the Federal Reserve Board, there was much speculation that this Gang of Four would vote as a bloc for stepped-up expansion in the money supply. The foursome is generally more optimistic than its colleagues about how fast the economy can grow without producing unacceptably high inflation.
However, policy making seems to have been little affected by the Gang's arrival. Dissenting votes have been rare and, according to Fed watchers, there has never been a 4-3 decision along the presumed ''ideological'' lines.
Yet the possibility remains that Paul A. Volcker, whose second term as chairman runs out next August, could yet find himself in an untenable position because of changes in the board's composition. When President Reagan's choices to succeed the departing Henry C. Wallich and Emmett J. Rice are installed next year, Mr. Volcker will be facing, in theory at least, a Gang of Six.
Elevated to vice chairman of the board in August 1986, six months after becoming a governor. Age 37. Usually called
Manley. An ardent supply-sider while serving in the Reagan Treasury, he has played down or perhaps even modified his views since moving to the Fed. Said to have proven ''responsible'' and properly respectful of Fed traditions. Despite his youth, insiders say he has a shot at succeeding Mr. Volcker, although the No. 2 job has never been considered a steppingstone. A native of Troy, Ala. Earned a Ph.D. in economics at Florida State University in 1977. Taught economics at George Mason University. At Treasury, helped formulate economic policy and played a big role in designing the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981. Author of four books and has wide experience as a consultant. His term as governor expires in the year 2000.
A Kansas native who owes his seat to strong support by Senator Bob Dole. Age 56.
Proud of his diverse background as farmer, banker and college professor. Initially emphasized his ''pro-growth'' tendencies but recently has talked a strong anti-inflation line. His early outspokenness on the need to counter the depression in farming led some to perceive him as soft on inflation. Took a big gamble soon after joining the board by voting against Mr. Volcker on timing of a discount-rate cut. Since 1950, has been an active partner in a 3,300-acre Kansas farm. Ph.D. from University of Kansas. Long-time economics teacher at Ottawa (Kansas) University. Six years as member of the state House of Representatives. Extensive foreign travel. Sworn in on Feb. 7, 1986, the same day as Mr. Johnson, to fill an unexpired term ending in January 1994.
Second woman to serve on the board. Age 54. Was Michigan's
Commissioner of Financial Institutions in 1981-82, then professor of finance at Central Michigan University until nominated to the board. Opposed by many
Democrats, who called her unqualified, she survived a harrowing year-long struggle for confirmation. She has published little but describes her views as ''eclectic.'' After early experience as a Fed staffer in Washington and Chicago, spent 10 years as a commercial banker, including a stint as chief economist for the National Bank of Detroit. Close ties to the automobile business. Shortly after becoming governor, she made a highly publicized complaint that Mr. Volcker was running the Fed like a dictator. Ph.D. from the University of Michigan, where she was a protege of Paul W. McCracken. Installed in July 1984 to a full 14-year term.
The newest governor, only four months in office, he provides international expertise to fill the gap left by the resignation last week of his friend, Henry C. Wallich. Age 46. Born in Cologne, Germany, he came to the United States shortly after high school - and still marvels at his rise in the American financial establishment. A Ph.D. from the University of Minnesota, he taught at the Universities of California and Hawaii, spent four years at the International Monetary Fund. Head of international research for Bank of America just before joining the board. So far has kept a low profile and taken a pragmatic approach. Witty and urbane, he jokes that the Fed's regulatory work makes him feel like Judge Wapner of TV's ''People's Court.'' Well-connected with European central bankers. Author of five books. Filling an unexpired term that runs to 1996.

Subject: UNITED STATES ECONOMY; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; ETHICS; CREDIT

Location: IRAN UNITED STATES

People: HERSHEY, ROBERT D JR VOLCKER, PAUL A (CHMN) REAGAN, RONALD WILSON (PRES)

ECONOMIC SCENE; The Pressures Facing Volcker

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 July 1986: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425940903?accountid=11752

Abstract: There is bound to be a dispute about the priorities. Robert D. Hormats, vice president for investment banking at Goldman, Sachs & Company and a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, is one who thinks that combating the risk of economic weakness should be the Fed's top priority. He notes that Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, has been ''speaking for further cuts in the discount rate.'' Mr. Hormats sees the United States in a ''bit of a Catch-22'' situation: If the United States does not reduce the dollar's exchange rate further now, the prospects of a worsening trade deficit will increase; but if the Fed fails to bring interest rates down, the economy will weaken, driving the dollar further down anyway. In Mr. Hormats's view, the right course is to take the risk of cutting interest rates to move the dollar down and stimulate the economy while you can afford the risk of inflation. He sees a greater risk that, if nothing is done, ''we can really lose control of our currency, as Britain did in 1976.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=ECONOMIC+SCENE%3B+The+Pressures+Facing+Volcker&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1986-07-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WHEN Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, goes before Congress today to deliver the central bank's midyear review, he is likely to encounter a tougher grilling than usual on the Fed's forecasts and plans for correcting the economy's perceived weaknesses.
Anxieties about the economy were heightened yesterday by the Commerce Department's estimate that the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, grew at an annual rate of only 1.1 percent in the April-June quarter, the slowest pace since the end of the 1981-82 recession.
The Fed's report to Congress is cautiously optimistic about the economic outlook. For 1986, it expects real G.N.P. to rise within a range of 2.5 percent to 3 percent. That implies a slight improvement in the second half over the 2.4 percent rate in the new figures for the first half.
However, the Fed's forecast of 2.5 to 3 percent for 1986 marks a downward revision from its 3 to 3.5 percent growth range, projected six months ago. The Fed has also marked down its inflation forecast for this year to 2.25 to 2.75 percent from its original range of 3 to 4 percent. The just-reported inflation rate in the second quarter, as measured by the G.N.P. deflator, was only 2.1 percent, the lowest rate since the second quarter of 1967.
For next year, the Fed sees a moderate pickup. It is projecting inflation-adjusted growth of G.N.P. at 3 to 3.5 percent, with inflation moving up slightly, to 3 to 4 percent. And it predicts that the unemployment rate will decline to 6 3/4 percent by the final quarter of 1987, down a bit from its forecast of 7 percent in the last quarter of this year.
The main issue facing Congress in reacting to the Fed's midyear review is whether it has given too high a value to the risk of inflation relative to the risk of sluggish growth or recession.
There is bound to be a dispute about the priorities. Robert D. Hormats, vice president for investment banking at Goldman, Sachs & Company and a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, is one who thinks that combating the risk of economic weakness should be the Fed's top priority. He notes that Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, has been ''speaking for further cuts in the discount rate.''
Mr. Volcker has often argued that the Fed should cut its discount rate in step with other countries, lest it cause a ''free fall'' of the dollar. Two weeks ago, however, it did cut that rate without waiting for the others, and the dollar, while continuing to slide, has not plunged in a free fall.
Mr. Hormats sees the United States in a ''bit of a Catch-22'' situation: If the United States does not reduce the dollar's exchange rate further now, the prospects of a worsening trade deficit will increase; but if the Fed fails to bring interest rates down, the economy will weaken, driving the dollar further down anyway.
In Mr. Hormats's view, the right course is to take the risk of cutting interest rates to move the dollar down and stimulate the economy while you can afford the risk of inflation. He sees a greater risk that, if nothing is done, ''we can really lose control of our currency, as Britain did in 1976.''
Not all economists think further cuts in the dollar's value provide the answer to the trade deficit, which has played so key a role in slowing economic growth. Jeffrey R. Leeds, managing director of the Chemical Bank of New York, says the bulk of United States trade with Canada and the Pacific Basin, excluding Japan, is ''unaffected by the highly publicized decline in the value of the dollar, since those currencies have tended to remain steady or have lost value relative to the dollar over the past 15 months.''
While cutting the dollar's value may not be the entire answer to the trade deficit, most economists consider it crucial to improving the American trade position. The alternative would be for Japan, West Germany and the other industrial countries to spur their economies as a means of increasing markets for American and other exports.
But the efforts of Mr. Volcker, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and other Administration officials to ''jawbone'' the Europeans and Japanese into adopting more stimulative fiscal and monetary policies appears to be getting nowhere.
The choice for the United States is whether to risk unilateral action to bring down interest rates and the dollar - or wait for cooperative action by the other industrial countries.
In his session with Congress today, Mr. Volcker is likely to find himself under pressure to stop waiting and take more action to reduce interest rates, to spur exports and domestic investment as a way out of a slump. It is a situation calling for the fanciest of footwork, at which his skills are legendary. But he is likely to wind up assuring Congress that the Fed will do whatever is necessary to prevent a recession.

SHRINKAGE OF DEFICIT AWAITED

Author: PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]23 June 1986: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425911853?accountid=11752

Abstract: Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. and one of Wall Street's best-known foes of big deficits, sees a figure of $210 billion for 1986. For next year, he predicts $175 billion to $185 billion. ''But that's hardly an accomplishment,'' he said. ''It's still an extraordinary amount.'' Most projections exceed the earlier ones because the economy has taken some curious turns. One was the 50 percent plunge in oil prices, which has helped bring this year's inflation rate down a full percentage point or more to about 2 percent. ''I do agree that the political culture has probably changed,'' said Alan Greenspan, who was President Ford's chief economic adviser. The Senate's tax-revision bill, like the Gramm-Rudman law, shows the change. ''Twenty years ago you couldn't have gotten two votes for that,'' he said. ''The deficit will decline to a point where it has minor economic implications.'' ''We are headed for 2 percent of G.N.P., or $100 billion, from 5 percent,'' said John H. Palmer, senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a policy research organization. ''We're on track with that without any additional action by Congress. We're there without any further cuts in domestic spending or with any tax increases. We don't need Gramm-Rudman to get us there. Gramm-Rudman just gets us from 2 percent to zero.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=SHRINKAGE+OF+DEFICIT+AWAITED&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1986-06-23&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=PETER+T.+KILBORN%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The decline in the Federal budget deficit, a trend that the Reagan Administration, Congress and private economists saw in the cards for this year, has not shown up. It should, they say - maybe in a month or two, maybe next year - but so far expectations are running ahead of the evidence.
Such authorities still say that the deficit has been tamed for now, that in relation to the growing economy it is already falling and that its apparent damage, in high interest rates and the strong dollar, is abating.
But they also say that the actual deficit figures will start shrinking later and possibly more slowly than they thought. The main reason is that the economy is proving weaker, with less inflation and higher military spending, than they had predicted.
Early this year the President's Office of Management and Budget and the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office arrived at similar deficits for the fiscal year 1986, which will end Sept. 30. The C.B.O. said it would be $208 billion, and the O.M.B. said $206 billion - both smaller than the record $212 billion of fiscal 1985. New Budget-Balancing Law
Both also predicted deficits of $181 billion next year and $104 billion five years from now. They arrived at these even without taking account of the cuts required in 1987 and beyond by the new Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to drive the deficit to $144 billion next year and to zero by 1991.
The agencies have yet to produce new computations, but other numbers point up, not down. Through April of the fiscal year 1986, the Treasury's monthly reports of spending and tax receipts show a deficit of $126 billion, compared with a deficit a year earlier of $119 billion. If the accounts continue at that pace through September, this year's deficit would be $216 billion, or $4 billion bigger than last year's.
Extrapolating figures of such magnitude is risky. By year-end some economists expect them to show a larger deficit; some do not. John H. Makin, a political economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington, says the deficit will be $220 billion this year and, without any Gramm-Rudman cuts, $190 billion next year. Outlook as Seen by Kaufman
Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. and one of Wall Street's best-known foes of big deficits, sees a figure of $210 billion for 1986. For next year, he predicts $175 billion to $185 billion. ''But that's hardly an accomplishment,'' he said. ''It's still an extraordinary amount.'' Most projections exceed the earlier ones because the economy has taken some curious turns. One was the 50 percent plunge in oil prices, which has helped bring this year's inflation rate down a full percentage point or more to about 2 percent.
Most people welcome lower inflation. It means they pay less than they otherwise would for much of what they buy. But it also means that businesses and individuals get lower profits and wages than they otherwise would. That, in turn, means that the Government's tax collections are less than they would have been had inflation remained above 3 percent.
Falling oil prices have fattened the deficit in another way. They put the relatively small part of the economy that benefits from higher oil prices -the energy industry and areas that depend upon it - on the ropes. Shrinkage of Tax Revenues
Bankrupt oil drillers, unemployed roughnecks and owners of empty office buildings in Dallas and Houston do not produce much taxable income.
Then there is the rest of the economy. Falling interest rates are supposed to give it a kick, but so far only the residential real estate business has taken advantage of them. Cheaper oil is supposed to help most businesses and consumers, and the cheaper dollar is supposed to help farms and industries that compete with foreigners. The help, however, has been slow in coming.
The economy grew at an annual rate of only 1.8 percent from October through March, about half what forecasters had expected, slowing the Government's tax revenues.
Another reason for the fatter deficit is military spending, which is mostly responsible for pushing all Federal outlays about 4 percent above last year's pace - even though the military budget has stabilized.
But the actual flow of the spending, with much of it authorized long before the Pentagon actually starts sending money to its suppliers, is hard to gauge ahead of time. And during the first half of the current fiscal year, it has run beyond analysts' projections. Fast Deficit Growth Ended
But economists and Government officials remain confident on their main point: Rapid deficit growth in the Reagan years, starting at $79 billion in 1981, has been arrested.
As recently as a year ago, the Congressional Budget Office and others were projecting deficits rising to $300 billion and beyond. But not now. ''Three hundred billion?'' said Mr. Makin. ''That's history. Congress has already done dramatic cutting in the non-defense area, and now they're starting in on defense.''
It is tough to find a member of Congress who says he is not committed to driving the deficits down, even if the Supreme Court, as widely expected, jettisons the mechanism in the balanced-budget law that forces $36 billion annual cuts in the deficits.
Congress might stop short of pushing the deficit anywhere close to zero, but it seems to want a substantial reduction. ''My view is, there must still be tough action to see that the downward path continues,'' said Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat from Philadelphia and chairman of the House Budget Committee. Change in Political Culture
''I do agree that the political culture has probably changed,'' said Alan Greenspan, who was President Ford's chief economic adviser. The Senate's tax-revision bill, like the Gramm-Rudman law, shows the change. ''Twenty years ago you couldn't have gotten two votes for that,'' he said. ''The deficit will decline to a point where it has minor economic implications.''
By the measure that many economists consider more significant than monetary figures, deficit spending is already declining. It has dropped from a Reagan-era peak (in 1983) of 6.3 percent of the overall economy, or the gross national product, to 5.3 percent last year and 5 percent now.
Legislation already on the books points to still lower percentages if the economy avoids a severe recession in the rest of the decade and if Congress holds military spending growth to the inflation rate or slightly above.
''We are headed for 2 percent of G.N.P., or $100 billion, from 5 percent,'' said John H. Palmer, senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a policy research organization. ''We're on track with that without any additional action by Congress. We're there without any further cuts in domestic spending or with any tax increases. We don't need Gramm-Rudman to get us there. Gramm-Rudman just gets us from 2 percent to zero.''

U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT SLOW 1.7% RATE IN SECOND QUARTER

Author: PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]19 July 1985: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425467757?accountid=11752

Abstract: The Federal Reserve's policy changes, in the face of the stalemate in Congress over the budget deficits, also carry risks of higher inflation and another recession. ''It's a difficult thing to pull off,'' Mr. [Stephen S. Roach] said. ''This was the slowest rate of nonfarm inventory investment in two years,'' said Joseph Carson, an economist at Merrill Lynch Economics. ''It points to some modest pickup in production in the third quarter.'' Other figures in the report that cheered economists were those for inflation. One gauge, the implicit price deflator, showed only 2.8 percent inflation in the quarter and another, the fixed-weighted price index, showed 3.8 percent. Both marked declines from the first-quarter rates. Among other things, he said that lower interest rates should stimulate new-home construction and automobile sales. ''Lower interest rates,'' he added, ''augur well for all interest-sensitive industries.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=U.S.+ECONOMY+GREW+AT+SLOW+1.7%25+RATE+IN+SECOND+QUARTER&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-07-19&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=PETER+T.+KILBORN%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of only 1.7 percent in the spring, the Commerce Department said today.
The April-to-June rate of gain for the gross national product, the country's total outpouring of goods and services, was much slower than the Government first estimated last month, but the figure did not surprise many.
The earlier ''flash'' estimate of 3.1 percent second-quarter growth was based on incomplete figures for April and May and none at all for June. As more figures for such areas as consumer spending, housing, investment and trade have been reported, analysts suspected that the overall G.N.P. growth rate would prove slower than the initial estimate.
Lackluster Behavior

Another important report today, showing growth of only one-tenth of 1 percent in industrial production in June, following a similar figure for May, was further evidence of the economy's lackluster behavior. [Page D2.] The new 1.7 percent G.N.P. figure, coming on top of a mere three-tenths of 1 percent rate in the first quarter, meant that, over the first six months, the economy grew at a rate of only 1 percent. Such a pace has proved too weak to produce declines in an unemployment rate that has been locked at 7.2 percent since February.
Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted a moderately strong second-half rate of expansion of roughly 4 percent, but some other analysts were less optimistic, chiefly because of the large share of American markets imports have claimed. John M. Albertine, an economist and business lobbyist, foresaw at best ''less mediocre'' statistics for the rest of the year.
New Difficulties on Deficits

The slow growth of the first half and the possibility of little acceleration for the balance of the year suggest little reduction in unemployment and new difficulties for Congress and the Administration in their now-stalemated efforts to reduce the Federal budget deficits.
Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment firm, said that the lower tax collections of an economy growing at half the 4 percent rate the Administration originally predicted for this year could add $20 billion to $30 billion to the current fiscal year's expected deficit of well over $200 billion.
The report also provided new ammunition for members of Congress who have been pressing the Administration to adopt tough restraints on imported goods, particularly from Japan and other Far Eastern countries that export freely but restrict sales of imported goods in their own markets.
''The United States Government is sitting and watching as this country's manufacturing capacity is being dismantled brick by brick,'' said Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, author of a bill to impose a 25 percent import surcharge on such countries.
The report on the G.N.P., the Government's most comprehensive gauge of economic performance, comes at a moment when analysts suspect that the country appears to be sliding through the shoals of an important transition.
Partly as a result of an easier credit policy by the Federal Reserve Board to deal with the nation's trade deficit and the recession in manufacturing, they say, the dollar has fallen 15 to 20 percent from the peak it reached in February, and interest rates, which have been unusually high for five years, have dropped. Mr. Baldrige said that the dollar would have to fall 20 percent to 25 percent more before domestic manufacturers would be competitive again.
'Difficult Thing to Pull Off'

But the Federal Reserve's policy changes, in the face of the stalemate in Congress over the budget deficits, also carry risks of higher inflation and another recession. ''It's a difficult thing to pull off,'' Mr. Roach said.
The Commerce Department attributed the second quarter's small speedup in G.N.P. growth to a revival of business investment, continuing strong spending by consumers, a smaller rise in the trade deficit than in the first quarter and to Government spending, expecially by the military. Business investment, the strongest contributor, grew $6.9 billion in the second quarter after declining $800 million in the first. Investment in new housing, driven partly by declining interest rates, increased $2 billion after rising $800 million.
A significant drag on the economy during the second quarter could prove the silver lining of the third and fourth. Business's inventories of unsold goods and production materials rose only $5.8 billion in the second quarter after rising $35.9 billion in the previous two quarters. The sharp decline meant that business was expecting slower growth and adjusted its inventories accordingly, but now that they are low, economists assume that companies will have to start replenishing them.
''This was the slowest rate of nonfarm inventory investment in two years,'' said Joseph Carson, an economist at Merrill Lynch Economics. ''It points to some modest pickup in production in the third quarter.'' Other figures in the report that cheered economists were those for inflation. One gauge, the implicit price deflator, showed only 2.8 percent inflation in the quarter and another, the fixed-weighted price index, showed 3.8 percent. Both marked declines from the first-quarter rates.
View on Balance of Year

Discussing what to expect in growth for the balance of the year, Mr. Baldrige expanded on his view that, because of the lackluster first half, the Administration would not realize its expected 4 percent growth for the full year but might for the second half.
Among other things, he said that lower interest rates should stimulate new-home construction and automobile sales. ''Lower interest rates,'' he added, ''augur well for all interest-sensitive industries.''
The Federal Reserve also expects relatively strong growth for the balance of the year, of close to 4 percent, but some private economists see rates closer to 2 percent to 3 percent.
The Commerce Department also reported that word of the 1.7 percent G.N.P. figure leaked to the financial community early Wednesday afternoon. The department has asked its inspector general's office to track down the leak, and Mr. Baldrige said the department had some strong leads.
The department, which has not experienced such a leak in more than a year, said that, if any Government employees were involved, they would be subject to a $10,000 fine and a year in jail. The department tries to avoid such leaks because they can influence trading in the markets. In this case, however, Mr. Baldrige said he doubted that the leak had such an effect.

SENATE VOTE URGES BACKING ARMS PACT

Author: STEVEN V. ROBERTS, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 June 1985: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425444330?accountid=11752

Abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, hailed the resolution on the treaty as a ''major victory for the forces of arms control.'' Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, added that the statement reflected a consensus in the Senate that the United States ''should do everything we can to restrain ourselves and for the Soviet Union to do likewise.'' ''I think the Senate ought to go ahead and be heard,'' said Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee. ''It makes a lot more sense to vote first.'' Some conservatives were less than enthusiastic, and Senator Pete Wilson, Republican of California, called the resolution ''mealy mouthed.'' But he said he would vote for it. The key provision states: ''The United States should, through Dec. 31, 1986, continue to refrain from undercutting the provisions of existing strategic offensive arms agreements to the extent that the Soviet Union refrains from undercutting those provisions, or until a new strategic offensive arms agreement is concluded; and provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the U.S. from carrying out other proportionate responses to Soviet undercutting or strategic arms provisions.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=SENATE+VOTE+URGES+BACKING+ARMS+PACT&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-06-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=STEVEN+V.+ROBERTS%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Senate overwhelmingly adopted tonight a compromise resolution urging President Reagan to continue to adhere to the second strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union. But the statement also seems to give approval to a measured move by the Administration to respond to any Soviet violations of the treaty.
By a vote of 90 to 5, the resolution was attached to legislation covering programs for the Pentagon costing up to $232 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The entire bill, which would limit the increase in military spending to the inflation rate, was then approved, 92 to 3.
The military bill that is to go to floor of the House next week is even tighter, providing for no increase to account for inflation.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, hailed the resolution on the treaty as a ''major victory for the forces of arms control.'' Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, added that the statement reflected a consensus in the Senate that the United States ''should do everything we can to restrain ourselves and for the Soviet Union to do likewise.''
Approval of the resolution came as the Administration tried to set forth an updated policy toward the treaty, which was concluded with the Soviet Union in 1979 and expires at the end of this year. Although the pact was never ratified, each side has informally agreed to abide by its provisions if the other side does.
At a meeting in Portugal, Western European leaders told Secretary of State George P. Shultz that they would oppose any effort by the Administration to abandon the treaty.
Republican leaders and Administration officials had tried to stave off any expression of senatorial opinion until after Mr. Reagan announced his policy decision on the pact, which he is to do next Monday. But Democrats argued strenuously that the lawmakers should try to influence the Administration's decision.
''I think the Senate ought to go ahead and be heard,'' said Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee. ''It makes a lot more sense to vote first.''
The resolution has no force of law, but according to Mr. Nunn it reflects ''continuing skepticism'' on Capitol Hill about the Administration's intentions toward arms control. Similar feelings helped convince the Senate last month to vote to limit MX missile deployment to 50 weapons, half the number requested by the President.
Phrase for Conservatives

In order to satisfy conservatives, who argued for renunication of the treaty, the compromise resolution states that the Administration could carry out ''proportionate responses'' to any Soviet violations of the pact. Senator Nunn said tonight that the phrase remained undefined, but it clearly implied Senate approval for something less than strict adherence to the pact.
Senator James A. McClure, Republican of Idaho, said he supported the resolution because the ''proportionate response'' phrase gave the Administration greater flexibility in responding to Soviet violations.
''There are shades of seriousness to violations,'' he said, adding that not all of them should be answered by abrogating the entire treaty.
Some conservatives were less than enthusiastic, and Senator Pete Wilson, Republican of California, called the resolution ''mealy mouthed.'' But he said he would vote for it. The key provision states: ''The United States should, through Dec. 31, 1986, continue to refrain from undercutting the provisions of existing strategic offensive arms agreements to the extent that the Soviet Union refrains from undercutting those provisions, or until a new strategic offensive arms agreement is concluded; and provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the U.S. from carrying out other proportionate responses to Soviet undercutting or strategic arms provisions.''
The resolution also states that before the Administration decides to abrogate the treaty or alter its compliance, it should ''carefully consider'' the impact on existing arms agreements and American security interests, and should consult with Congress.
The policy review now under way in the White House has been brought on by two factors. One is a provision in the treaty that limits each side to deployment of 1,200 missiles carrying multiple warheads. The United States would exceed that limit this fall when a new Trident submarine, the Alaska, begins sea trials armed with 24 missiles.
If the Administration decides to adhere to the treaty, it could stay under the limit by dismantling a Poseidon submarine, which carries 16 missiles. Another option would be to remove 14 Minuteman missiles from their land bases beneath the Western plains.
The other factor causing the Administration's review is the treaty's expiration at the end of the year.
Soviet Violations Charged

In arguing for continued adherence to the treaty, Senator Bumpers said the Soviet Union had clearly violated several provisions of the pact. But he said Moscow would be far more restricted by the 1,200-missile limit than would Washington.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff have indicated they favor continued adherence to the treaty, on the ground that the pact restrains the Soviet Union more than it restrains the United States.
According to Administration officials, the probable result of the debate will be a decision to adhere to the pact, but with some modifications. For instance, instead of dismantling a Poseidon submarine and destroying its missiles to stay under the limit, the President might simply take the ship out of active service.
The resolution was the final obstacle blocking passage of the military bill, which continues or establishes most of the programs allotted to the Pentagon under the $302 billion Senate-passed budget. The rest of the programs would be authorized by other bills. Later in the year, Congress is to consider legislation to provide the funds.
Mr. Reagan originally requested a military spending increase of 6 percent on top of a rise to make up for inflation.
In addition to the provision limiting MX deployment to 50 missiles, the Senate bill would also permit testing of antisatellite weapons, call for a new generation of chemical weapons and make it harder for Government employees to parlay their positions into jobs with military contractors.

MILITARY RECEIVED $18 BILLION EXTRA, ASPIN CALCULATES

Author: CHARLES MOHR, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]20 May 1985: A.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425398035?accountid=11752

Abstract: In a speech prepared for delivery on the House floor Monday and made public today, Mr. [Les Aspin] described the funds as an ''unplanned'' and ''secret'' dividend for the Pentagon. Mr. [Caspar W. Weinberger] used somewhat different phrasing in an appearance on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' when asked about the issue of such surplus funds. ''We give it back and ask that it be applied to next year,'' he said. For developing and buying weapons and equipment, the Reagan Administration has applied a special inflation prediction which is 30 percent higher than the general prediction used for the rest of the Government. This factor is meant to reflect historically high costs for weapons. Seen Using Presidential budget statistics, Mr. Aspin said, ''The Administration has consistently overestimated inflation by a substantial amount, averaging about 1.7 percentage points a year.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=MILITARY+RECEIVED+%2418+BILLION+EXTRA%2C+ASPIN+CALCULATES&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-05-20&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=CHARLES+MOHR%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Because the Reagan Administration overestimated inflation, Congress appropriated $18 billion to $50 billion more than needed for Defense Department programs in the last four years, according to Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
In a speech prepared for delivery on the House floor Monday and made public today, Mr. Aspin described the funds as an ''unplanned'' and ''secret'' dividend for the Pentagon.
The Wisconsin Democrat said he did not suggest wrongdoing on the part of the Defense Department. In a letter, Mr. Aspin did ask Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger to cooperate in seeking ''a more rational and fair system'' to deal with the situation.
Taft Sees 'Achievement'

William H. Taft 4th, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, said in a written statement today that Mr. Aspin was correct in saying that billions of dollars were involved. But in it he said the Pentagon had made a ''remarkable achievement'' in spending less money than expected, which he attributed to better management and to Administration success in controlling inflation.
Mr. Aspin said Congress did not have enough information to calculate precisely the extra money that the Pentagon had received because of faulty inflation predictions. However, he used Pentagon statistics to argue that for the portion of annual military budgets devoted to such items as operations, maintenance and military construction, $18.2 billion had been appropriated to meet inflation levels that did not materialize.
A Subject for Debate

He took this figure as his minimum estimate. He said inflation had also been overestimated for such functions as buying weapons and paying for fuel and that the total surplus might be $50 billion.
The largely unnoticed inflation cushion will probably be an issue when the full House debates its budget resolution. The House Budget Committee voted last week to hold the military budget for the fiscal year 1986 to the same level as this year, with no allowance for inflation. Administration officials asserted that this was irresponsible and damaging to national security. The Senate's budget resolution permits military spending to rise by the Administration's estimate of inflation.
Mr. Taft's statement said, ''We have already returned to the taxpayer billions of dollars we have not spent.''
Mr. Weinberger used somewhat different phrasing in an appearance on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' when asked about the issue of such surplus funds. ''We give it back and ask that it be applied to next year,'' he said.
A staff member from the House Armed Services Committee, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said that, in fact, very little unspent money is returned to the Treasury, but in some cases Congress is made aware of some of the inflation overestimates and is then able to reduce future military appropriations accordingly.
He said this amounted to ''only a fraction'' of the total money involved. He estimated that the total surplus from lower inflation reported to Congress annually varied from $1 billion to $2 billion, a figure much lower than those put forth by Representative Aspin.
Several members of the Senate Armed Services Committee expressed anger last week when Mr. Weinberger, in an attempt to stave off reductions in or elimination of any major weapon-buying programs, reported that the Pentagon had found $1.7 billion in inflation-caused surpluses in the current fiscal year and $3.5 billion in unspent contingency funds and other categories. The senators, including some backers of high military spending, said Mr. Weinberger had damaged his credibility, if only by the timing of his discloRepresentative Aspin suggested that to make inflation predictions more accurate, each appropriation should be calculated on the inflation that occurred in the previous year.
In his speech, Representative Aspin noted that the Pentagon used four different inflation estimates each budget year, including operations, fuel and pay.
For developing and buying weapons and equipment, the Reagan Administration has applied a special inflation prediction which is 30 percent higher than the general prediction used for the rest of the Government. This factor is meant to reflect historically high costs for weapons. Seen Using Presidential budget statistics, Mr. Aspin said, ''The Administration has consistently overestimated inflation by a substantial amount, averaging about 1.7 percentage points a year.''
Moreover, he said, some of the increase in weapon costs was a result of inflation but some was from other factors, such as inefficient production rates and design changes that prevented military industry workers from learning how to cheaply build equipment stable in design. If all or almost all of the cost increase since 1982 is unrelated to inflation, Mr. Aspin said, then ''we have appropriated an unnecessary $30 billion for major weapons.''

REAGAN PRAISES BUDGET PROPOSAL; LIMIT ON BENEFITS IS ASSAILED

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Apr 1985: 1.6.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425397395?accountid=11752

Abstract: Christopher Matthews, a spokesman for Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, said the Mr. [Reagan]'s agreement ''is is the second time that President Reagan has tried to wriggle out of his 1980 campign promise,'' He was referring to Mr. Reagan's short-lived proposal in 1981 to reduce benefits. ''Democrats are going to keep him honest,'' he said. Mr. Reagan said the compromise faced stiff opposition in the Republican- controlled Senate. ''We all agree it is going to be a fight,'' he said. ''We are very optimistic and hopeful and think we have a very good plan.'' Alan K. Simpson, the Senate Republican whip, who was among the negotiators of the compromise, said, ''We have in effect alienated everyone in the United States with this budget. I don't predict where we will go when we get on the floor of the United States Senate and go through the painful votes that will come as people amend their favorite, magnificent projects back in - or try to.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=REAGAN+PRAISES+BUDGET+PROPOSAL%3B+LIMIT+ON+BENEFITS+IS+ASSAILED&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-04-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.6&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: President Reagan said today that he thought the budget compromise reached by White House negotiators and Senate Republican leaders was ''a very good plan'' for reducing the deficit. But he was immediately attacked for his agreement to limit the cost-of-living increase for Social Security for three years.
The compromise, reached Thursday after two weeks of negotiations, would reduce spending by $52 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and nearly $300 billion over three years. It would cut the projected 1986 deficit to $175 billion from $227 billion.
Mr. Reagan, in comments as he left the White House for a vacation in California, said the proposal's 3 percent increase in the military budget, on top of an increase to make up for inflation, was the least he would accept. He argued that such an increase would not harm national security.
And he defended his agreement to limit Social Security cost-of-living increases, saying that any Democrats who used the issue in next year's campaigning would ''be lying in their teeth as they did in 1982.''
Attack at News Conference

Mr. Reagan was attacked on the issue in an afternoon news conference held by seven groups representing the elderly. Speakers said he had broken what they described as a pledge in the 1984 campign not to touch Social Security benefits.
White House officials argued that Mr. Reagan had not pledged to protect cost-of-living increases, but rather basic benefits. They said the compromise proposal was acceptable to Mr. Reagan because it guaranteed a 2 percent cost-of-living increase for three years regardless of the rate of inflation, rather than eliminating the increase for one year, as the Senate Budget Committee had proposed.
David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said Mr. Reagan would have preferred not to touch Social Security. ''But that became necessary to glue the package together and a fair way was found to compromise it,'' he said.
Major Concession on Military

The President originally requested a 6 percent increase in the military budget on top of an increase to make up for inflation. The agreement to accept the 3 percent increase, which is likely to be reduced further in Congress, is a major concession. Some Senate negotiators said it reflected Mr. Reagan's willingness to compromise when he decided the time was right.
In December he disappointed some of his staff and angered some Republicans by agreeing to not much more than cosmetic cuts in his proposed military budget.
But White House officals acknowledged that Mr. Reagan had to face the fact that the Senate Budget Committee, in the budget proposal it approved last month, provided no increase in the military budget beyond one to make up for inflation. Republicans in the Senate had argued that if the President did not compromise he faced even larger military budget cuts.
Limits on Social Security

On Social Security, the compromise plan limits the cost-of-living increase to 2 percent for 1986, 1987 and 1988, unless inflation exceeded 4 percent. Then the cost-of-living increase would be the rate of inflation minus two percentage points.
The White House described this agreement as a compromise that would provide larger benefit payments than the Senate Budget Committee's proposal to eliminate the cost-of-living increase for one year. But the compromise proposal limits cost-of-living increases for three years, while under the Budget Committee plan there would have been full increases for inflation after the one year freeze.
Over three years the compromise plan is expected to produce savings of $22.6 billion, slightly more than the $22.4 billion projected under the proposal the Senate Budget Committee approved. And in later years the saving is even greater.
Pepper Assails President

At the news conference of associations representing the elderly, Representative Claude Pepper, a Florida Democrat who is a chief spokesman for the elderly in Congress, said, ''I am shocked the President of the United States would repudiate a solid commitment he made to the elderly.''
The reference is to comments made both in the 1980 campaign and the 1984 campaign, which have been interpreted as pledges not to touch Social Security benefits.
Christopher Matthews, a spokesman for Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, said the Mr. Reagan's agreement ''is is the second time that President Reagan has tried to wriggle out of his 1980 campign promise,'' He was referring to Mr. Reagan's short-lived proposal in 1981 to reduce benefits. ''Democrats are going to keep him honest,'' he said.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, opposed the cut in a letter to his colleagues. He said it would cost the average recipient a total of $1,300 in benefits by 1990.
Plan Includes No Tax Increases

The compromise budget plan includes no tax increases but does provide for new and increased fees, including new charges to commerical mariners and receational boaters for some Coast Guard services, fees for Government-sponsored credit agencies which borrow through the Treasury, and increased fees for Federal recreational facilities.
The proposal does not set specific fee increases; it estimates, however, that the changes would raise an additional $750 million in 1986.
Mr. Reagan said the compromise faced stiff opposition in the Republican- controlled Senate. ''We all agree it is going to be a fight,'' he said. ''We are very optimistic and hopeful and think we have a very good plan.''
Alan K. Simpson, the Senate Republican whip, who was among the negotiators of the compromise, said, ''We have in effect alienated everyone in the United States with this budget. I don't predict where we will go when we get on the floor of the United States Senate and go through the painful votes that will come as people amend their favorite, magnificent projects back in - or try to.''

CREDIT MARKETSNote and Bond Prices Rise

Author: Quint, Michael

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 Jan 1985: D.16.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425287939?accountid=11752

Abstract: Joseph Bench, a vice president at Shearson Lehman/American Express, said, ''We are seeing quite a bit of maturity extension by individuals, and some of the big players are reluctantly moving in the same direction.'' Elliot Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said in a recent publication that his forecast for declines in long-term bond yields by year-end ''rests on our perception that inflation will remain moderate and that investors' inflation expectations will continue to fall.'' Even though huge Federal budget deficits will prevent too steep a drop in long-term bond yields, Mr. Platt noted that recent yields of around 11 1/2 percent for Treasury bonds are ''inordinately high'' compared to expectations of inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CREDIT+MARKETSNote+and+Bond+Prices+Rise&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1985-01-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.16&amp;au=Quint%2C+Michael&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Increasing confidence that inflation will remain low and the willingness of some investors to shift funds out of low-yielding short-term securities led to a modest rise in Treasury note and bond prices yesterday.
Although investor buying was well short of a stampede, and many potential buyers are still worried about an upturn in rates later this year, Government securities dealers said there was a modest amount of buying yesterday by small and large investors. By late in the day, the 11 3/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2014 were offered at 103 21/32, up 10/32, to yield 11.31 percent. As recently as Jan. 4, the bellwether Treasury bond was offered at 100 1/2 to yield 11.68 percent.
The latest sign that inflation remains subdued was the two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the December Consumer Price Index announced by the Commerce Department yesterday. The closely watched Consumer Price Index rose 4 percent during 1984, and many economists expect that falling oil prices and a strong dollar in foreign exchange markets could prevent inflation from accelerating this year.
The eagerness of some investors to shift funds out of short-term securities yielding 8 percent or less into longer maturities was evident at the Treasury's regular monthly auction of two-year notes. Although the average yield on the 9 3/4 percent notes fell to 9.83 percent from 9.92 percent in December and 10.47 percent in November, the issue still attracted nearly $26.8 billion of bids, up from $22.7 billion at last month's sale.
Joseph Bench, a vice president at Shearson Lehman/American Express, said, ''We are seeing quite a bit of maturity extension by individuals, and some of the big players are reluctantly moving in the same direction.''
Longer Term Securities

Longer-term securities are subject to greater price volatility than short- term issues due in less than a year, but many analysts noted that investors are being compensated with note and bond yields that are unusually generous compared with short-term issues. For example, at a discount rate of 7.64 percent, the bond equivalent yield on three-month Treasury bills is about 7.9 percent, or roughly 3 1/2 percentage points less than 30- year Tresuary bond yields and more than 1.6 percentage points less than the yield on four-year Treasury notes.
According to R. A. Froehlich Arbitrage, a Mount Kisco, N.Y., firm, the spread between three-month bills and 30-year bonds is the widest it has been since late May 1984, when Treasury bond yields touched 14 percent. As recently as September, the bond yield was only about 1.4 percentage points greater than the three-month bill yield.
On the inflation front, market participants are well aware that prices have not increased as fast during the economic expansion as was feared. But they note that bond yields and inflation do not move in lock step, and it is difficult to predict when and how expectations of lower inflation become powerful enough to bring down bond yields.
Elliot Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said in a recent publication that his forecast for declines in long-term bond yields by year-end ''rests on our perception that inflation will remain moderate and that investors' inflation expectations will continue to fall.''
Even though huge Federal budget deficits will prevent too steep a drop in long-term bond yields, Mr. Platt noted that recent yields of around 11 1/2 percent for Treasury bonds are ''inordinately high'' compared to expectations of inflation.
Although there are no indications that the Federal Reserve is encouraging lower short-term interest rates, the short-term markets were liquid enough yesterday for short-term rates to fall slightly. Three-month Treasury bills, for example, fell to 7.64 percent from an average of 7.68 percent at yesterday's auction.
Overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market fluctuated around 8 3/8 percent, or slightly higher than the 8 1/4 percent average for the two weeks ended Jan. 16.
In the tax-exempt market, this week's new issues have been well received, even as underwriters raised prices enough to reduce yields by as much as 20 basis points from the levels set early Tuesday.
Following are results of yesterday's auction of new two-year Treasury notes:

WARNING ISSUED BY I.M.F. ON THE DOLLAR

Author: Special to The New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Sep 1984: D.16.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/425189156?accountid=11752

Abstract: The record level to which the dollar has risen is ''unsustainable'' and potentially ''detrimental'' to the United States and the rest of the world, the International Monetary Fund said today in its annual report. The I.M.F. also noted that, largely following patterns set by the United States, the average of short-term interest rates in the major industrial countries rose to 9 3/4 percent in the first half of 1984. The rates had fallen to 9 1/4 percent in the first half of 1983, from a peak of some 15 percent during 1981. ''The recent rise in interest rates,'' the report said, ''has been strongest and most persistent in the United States, where both short-term and long-term yields in the spring of 1984 reached levels roughly two percentage points higher than in the early months of 1983.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WARNING+ISSUED+BY+I.M.F.+ON+THE+DOLLAR&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1984-09-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.16&amp;au=Special+to+The+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The record level to which the dollar has risen is ''unsustainable'' and potentially ''detrimental'' to the United States and the rest of the world, the International Monetary Fund said today in its annual report.
The report appeared to presage another spirited debate about the dollar and Washington's policies when the fund's 147 member countries meet here later this month. The joint annual meeting of the fund and the World Bank starts Sept. 24.
The report also repeated earlier I.M.F. criticism of the large United States budget deficit, but went a step further by warning of some of the perils of the high dollar.
The 203-page report noted that at around midyear, when the study was being drafted, the dollar had risen to about 15 percent above its average value for the period 1973 to 1982 in relation to the Japanese yen and the British pound. It was up 40 percent over the West German mark and nearly 50 percent over the French franc.
In recent days the dollar has reached record levels against the pound, the franc and the Italian lira and an 11 1/2-year high against the mark.
Impact of the Deficit
The I.M.F. document, whose key passages are negotiated by governments and represent a consensus of the membership, said the United States budget deficit, by intensifying competition for savings, contributes to high interest rates, which in turn increases the value of the dollar.
The Reagan Administration does not endorse this causal relationship. It argues that the dollar's popularity is spurred by low inflation, high growth of the American economy and profitability of American investments.
The report cited the dollar's strength as ''an important factor'' contributing to the deterioration in the American trade accounts - to an estimated $130 billion merchandise trade deficit this year.
The I.M.F. study said the trade deficit ''could have disquieting implications for the international allocation of world private saving,'' by drawing in savings to the United States from the rest of the world to finance the deficit.
Easing of Debt Crisis
At the same time, the international agency, which has more than $30 billion of short-term credits outstanding to more than 40 countries, said that the trade deficit had contributed to an easing of the world debt crisis. The huge American appetite for imports has spurred economic activity abroad and has especially helped many third world countries improve their cash position and pay their debts, the I.M.F. report notes.
The I.M.F. also noted that, largely following patterns set by the United States, the average of short-term interest rates in the major industrial countries rose to 9 3/4 percent in the first half of 1984. The rates had fallen to 9 1/4 percent in the first half of 1983, from a peak of some 15 percent during 1981. ''The recent rise in interest rates,'' the report said, ''has been strongest and most persistent in the United States, where both short-term and long-term yields in the spring of 1984 reached levels roughly two percentage points higher than in the early months of 1983.''
