BUSINESS FORUM; ECONOMICS FROM THE BIG BOARD; THE REASONS FOR OPTIMISM

Author: Freund, William C

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]27 Dec 1981: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424256386?accountid=11752

Abstract: In the years ahead, Government policies will no longer be viewed one-dimensionally. Taxes, transfer payments, expenditures, deficits, regulations and the like will be reviewed not only for their immediate effects, but also for their implications for productivity, economic growth and inflation. Painfully, we have rediscovered the old economic lesson: ''There is no such thing as a free lunch.'' We now know that the competitiveness of United States industry is intimately linked to Government policies. Our labor force is becoming more experienced and productive. The 1970's saw millions of young people (the baby-boom generation) join the United States work force. Because of their inexperience, these young people were not very productive. But now they're older - in the 25- to 35-year-old range - and they are becoming increasingly skilled and productive. Indeed, with fewer young people coming into the labor force in the 1980's, business will have an added incentive to substitute capital for routine unskilled operations. That, too, will improve economic performance in the 1980's. There is never certainty about the future. Inflationary forces could gain renewed momentum. But let us recognize also that after the current economic storm, chances are good that the 1980's will enjoy higher productivity growth, more real economic growth, greater per capita spendable income and less inflation than in the 1970's. This improved economic climate will help create an environment in which relations between the Government and the private sector and between business and labor are likely to be better. The economic optimists may prove to be right after all. --------------------------------------------------------------------- William C. Freund is chief economist at the New York Stock Exchange and professor of economics at Pace University's Graduate School of Business.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BUSINESS+FORUM%3B+ECONOMICS+FROM+THE+BIG+BOARD%3B+THE+REASONS+FOR+OPTIMISM&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-12-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Freund%2C+William+C&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: T HE pessimists are having a field day. Supply-side economics will not be producing its promised miracles any time soon. Instead, the next few months will see more workers losing their jobs, business profits falling and the Federal deficit climbing - to a projected $100 billion this fiscal year and even more in fiscal 1983 and 1984.
Government forecasters were far too optimistic in predicting a quick upturn in economic growth that would bolster tax revenues. They correctly projected early reductions in Treasury revenues as a result of the tax cuts. Tax reductions depress revenues very quickly. Where the forecasters went wrong was in assuming that the package of tax cuts, slowed transfer payment growth, liberalized depreciation rules and eased Federal regulation would soon trigger a surge in economic growth and yield major revenue increases.
That expectation was naive. Changes in productivity trends are not easily brought about. It took years for harmful Federal policies to help drag our nation's annual productivity growth down from 3 to 2 to 1 percent per year, and finally pull it into negative numbers. Given this experience, one should not expect productivity growth to recover very quickly. Similarly, it took years for inflation to heat up to double-digit levels; obviously it will take time to bring it down to an acceptable level. In the face of disappointed expectations thus far, and the prospect of a not very lusty economic performance in 1982, the optimists have lost much of their credibility.
However, more important than what lies ahead over the next year is whether the economic climate will improve as the 1980's unfold. On that score there is reason for optimism. All forecasts and projections are uncertain. But I believe there is at least a betterthan-even chance that the next decade will be better than the last.
One of the most important reasons for optimism is the power of a new idea. For almost half a century - ever since the Great Depression - economic policy has been governed by the Keynesian prescription of maintaining high employment through Government spending and economic intervention, particularly through consumer demand stimulation. That theory may have been appropriate for the Great Depression, but in the inflationary climate of the 1970's, Keynesian policies proved counterproductive.
No wonder disillusionment with the thrust of economic policy grew and surfaced well before Ronald Reagan seized it as an election issue. In the late 1970's, both sides of the political aisle began talking of the need to encourage saving and investment to improve productivity and stimulate growth. The broad agreement on the subject is reflected in a series of unanimous reports of the Joint Economic Committee. And it was given tangible expression by the incorporation of sharpened investment incentives in the Tax Act of 1978.
There is always the chance that sound long-range economic policies will not survive immediate discontent. The political pendulum could swing back toward the discredited policies of the past. But a complete reversion to Keynesian policies and their stagflationary consequences is unlikely.
In the years ahead, Government policies will no longer be viewed one-dimensionally. Taxes, transfer payments, expenditures, deficits, regulations and the like will be reviewed not only for their immediate effects, but also for their implications for productivity, economic growth and inflation. Painfully, we have rediscovered the old economic lesson: ''There is no such thing as a free lunch.'' We now know that the competitiveness of United States industry is intimately linked to Government policies.
I N addition to Government policies more sensitive to economic performance, business managers themselves are becoming more aware of the need to actively pursue productivity growth. More attention is being given to R.& D. as the fountainhead of economic progress. Major scientific and technological advances lie ahead in genetic engineering, microprocessing, communications and robotics. Their movement from the laboratory to practical application holds promise for our economic future. It is encouraging, too, that our capital stock is gradually being replaced by more energy-efficient plants and equipment.
Executives are also looking for better ways to manage workers, our most important national resource. Programs to enhance the quality of work life and to involve workers in decisions affecting their work are beginning to pay off. Companies by the hundreds are setting up worker circles to allow employees at all levels of the company to work together in solving production problems, reducing grievances and improving product quality.
Our labor force is becoming more experienced and productive. The 1970's saw millions of young people (the baby-boom generation) join the United States work force. Because of their inexperience, these young people were not very productive. But now they're older - in the 25- to 35-year-old range - and they are becoming increasingly skilled and productive. Indeed, with fewer young people coming into the labor force in the 1980's, business will have an added incentive to substitute capital for routine unskilled operations. That, too, will improve economic performance in the 1980's.
But what about the $100 billion-plus Federal deficits projected for the next three fiscal years? Won't they upset the apple cart by crowding out private investments to satisfy the voracious Federal financial appetite?
During the current recession, with private financial demands depressed, little crowding out is likely. But there is an urgent need to reduce the Federal deficit, particularly once the recession ends. Chances are good, probably better than 50-50, that the danger of crowding out can be contained.
What is not well-known is that the large deficits projected for fiscal 1983 and 1984 are based on the assumption of a 5 percent rate of inflation. If that were to come about, inflation expectations would decline and interest rates would fall. Does anybody really think interest rates will be 20 percent with only 5 percent inflation?
Moreover, a low rate of inflation would encourage more savings domestically as well as a greater inflow of savings from abroad. If the assumed 5 percent rate of inflation is wrong, then the projected Federal deficit is too large. High incomes, even if inflation-induced, draw in larger tax revenues. At, say, 10 percent inflation, the deficits are likely to be considerably less than now projected.
There is never certainty about the future. Inflationary forces could gain renewed momentum. But let us recognize also that after the current economic storm, chances are good that the 1980's will enjoy higher productivity growth, more real economic growth, greater per capita spendable income and less inflation than in the 1970's. This improved economic climate will help create an environment in which relations between the Government and the private sector and between business and labor are likely to be better. The economic optimists may prove to be right after all. --------------------------------------------------------------------- William C. Freund is chief economist at the New York Stock Exchange and professor of economics at Pace University's Graduate School of Business.
Illustration bar graphs on U.S. G.N.P., prices and jobs in 1970's

CONSUMER PRICES UP BY SHARP 1.2% DURING SEPTEMBER

Author: JONATHAN FUERBRINGER, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 Oct 1981: 1.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424208595?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''I think it is somewhat of a glitch,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, of Chase Econometrics in Pennsylvania. ''I think you'll see smaller numbers for the rest of the year but still in the 9 percent range.'' Bond Reaction Feared ''It's disappointing,'' said Allen Sinai of Data Resources Inc. of Massachusetts. ''The increase was too broad-based to dismiss out of hand as an aberration. It's in enough categories to raise a red flag of concern. It looks like there is a pause in the downward movement in inflation.'' ''You shouldn't take the spring numbers as an indication of how low inflation is and, likewise, you shouldn't take higher numbers as an indication of what inflation is now,'' he said. ''The number is somewhere in between.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=CONSUMER+PRICES+UP+BY+SHARP+1.2%25+DURING+SEPTEMBER&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-10-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1.1&amp;au=JONATHAN+FUERBRINGER%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The Consumer Price Index, pushed up by increases in food, transportation, interest rates and medical care costs, surged 1.2 percent in September. At an annual rate, this comes to more than 14 percent.
The September increase in the nation's most widely followed measure of inflation meant that consumer prices have been rising at a double-digit annual rate since July, when the index also jumped 1.2 percent. It rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in August.
In the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, consumer prices rose 1.5 percent last month. (Page 30.) The latest figures, reported by the Labor Department today, continued the sharp turnaround from the good news of the second quarter, when the Consumer Price Index slipped below an annual rate of 8 percent. 10.1% Rate for Year So Far
Despite this reversal, the index for the year through September is running at an annual rate of 10.1 percent, significantly lower than the 12.1 percent posted in the corresponding 1980 period.
Some economists inside and outside the Reagan Administration generally agreed today that the Consumer Price Index numbers for the past three months did not mean that inflation was on the upswing again. They argued that the current recession would help hold the inflation rate down for the rest of the year and in 1982.
''It's not as bad as the numbers look,'' said Robert Ortner, the chief economist for the Commerce Department. ''With a softening economy, it should not be anticipated that this will continue.''
''I think it is somewhat of a glitch,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, of Chase Econometrics in Pennsylvania. ''I think you'll see smaller numbers for the rest of the year but still in the 9 percent range.'' Bond Reaction Feared
Despite the overall slowdown for the year, September's jump in the Consumer Price Index could hurt the Administration's effort to convince the bond market that inflation is moderating enough for interest rates to fall.
''The bond market will probably make it look worse than it is,'' Mr. Ortner said. The rise in the index in September was partly the result of another jump in mortgage interest rates, which rose 2.5 percentage points and are now in the 16-to-17-percent range. If this jump were the main reason for the rise, both in September and for the past three months, the figures might have been dismissed because of the distorting effect of interest and housing costs on the index.
But because the rise resulted from increases across the board, some econo-mists saw it as a reminder of how hard it might be to bring inflation down.
''September's C.P.I. emphasizes that inflation continues to be a serious problem,'' said Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, in a statement.
''It's disappointing,'' said Allen Sinai of Data Resources Inc. of Massachusetts. ''The increase was too broad-based to dismiss out of hand as an aberration. It's in enough categories to raise a red flag of concern. It looks like there is a pause in the downward movement in inflation.''
Consumer food costs, which had been keeping the index down in the spring and early summer, rose 1.2 percent in September and were up at an annual rate of 12.4 percent in the third quarter, following a 2.5 percent decline in the second quarter. Meat, poultry, fish, eggs, fresh fruits and vegetables all contributed to the increase.
Medical care costs continued their surge, rising nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, following rises of 1.3 percent in both July and August. Medical care costs have been rising at high rates for nine months.
Transportation costs jumped 1.2 percent in the month, the largest rise since last February. Half of this increase was in the cost of used cars, which rose 4 percent in September. New-car prices, even after accounting for rebate programs, were up six-tenths of 1 percent for the month.
The rise in school tuition and the cost of books pushed up the index for the month. Tuition fees gained 9.8 percent. Entertainment costs rose eight-tenth of 1 percent, led by a 2.8 percent jump in prices for magazines, periodicals and books.
Although interest rates and the Consumer Price Index's housing index -which treats housing costs as if purchases were made every month - continue to distort the index, an alternative experimental measure used by the Labor Department shows the impact of other factors on the index.
Using this experimental measure, which tries to treat housing costs as if they were equivalent to rent, the Consumer Price Index for September was up eight-tenths of 1 percent, lower than the official figure but still near double-digit rates for the year.
The economists who argued that the index would not rise as sharply toward the end of the year said they expected food prices to moderate because of the small food price increases reflected at the wholesale and farmer level. They also said declining interest rates should help bring the index down.
Charles Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration, agreed with other economists that the Consumer Price Index numbers for the last three months are overstating the rate of inflation.
''You shouldn't take the spring numbers as an indication of how low inflation is and, likewise, you shouldn't take higher numbers as an indication of what inflation is now,'' he said. ''The number is somewhere in between.''
Mr. Schultze and Mr. Sinai also agreed that it was not surprising that while the economy was going into a recession, the rate of inflation should pop up. ''Retail prices lag the downturn in the economy,'' Mr. Sinai said. ''There has to be significant downward pressure on wages before prices start coming down.''

ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; A RECESSION COULD PUT REAGAN IN A BOX

Author: Bergmann, Barbara

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]18 Oct 1981: A.3.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424217842?accountid=11752

Abstract: If the next recession strikes anytime soon, it will strike before inflation has been completely conquered. Unless the recession is short, a tug-of-war will develop between those policy advisers who favor continuing the fight on inflation at all costs, and those who want to stimulate a faster recovery by stimulating demand, even at the cost of a possible setback in the campaign against inflation. E VEN that would be opposed by a contingent of conservative economists of considerable stature who would quite literally welcome a severe recession. These people will counsel against any action to shorten the downturn or strengthen the recovery. They will advocate a do-nothing policy because they believe that suffering through a long period of high unemployment is the only way for the country to get free of the inflationary syndrome of the last 15 years. They would argue that the first two or three years of the President's term are an ideal time to put the economy through the wringer, setting the stage for the pre-election period as a happy era of recovery with price stability. Opposing them would be those who rate the human and economic losses caused by persistently high unemployment and low or negative profits as worse than the losses we might suffer if we relax the fight to get rid of inflation. Also opposing a do-nothing policy would be those who would worry that a really severe recession might develop if a mild one were not contained and those worried about political fallout.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=ECONOMIC+AFFAIRS%3B+A+RECESSION+COULD+PUT+REAGAN+IN+A+BOX&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-10-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Bergmann%2C+Barbara&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: W ITH the possibility of a recession seemingly on an increase, the President and his economic advisers need contingency plans. They may be faced with a situation in which nothing is growing in the economy except the deficit and the unemployment rate.
Recession is not, according to the main line forecasters, the most likely course for the economy in the near term. But even if recession is unlikely, serious thinking is needed now about what the best way would be for the monetary and fiscal authorities to respond to it, should it come.
The nature and size of the tax cut passed this year make a response to recession on the part of the Administration particularly problematic. Thus, it would be well to have some advance discussion of whether and when and how demand-side stimulus might be applied.
In the past, there was considerable agreement that appropriate responses to persistent recession included Federal tax cuts, rises in Federal spending, monetary policy allowing for very low interest rates, or some combination of those three. These remedies were believed to work on the demand side of the economy. At such times, it was obvious to almost everybody that demand was deficient, and could use some bolstering.
But those times are gone because the inflation problem persists. Inflation is widely interpreted as excessive demand somewhere in the economy. Even double-digit unemployment rates will no longer be universally accepted as a signal of deficient demand.
If the next recession strikes anytime soon, it will strike before inflation has been completely conquered. Unless the recession is short, a tug-of-war will develop between those policy advisers who favor continuing the fight on inflation at all costs, and those who want to stimulate a faster recovery by stimulating demand, even at the cost of a possible setback in the campaign against inflation.
A recession would, of course, increase the Federal deficit far beyond the present prospect of a deficit that could range from $40 billion to $65 billion. There would be a huge outflow of funds to finance unemployment insurance. The Social Security Trust Fund would have to pay for a great many early retirees, and the tax revenues that feed the Social Security funds would shrink as payrolls shrank. As private demand for credit ebbed, lower interest rates would reduce Treasury outflows to some degree, but this would probably not offset the tax and benefit effect completely.
One way to respond to the prospect of an increased deficit that recession would bring would be to try to cut government spending even further. The Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, seems to favor this type of response. The immediate effect would be to cut the demand for goods and services and make the recession deeper than it otherwise would be and the recovery slower.
It is hard to believe that the Administration's stomach will be strong enough for that severe and risky a policy, and David A. Stockman, the budget director, has signaled that he would not press in such a direction.
The practical choice will be between passively allowing the deficit to balloon or going even further and trying to apply a positive stimulus. If stimulus does seem the right course, the Administration is in something of a box.
Fiscal stimulus in the standard form of tax cuts for lower- and middle-income groups would seem to be precluded by the previously legislated tax cuts for business and upper-income groups. Yet tax cuts targeted toward the rich may turn out to provide only mild stimulus to consumer demand and, in a recession, even milder stimulus to the demand for fixed capital.
It is hard to see the Administration espousing new employmentgenerating spending programs. The only other option for the Administration would be to beseech the Fed to relax tight money so as to allow for a turnaround and to keep it relaxed so as to avoid aborting the subsequent recovery.
E VEN that would be opposed by a contingent of conservative economists of considerable stature who would quite literally welcome a severe recession. These people will counsel against any action to shorten the downturn or strengthen the recovery. They will advocate a do-nothing policy because they believe that suffering through a long period of high unemployment is the only way for the country to get free of the inflationary syndrome of the last 15 years. They would argue that the first two or three years of the President's term are an ideal time to put the economy through the wringer, setting the stage for the pre-election period as a happy era of recovery with price stability.
Opposing them would be those who rate the human and economic losses caused by persistently high unemployment and low or negative profits as worse than the losses we might suffer if we relax the fight to get rid of inflation. Also opposing a do-nothing policy would be those who would worry that a really severe recession might develop if a mild one were not contained and those worried about political fallout.
One piece of recent history that is pertinent to this issue is the resilience the economy displayed last year. There was a severe drop, but interest rates eased and the drop was short-lived. If the economy turned down again, that history of resilience would be brought forward as evidence that no stimulus was needed, because the economy could take care of itself. Stimulus would, in this view, only have the effect of making the recovery too energetic for purposes of the war on inflation.
However, the unemployment rate is already high by historical standards and it traditionally rises much faster than it falls. It has not yet recovered from the downturn in activity in 1980. Even a brief downturn in business activity starting now would guarantee a long period of unemployment rates above 8 percent, in the absence of demand-side stimulus.
It is not easy to be President in such times. Mr. Reagan might end up in the history books as the valiant slayer of the dragon of inflation, as a Margaret Thatcher look-alike, or even worse, as another Republican President who tolerated severe unemployment without action to fight it. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Barbara Bergmann is a professor of economics at the University of Maryland.

Economic Scene; The Pressure On the Fed

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]16 Sep 1981: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424195227?accountid=11752

Abstract: Earlier, Secretary [Donald T. Regan] had muzzled an inside critic of the Fed, Under Secretary of the Treasury Beryl Sprinkel, the Administration's top monetarist. But that was when Mr. Sprinkel had been publicly scolding the Fed for not being tight enough. Is Mr. Regan, with the backing of the Presi dent's chief economic adviser and presumably the President himself, now scolding the Fed for being too tight? Or are Mr. Regan and Mr. [Murray L. Weidenbaum] really running interference for the Fed, trying to s mooth down the financialmarkets lest they make it impossible for the Fed to get out of a box and get the Administration out of a jam? It was not just the untrained observer who saw an effort by the Administration to push the Fed toward easier money. The professional monetarists (some of whom are within the Administration's own bosom) are starting to pounce. Allan T. Meltzer, professor of economics at Carnegie-Mellon University and a leader of the monetarist Shadow Open Market Committee, said there was ''fear'' that the Administration would put pressure on the Fed to loosen up, contending that ''a little inflation won't hurt now.'' In fact, Mr. Meltzer said, this pressure by the Administration had already begun.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+The+Pressure+On+the+Fed&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-09-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: THE Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, and the chairman of the Council of Ecomomic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum, have both begun to suggest in their public orations that the Fed might make the money supply grow a bit faster, even if Wall Street takes fright.
Mr. Regan, as a former chairman of Merrill Lynch, clearly feels that he possesses the hard-earned right to show proper disrespect for the wisdom of Wall Street. He is complaining that the Street is so nervous it turns all news into bad news. If the money supply increased, the Street grew sick with fear over inflation; if the money supply fell, it trembled over a coming money crunch.
Mr. Weidenbaum was specific on what the Administration would like the Fed to do. A staunch champion of the independence of the Fed, Mr. Weidenbaum nevertheless told the Fed, in his address to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, that it really ought to step up the annual rate of growth of M-1B, the most closely watched measure of the money supply, to the lower half of its planned range for this year. That range was set at 3 1/2 to 6 percent.
M-1B has been below its band, although some other measures of the money supply, such as M-2, have been above theirs. No doubt Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Fed, would like to have all the money supply measures in their proper band waves, but the central bank seems not to have the remarkable skill of its outside critics in controlling the various measures of the money supply.
Earlier, Secretary Regan had muzzled an inside critic of the Fed, Under Secretary of the Treasury Beryl Sprinkel, the Administration's top monetarist. But that was when Mr. Sprinkel had been publicly scolding the Fed for not being tight enough. Is Mr. Regan, with the backing of the Presi dent's chief economic adviser and presumably the President himself, now scolding the Fed for being too tight? Or are Mr. Regan and Mr. Weidenbaum really running interference for the Fed, trying to s mooth down the financialmarkets lest they make it impossible for the Fed to get out of a box and get the Administration out of a jam?
Mr. Weidenbaum said that a resumption of growth to within the lower half of the range, that is, 3 1/2 to 4 3/4 percent, ''should not be viewed as alarming, even though individual month-to-month increases may appear at first blush to be excessive to the untrained observer.''
It was not just the untrained observer who saw an effort by the Administration to push the Fed toward easier money. The professional monetarists (some of whom are within the Administration's own bosom) are starting to pounce. Allan T. Meltzer, professor of economics at Carnegie-Mellon University and a leader of the monetarist Shadow Open Market Committee, said there was ''fear'' that the Administration would put pressure on the Fed to loosen up, contending that ''a little inflation won't hurt now.'' In fact, Mr. Meltzer said, this pressure by the Administration had already begun.
The pure monetarists want the Administration to hang tough, but the President and the pragamatists around him are not enthusiastic about a policy that is threatening them with serious losses in the 1982 Congressional elections - and threatening the economy with a steeper slump.
The worry of the pragmatists is that the Administration is caught, as its critics charge, between a fiscal policy that is too loose and a monetary policy that is too tight. The consequence has been the high interest rates that are not only depressing Wall Street but scaring the endangered thrift institutions, choking off housing, slowing the growth of the economy more than the Administration wants and threatening to produce greater imbalance in the budget for the fiscal year 1982 than the $42.5 billion deficit the President had forecast. It begins t o look impossible for the President to make that goal. His Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, has said that $50 billion would not be so bad. Even that goal will be impossible if thePresident sti cks to his two ''sacrosancts'' - the defense budget and the tax cuts.
The $2 billion defense budget cut for the fiscal year 1982 that was announced by the White House has been dismissed by most Wall Street analysts as minuscule. And Mr. Weidenbaum reacted with horror in his speech to the savings bankers to the suggestion of raising taxes again.
But unless a way is found to narrow the budget deficit - and economists outside the Administration are putting it at $60 billion to $80 billion in the fiscal year 1982 - the Government will increase its demands on the credit markets and interest rates would likely stay high.
That would create a vicious cycle for Mr. Reagan. High interest rates aggravate the budget deficit in two ways - directly by adding greatly to the public debt, and indirectly by slowing the economy, reducing incomes, and hence causing a shortfall of tax revenues.
The effort of Mr. Regan and Mr. Weidenbaum to encourage a modest easing of monetary restraints by the Fed in order to bring down interest rates cannot do much in the absence of progress on the budget - cuts in defense spending, nondefense spending or a giveback of some of the tax reduction.
The Administration wants the options limited to one - further cuts in social spending. But Congress seems about to mutiny against this conception. That holds not only for liberal Democrats but even for some conservative Republicans like Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.

WALL ST. WASN'T SCARED STIFF BY DEFICITS

Author: Cowan, Edward

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]13 Sep 1981: A.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424182623?accountid=11752

Abstract: All four are economists of the monetarist school, who argue that statistical a nalysis shows no correlation between deficits and high interest rate s or between deficits and inflation. Private saving and investing mak e room for Federal deficits with little change in interest rate s or inflation, they say. ''The Wall Street analysts like Henry Ka ufman are mistakenly worried about the deficit,'' said adissenter who asked to remain anonymous. President [Ronald Reagan], who last week said he was ''upset'' that his program has declining support on Wall Street, evidently shares that view, partly on the advice of Secretary [Donald T. Regan], who came to Washington after a long career in Wall Street. What, then, is causing the present high rates of interest? ''It's difficult to weave out an explanation,'' says Mr. [Norman B. Ture]. As for inflation, the monetarists assert that it is caused not by deficits as such but by excessive expansion of the money supply (sometimes called ''monetization'' of the deficit) by the Federal Reserve system. The monetarists argue that a steady upward trend of prices and wages can occur only if the central bank is creating too much money. What may be bothering the money markets, say the dissenters - and here there is some agreement between them and the mainstream view - is a fear, as Mr. Ture put it, that ''the Fed will lose its courage,'' and that under the threat or fact of recession - possibly with prompting by a politically ap prehensive White House - it will start pumping out credit to cure the recessio n instead of ''staying the course'' of wringing out inflation.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=WALL+ST.+WASN%27T+SCARED+STIFF+BY+DEFICITS&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-09-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Cowan%2C+Edward&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: For the second time in 18 months, sinking bond and stock markets have forced a President to order politically disruptive spending cuts in hopes of pulling the Federal budget into the black.
In 1980, Jimmy Carter tore up his 1981 budget just weeks after sending it to Congress. Now, Ronald Reagan is ordering his Cabinet to prepare still more nonmilitary - and for the first time, some military - spending cuts for 1982.
What is startling - to the public, Congress and even the White House - is that the Reagan move comes on the heels of stunning victories on the first round of budget retrenchment and the enactment of his tax bill. That completed the adoption of the Reagan fiscal policy. It also directed attention to the unlikelihood, as critics have contended for a year, that big increases in military spending and deep cuts in taxes could result nevertheless in the promised balanced budget in 1984.
Mr. Reagan is experiencing what his predecessors of both parties suffered through: The apparent tendency of the Federal budget to run toward larger deficits than the President planned and the subsequent reaction of the financial community.
Since midsummer, bond prices and stock prices have plummeted and interest rates have climbed to record or near-record highs. But while virtually all Administration economists believe that Mr. Reagan can't go wrong by insisting on still sharper contractions in the scope of Government to convince the markets that there is a will to end deficit financing, there is disagreement about whether it is the budget deficit that is troubling Wall Street.
The standard view is that it is. It starts with the basic fact that deficit spending is financed by borrowing. As Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office, explained to the House Budget Committee last week, any increase in borrowing tends to push up interest rates, which are the price the borrower pays to the lender for temporary hire of the money. And since Uncle Sam is not just another borrower but the colossus that dwarfs others in its need for money, when Federal fiscal specialists in Wall Street predict that the deficit will be larger than advertised, that is a signal for interest rates to rise.
This essentially conventional view of the markets' malaise is held by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and by President Reagan.
The Dissenters at Treasury
At the Treasury, there is a dissenting view -and irritation with Mr. Stockman and his chief economist, Lawrence A. Kudlow. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan is understood to share the Stockman view. But some of his lieutenants do not, notably undersecretaries Norman B. Ture and Beryl W. Sprinkel, Assistant Secretary Paul Craig Roberts and his deputy, Stephen Entin.
All four are economists of the monetarist school, who argue that statistical a nalysis shows no correlation between deficits and high interest rate s or between deficits and inflation. Private saving and investing mak e room for Federal deficits with little change in interest rate s or inflation, they say. ''The Wall Street analysts like Henry Ka ufman are mistakenly worried about the deficit,'' said adissenter who asked to remain anonymous.
President Reagan, who last week said he was ''upset'' that his program has declining support on Wall Street, evidently shares that view, partly on the advice of Secretary Regan, who came to Washington after a long career in Wall Street. What, then, is causing the present high rates of interest? ''It's difficult to weave out an explanation,'' says Mr. Ture. As for inflation, the monetarists assert that it is caused not by deficits as such but by excessive expansion of the money supply (sometimes called ''monetization'' of the deficit) by the Federal Reserve system. The monetarists argue that a steady upward trend of prices and wages can occur only if the central bank is creating too much money.
What may be bothering the money markets, say the dissenters - and here there is some agreement between them and the mainstream view - is a fear, as Mr. Ture put it, that ''the Fed will lose its courage,'' and that under the threat or fact of recession - possibly with prompting by a politically ap prehensive White House - it will start pumping out credit to cure the recessio n instead of ''staying the course'' of wringing out inflation.
The monetarists are also economists of the supply-side school, who passionately urged upon candidate and President Reagan a commitment to three years of tax relief, arguing that lower tax rates were essential to revitalization of the private sector.
As a result, they have played down the economic significance of budget deficits. Indeed, the original sponsor of a three-year taxcut bill, Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, has been widely quoted on Capitol Hill as having said ''Republicans no longer worship at the shrine of a balanced budget,'' a heretical statement by traditional norms.
Two decades ago, budget deficits were also the subject of intense political dispute. Republicans condemned them - President Dwight D. Eisenhower said they would be a burden on future generations - while liberal Democrats argued that in times of economic slack, deficit spending could put idle workers and machines to work.
Some Democrats may still hold that Keynesian view. But it is not an argument that is heard in Congress any more. In opposing the Reagan tax cut, the Democrats tried to show they were the champions of a balanced budget.
With Mrs. Rivlin cautioning Congress that the 1982 deficit may exceed the President's $42.5 billion July estimate by $20 billion, each party is jockeying for position so that in October 1982, on the eve of the Congressional elections, it can blame the other for still another splash of Federal red ink.

SHOULD WE (AND COULD WE) RETURN TO THE GOLD STANDARD

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]06 Sep 1981: A.4.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424194659?accountid=11752

Abstract: WASHINGTON KEYNES called it the ''barbarous relic.'' Lenin said it was fit only to adorn the latrines of the world. Ten years ago President Nixon, in effect, tore the world's currencies loose from it by pulling the dollar away from a gold peg. Still, gold has lost neither its romantic allure nor its practical attraction. I would foresee simply a sequence of events that follow from the kind of mechanism you've set in place. We're standing ready to sell gold at (a certain price) and we'll buy it at (that price). If there is a strong, private world demand for gold we'd lose gold. That will contract our money supply, work against inflation. But it might work much more strongly than we would want, and so we might then get very large unemployment and recession. We've all learned that we don't cut off our nose to spoil our face. If something is good for the United States, namely a monetary standard, a dollar and a price level that's stable, we don't worry too much about other countries who may get a minor benefit. Indeed, I would argue that South Africa and the Soviet Union have a stake in inflation, because they get a high price for gold when the United States inflates.

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=SHOULD+WE+%28AND+COULD+WE%29+RETURN+TO+THE+GOLD+STANDARD%3A+%5BINTERVIEW%5D&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-09-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON KEYNES called it the ''barbarous relic.'' Lenin said it was fit only to adorn the latrines of the world. Ten years ago President Nixon, in effect, tore the world's currencies loose from it by pulling the dollar away from a gold peg. Still, gold has lost neither its romantic allure nor its practical attraction.
President Reagan recently appointed a commission of 17 experts, mostly Government officials, to review the issue again. Its specific task is to determine whether the metal should once more play a dominant role in the domestic and international monetary system.
The Week in Review asked two members of that commission, Henry C. Wallich and Lewis E. Lehrman to talk about the gold standard. Mr. Wallich, a former economic professor at Yale, has been a governor of the Federal Reserve Board since March 1974. Mr. Lehrman, chairman of the executive committee of the Rite Aid Corporation, a discount drug chain, was one of the inner core of supply-siders in the Reagan transition team.Excerpts of their separate interviews with Clyde H. Farnsworth, a reporter in The New York Times's Washington bureau, follow.
Question. Advocates say that returning to a gold standard would cure inflation and high interest rates without recession. Is there justice to the argument?
Answer. That was the si tuation in the dim past - the 19th century, then in a mod ified way after World War II. But to get from our present situa tion to that blessed condition will take much more than some mechanic al decision to implement a certain standard.
The transition to stability would be just as difficult as it would be without the gold standard. You have high inflation, you have expectations, you have wage contracts, you have interest rates that were high and built into the system, and to get away from all that will just require substantial adjustments no matter how you do it.
If you got back to stable conditions it would be more feasible to have a gold standard. But I still am very doubtful that a gold standard would allow us to maintain that stability.
Q. Some have argued that moving to the gold standard immediately would reduce the inflation rate.
A. Do you think that a wage contract to pay a 12 percent increase for three years running would automatically change? Do you think that a Treasury bond issued for 30 years at 13 percent would automatically change?
I would foresee simply a sequence of events that follow from the kind of mechanism you've set in place. We're standing ready to sell gold at (a certain price) and we'll buy it at (that price). If there is a strong, private world demand for gold we'd lose gold. That will contract our money supply, work against inflation. But it might work much more strongly than we would want, and so we might then get very large unemployment and recession.
Alternatively, that price might turn out to have been too high. Then other countries or private holders will unload the gold they have. Then we would have to buy all that gold. We would issue money against it. We would get a big inflation.
Q. What about the argument that the gold standard is the natural regulator of monetary growth that the monetarists seek and fail to find in the Federal Reserve?
A. I doubt that very much. Those who tell me we're going to slow down the growth of the money supply by half a percent a year as the Fed is doing - that says something to me about the rate of inflation t hat you can expect over time. It will go down. Eventually, hopefully, it'll go to zero.
But if you tell me that we're going to issue money or extinguish money depending on whether gold flows in or out, then I can't predict anything about inflation except that it will be totally unpredictable.
Q. How about the point that gold is a unique and stable standard of economic value?
A. We all know that you can say that gold is better than some other things. But it's certainly not a stable standard in the short run.You can show that because the supply of it increases only slowly, if you use that as money or as the base for money, prices can't vary very much.
But they can vary quite substantially nevertheless. We've seen that during the 19th century. You saw over the century prices didn't change much, but you had big waves of rising and falling prices.
Q. There is the argument that the return to the gold standard would be a major stimulus to savings?
A. It might be some stimulus to saving. However, today you can buy gold all you want to, and historically its price has increased. So if you fix the price of gold you certainly wouldn't want to increase your saving in order to buy gold and get no interest on it. So the only benefit to saving that I would see is that people would have more confidence in the currency and for that reason might save more. But I don't believe that in the days of the gold standard saving was higher than it is today.
Q. What do you think the role of gold today should be in the international system?
A. To serve as a kind of last-ditch sort of liquidity. Countries that lack foreign exchange or are not sure that they can also earn or borrow foreign exchange, if they have a gold supply would be able to borrow against it. Several countries did that during the 70's. Some countries sold off some of their gold, including the United States.
Q. Do you see some kind of standard, such as the special drawing right (S.D.R) of the International Monetary Fund or a combination of that with the dollar as becoming the major international standard, or do you see some kind of future role for gold in the standard?
A. Well, to me the evolution towards S.D.R.-systems, that is, a basket of currencies, seems plausible. Q. Do you think there is enough public confidence behind the S.D.R. to warrant its move to the forefront?
A. That really depends on the confidence that exists in the five currencies th at constitute the S.D.R. You know the S.D.R. is simply a composite o f dollars, and Deutches-mark and yen and francs and pounds. If th ere's confidence in those, then the average of them presumably wi ll be stabler than any one of them. That is the philosophy of the S.D.R.
Question. Is the gold standard, as some advocates argue, a cure-all or is it a patent medicine?
Answer. My argument has always been that the gold standard is an imperfect institution. All institutions are imperfect. But it's the least imperfect institution that's been tested in a laboratory of history to yield reasonable price stability and to provide for a stable dollar.
The dollar would have a permanent fixed value. Think of it the following way. The dollar is the monetary standard, and the monetary standard is defined permanently as a weight unit of gold.
Q. But there can be gold strikes, or shortages.
A. Well, with respect, the truth about the production of gold is very different from some of the mythology. The rate of gain in gold stocks has averaged around 2 percent, particularly since the industrial revolution.
Q. The severe shortages and booms of the late 19th century had great economic consequences.
A. The consequences were all very beneficial. From 1875 until about 1912, the average rate of variation of the price level never exceeded 2 percent. Compare that to the last 10 years of the manipulated paper currency system, where the price level has varied as much as 13 percent above the previous year several times.
Q. How would going on a gold standard affect wage increases locked into contracts?
A. We all want to see the rate of gain in wages be approximately equal to the rate of gain in productivity. The gold standard gives people today confidence in the future purchasing power of the dollar. As a result, working men believing in an honest dollar begin to ask for reasonable wage increases, proportional, that is, to the gain in the productivity in t heir own labor.
It's almost as if the gold standard were an insurance policy, an actuarial reminder to all who participate in the market that the dollar in 10 years instead of being 50 percent of what it is worth today would be approximately equal in purchasing power as it is today.
Q. If you're going to establish a gold standard, you have to set a price. What happens if the price is too high? All the gold would come to the United States. If it's too low, the United States would lose gold, or go into some kind of economic contraction.
A. Under the gold standard there is no price for gold. The dollar is the monetary standard, set by law equal to a weight of gold. The price of gold does not exist. As a matter of fact, you may even look at the gold standard as the end to the speculation in gold in terms of paper dollars.
Q. But in the real world, you would be using paper dollars and you could turn them in to the Treasury for so much gold. So the gold does have a dollar value.
A. And I live in the real world. I'm a businessman and I'm very concerned about just the character of our monetary standard. Under the gold standard, the paper dollar is a promissory note. It is a claim to a real article of wealth defined by law as the standard.
Let us say, for example, that in January 1982, we would announce that two years hence the monetary standard of the United States would be established as a dollar equal to a weight of gold. About 90 days before the period in which the price, as you call it, would be fixed, the gold markets would be tending to stabilize because they would know that the President and the Congress, under statute, would be about to fix (the dollar) equal to a weight of gold.
Q. In other words, that's the market price and that would be the fair price for gold.
A. The market price would be the lead indicator. On the other hand, other indicators are important - the assignment of the experts assembled around the President in writing a statute. There's no substitute for judgment...
Q. Wouldn't we be mortgaging our future by founding our whole monetary system on the amount of gold coming out of, say, South Africa?
A. Generally that criticism is made by people who have never bothered to study the statistics of gold production. South Africa and the Soviet Union first of all would act in their own self interest because in order to obtain foreign exchange to buy Western technology and Western grain they would want to sell the gold in an orderly manner. On the other hand, if they chose not to sell their gold for foreign exchange they do not produce enough to disrupt the market, of which they ar e less than one percent.
Q. But why should we guarantee the price of the chief source of foreign exchange for them?
A. We are not guaranteeing a price for them. We are establishing a monetary standard for us.
We've all learned that we don't cut off our nose to spoil our face. If something is good for the United States, namely a monetary standard, a dollar and a price level that's stable, we don't worry too much about other countries who may get a minor benefit. Indeed, I would argue that South Africa and the Soviet Union have a stake in inflation, because they get a high price for gold when the United States inflates.
Q. Why is dependence on 'the barbarous relic' better than the rational creation of reserves by rational men?
A. Your phrase - quote, the rational creation of reserves, unquote - is precisely the technique that the Federal Reserve and central banks all over the world during the last 10 years have been using. Not only have they succeeded in destroying almost all currencies; they have succeeded in disrupting the trade patterns based upon a stable exchange rate.
Q. So you don't trust the Fed or the politicians?
A. Well, not that. I do trust them. I do not believe they have the proven techniques to rationally provide for reserves by manipulating the money supply.
In the abstract, especially in the classrooms of Yale where I went to school, it was always easy for professors to draw on a blackboard equations which showed why bank reserves could be provided rationally to the market. As a businessman I have learned that under the gold standard these reserves were provided much more rationally by virtue of the operations of markets.

BONN FISCAL POLICY REVIEWED

Author: JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to the New York Times

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]04 Aug 1981: D.1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424180573?accountid=11752

Abstract: ''The Social Democrats support it because they feel you can't cut spending, particularly for welfare, without doing something for jobs,'' Mr. [Karl Otto Pohl] said. ''I'm of the opinion that a surtax and spending program would be completely counterproductive. What we need are improved exports and a reduction in the current account deficit. Reducing the deficit will improve the job market over the long term.'' The Export Remedy ''The policy of the Bundesbank is not the decisive point,'' Mr. Pohl said, explaining his cautious optimism that the mark would regain some of its former strength soon. ''What is decisive is exchange rate expectations,'' he added. ''If the markets are convinced the mark will climb again, that will be, in a sense, selffulfilling. A bull market breeds a bull market.'' ''We Germans might not suffer that much,'' he added, ''but weaker currencies within the system would do so.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=BONN+FISCAL+POLICY+REVIEWED&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-08-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.1&amp;au=JOHN+TAGLIABUE%2C+Special+to+the+New+York+Times&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, has urged the Bonn Government to spend less time criticizing high United States interest rates, and more time putting its ''own house in order.''
He advised Bonn's economic planners that such an emphasis was necessary to bring an early end to West Germany's recession and meaningful improvement in the current-account deficit.
Mr. Pohl, in an interview Friday, one day after the Bonn Government disclosed a program of sharp spending cuts in its 1982 budget, said falling interest rates in the United States would not necessarily bring about lower rates in West Germany, ''if, at the same time, America's inflation dropped, and the country's economic revival program'' took effect. Praise for Spending Cuts
Mr. Pohl praised the program of sharp spending cuts announced last week by the Bonn Government for its 1982 budget but warned that a Government economic recovery plan financed by increased taxes - a plan that is still under discussion in Bonn - would be counterproductive.
Mr. Pohl cautioned that Europe would be unable to insulate itself from the effects of United States inflation, with the recessionary effects it would bring, if Mr. Reagan's policies failed.
In Ottawa at the economic summit meeting, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt blamed high United States rates for the level of lending rates in Europe that he said is stifling investment and prolonging Europe's recession.
His Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff, added that Washington overemphasized monetary policy, relying too heavily on money-supply control and neglecting fiscal policies, such as spending cuts and a reduction of the deficit, to control inflation.
But Mr. Pohl said that regardless of the direction taken by United States interest rates and the value of the dollar, countries such as Germany had to take independent steps to decrease pressure on their own capital markets. If President Reagan's programs fail, he said, causing inflation, then United States rates will stay high, exerting pressure on Europe. If inflation in America drops, the dollar will remain strong, regardless of inflation rate movements.
''For that reason, falling United States interest rates are no guarantee of a drop in rates here,'' Mr. Pohl said. Mr. Pohl said that he strongly favored such supply-side tactics as tax cuts, investment incentives for businesses, and conservative monetary policy, and warned that Bonn's ambitious program to cut Government spending and reduce the deficit would be effec-tive only if the temptation were resisted to raise taxes to finance a Government pump-priming program.
The program announced last Thursday involves spending cuts of roughly 1 percent of Germany's gross national product. It also anticipates reduced Government borrowing, giving relief to capital markets and removing pressure from interest rates, It also envisions hiring restraints and increased taxes for some luxuries, such as tobacco, coupled with tax breaks for businesses in the form of improved write-offs.
Chancellor Schmidt last week blamed American monetary policy for the spending cuts, saying they were necessary to cut German Government borrowing and relieve capital markets already under pressure from high United States interest rates.
But at the same time the program was announced, members of Mr. Schmidt's Social Democratic Party, with labor union support, were pushing for an income tax and a witholding surtax to finance a Government spending program to stem unemployment. The idea divided the Bonn Cabinet, because of strong opposition from the Free Democrats, the junior partners in the coalition Government, and Mr. Schmidt agreed to postpone a decision until September. Tax Factor Crucial
The spending cuts, Mr. Pohl said, stand a chance of succeeding if the Government resists the temptation to raise taxes.
''I'm very critical of the tax idea, and I told the Cabinet so,'' he said. Mr. Pohl, a former official of the Schmidt Government, has shown considerable independence since becoming head of the central bank in 1979 and has often differed with Government policy.
''The Social Democrats support it because they feel you can't cut spending, particularly for welfare, without doing something for jobs,'' Mr. Pohl said. ''I'm of the opinion that a surtax and spending program would be completely counterproductive. What we need are improved exports and a reduction in the current account deficit. Reducing the deficit will improve the job market over the long term.'' The Export Remedy
Germany's remedy, he said, is to raise exports and attract capital, to reduce the current account deficit. There are indications of a reversal of the capital outflow that has depressed the mark in recent months, as exchange rate expectations grow.
''The policy of the Bundesbank is not the decisive point,'' Mr. Pohl said, explaining his cautious optimism that the mark would regain some of its former strength soon. ''What is decisive is exchange rate expectations,'' he added. ''If the markets are convinced the mark will climb again, that will be, in a sense, selffulfilling. A bull market breeds a bull market.''
Mr. Pohl said he had little faith in the suggestion of some European finance officials that by strengthening the European Monetary System, Europe could insulate its currencies from the dollar's movements sufficiently to bring about lower interest rates independently of the United States.
Mr. Pohl said that he had warned colleagues at Europe's central banks that their currency reserves would ''melt like butter in the sun'' if they attempted such a tactic.
''We Germans might not suffer that much,'' he added, ''but weaker currencies within the system would do so.''

Economic Scene; Discord Stirs With Allies

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]30 June 1981: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424109852?accountid=11752

Abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is likely to hear plenty of discontent on this score during his visit to the United States next week. Both the [Carter] and [Ronald Reagan] foreign policy advisers accuse the Europeans of putting their own economic advantages, linked to detente and increased East-West trade, ahead of the need to counter Soviet military threats in trouble spots stretching from the Baltic Sea to Afghanistan. The Americans are accusing the Europeans of becoming victims of ''Finlandization'' or ''Euro-neutralism.'' As the urgency of American appeals increased, Professor [Karl Kaiser] says, ''so did European discontent about the unilateral nature of actions aimed at forcing America's allies to act in compliance with American wishes.'' He maintains that Americans made the shocking discovery that part of European public opinion regards the Soviet Union and the United States in much the same light - ''as superpowers who were endangering world peace because of their lack of selfcontrol.'' Economics has become a crucial aspect of the national security issue. Professor Kaiser says: ''The West's economic security today has just as high a priority as its military security. In the event of war, the threat to the West's economy would probably be greater than the strictly military threat.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Discord+Stirs+With+Allies&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-06-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A STORM is brewing between the incoming Reagan administration and European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over military spending. President-elect Ronald Reagan, stressing the need to counter the Soviet military buildup, has made proposals that would increase military expenditures by an estimated 7 to 9 percent a year in real terms - that is, after allowing for inflation. This represents a sizable increase over President Carter's proposed real increase of 4 1/2 to 5 percent.
Senator John G. Tower, who will become chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has been working with the Reagan transition team to draft a supplemental military budget. The Texas Republican declared this week: ''I don't think we put balancing the budget as the No. 1 priority. We put national security as our No. 1 priority.''
But several European countries - including West Germany, Denmark, Belgium and the Netherlands - are dropping below their earlier pledges to increase defense outlays by 3 percent a year.
Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is likely to hear plenty of discontent on this score during his visit to the United States next week. Both the Carter and Reagan foreign policy advisers accuse the Europeans of putting their own economic advantages, linked to detente and increased East-West trade, ahead of the need to counter Soviet military threats in trouble spots stretching from the Baltic Sea to Afghanistan. The Americans are accusing the Europeans of becoming victims of ''Finlandization'' or ''Euro-neutralism.''
The Europeans contend, however, that the Americans, in trying to coerce them into a military buildup, not only are threatening to damage the Western economy but also are increasing the danger of war.
In a recent article in the German weekly Die Zeit, Prof. Karl Kaiser, head of the German Foreign Policy Association, warns of rising anti-Americanism in Europe. Faced with erratic American policy in Afghanistan and Iran, he says, the Europeans found that the wisest course was to ignore American calls for immediate action, let time pass and wait for Washington to cool down.
But as the urgency of American appeals increased, Professor Kaiser says, ''so did European discontent about the unilateral nature of actions aimed at forcing America's allies to act in compliance with American wishes.'' He maintains that Americans made the shocking discovery that part of European public opinion regards the Soviet Union and the United States in much the same light - ''as superpowers who were endangering world peace because of their lack of selfcontrol.''
Some European observers are worried that a wedge is being driven between the Americans and their European allies - which has long been a goal of Soviet policy. Rolf Pauls, the just-retired West German envoy to NATO, recently warned his fellow Europeans, ''Let us take good care not to become the Kremlin's youthful idiots by virtue of our anti-Americanism.''
Mr. Reagan's foreign policy advisers are determined to press ahead, despite European misgivings, with a big defense buildup. They contend that this will be not so much a burden to the economy as a means of strengthening America's economic, as well as political, status in the world. They argue that the European countries and Japan will be less likely to follow the American lead in demanding reliable access to supplies of energy and raw materials from Middle Eastern and other third-world countries unless the credibility of the United States as an ally is increased. Lacking belief in American political resolution and power, the Reagan advisers maintain, the European allies and Japan have been and will continue to be reluctant to share the cost of collective defense and to regulate economic relations with the Soviet bloc or with third-world countries on a common basis with the United States.
But efforts by the Reagan administration to strengthen United States and Western pressures on Communist, oil-producing and thirdworld countries could worsen relations between the United States and Western Europe and Japan unless handled intelligently and skillfully.
America's allies regard United States foreign policy today as an overreaction to what they regard as Soviet defensive moves. And they fear that too rapid a defense buildup would not only damage their economic relations with Moscow but also would intensify inflation and other strains on the worldwide economy.
Economics has become a crucial aspect of the national security issue. Professor Kaiser says: ''The West's economic security today has just as high a priority as its military security. In the event of war, the threat to the West's economy would probably be greater than the strictly military threat.''
Countering the economic threat lies outside the capabilities of the defense establishments. Responding to economic dangers will require cooperation between partners with different foreign policies, different perceptions and different interests. The stability and growth of national economies will also play a crucial part in preserving the peace. This nation's next secretary of state ought to be a person who understands economics as well as diplomacy and national security.

Economic Scene; Third World Instability

Author: Silk, Leonard

Publication info: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]24 June 1981: D.2.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/424112953?accountid=11752

Abstract: The failure to understand and manage that interdependence, Mr. [Robert S. McNamara] warned, could lead to a global economic disaster. ''We've got this tremendous financial disequilibrium,'' he said, ''that has come about because of the increases in oil prices.'' In his view, the present oil glut and small price decline is likely to be short-lived. For the rest of the century, he expects the rise in oil prices to outrun the rate of inflation by an average of 3 percent a year. While he does not regard economic advance as assuring political stability, Mr. McNamara believes that a lack of economic and social advance in the third world is contributing to political instability, which is imposing increasingly heavy strategic costs on the United States. ''Surely,'' he says, ''we must realize that in relation to the problems we are facing in the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and Africa.'' Americans traditionally regard national security as a function of military armaments and manpower. Thirteen years after his service as Secretary of Defense during the Vietnam War, Mr. McNamara sees national security as the function of a broader set of economic, social and political as well as military factors. ''At the margin,'' he says, ''the United States gains more security through a dollar applied to development assistance than it does to apply that same dollar to military expenditures.''

Links: http://findit.library.jhu.edu/resolve?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Anytimes&amp;atitle=Economic+Scene%3B+Third+World+Instability&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;issn=03624331&amp;date=1981-06-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;au=Silk%2C+Leonard&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: AT the Ottawa conference of the leaders of the major Western industrial nations next month, President Reagan is likely to face heavy criticism for the impact of high United States interest rates on other countries. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, President Francois Mitterrand of France and other leaders have already voiced their fears that the Reagan Administration's stringent monetarist strategy could worsen unemployment and cause a breakdown of economic cooperation in the West.
Only Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, pursuing her own monetarist attack on inflation, is likely to provide strong support for Mr. Reagan's position. But with British joblessness above 10 percent, highest since the Depression, Mrs. Thatcher's praise may do Mr. Reagan more harm than good.
Mr. Reagan almost certainly will argue that tight money and a stronger dollar serve not just this country's best interests but that of all, by bringing down inflation and by strengthening the world monetary system. Strict control of the money supply, his advisers insist, is not the cause of high interest rates but the cure. For in stopping inflation, they argue, tight money will bring down interest rates.
Administration spokesmen have been asking what the United States must do to satisfy foreign critics, who complained bitterly when American inflation was climbing and the dollar falling, and now complain even more bitterly when the dollar is climbing. As the old political line had it, they are against inflation; they are against deflation; they are in favor of flation.
But the real issue raised by Mr. Reagan's critics (at home as well as abroad; on Wall Street as well as in the building industry) is not whether the Administration should fight inflation, but how.
That was also the issue stressed by Robert S. McNamara, who leaves as president of the World Bank at the end of this month, in an interview last week. Mr. McNamara argues that American economic policy has been distorted by three basic misconceptions: (1) a failure to distinguish between activities appropriate for the private sector vis-a-vis the public sector; (2) a failure to recognize that a major aim ought to be how to increase the effectiveness of government, and (3) a tendency to believe that all expenditure reductions (other than defense expenditures) are good.
Those three errors, he said, have led ''to an excessive reliance on monetarism, inadequate attention to fiscal constraints, inadequaate attention to an incomes policy, and inadequate attention to the structural rigidities of our society - subsidies for the middle class, agricultural subsidies, excessive rigidities in linkages between Social Security and inflation, wage contracts and price levels, and a host of other matters.''
All this, he maintained, goes to an even deeper problem - a failure of the American people to recognize the tremendous change that has taken place: the growing interdependence of the United States and other nations, including the poor countries of the third world with their heavy dependence on imported food and fuel.
The failure to understand and manage that interdependence, Mr. McNamara warned, could lead to a global economic disaster. ''We've got this tremendous financial disequilibrium,'' he said, ''that has come about because of the increases in oil prices.'' In his view, the present oil glut and small price decline is likely to be short-lived. For the rest of the century, he expects the rise in oil prices to outrun the rate of inflation by an average of 3 percent a year.
That forecast leads him to expect a continuing financial disequilibrium between the poor countries, the oil exporting countries and the industrial countries, endangering both rich and poor.
While he does not regard economic advance as assuring political stability, Mr. McNamara believes that a lack of economic and social advance in the third world is contributing to political instability, which is imposing increasingly heavy strategic costs on the United States. ''Surely,'' he says, ''we must realize that in relation to the problems we are facing in the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and Africa.''
Americans traditionally regard national security as a function of military armaments and manpower. Thirteen years after his service as Secretary of Defense during the Vietnam War, Mr. McNamara sees national security as the function of a broader set of economic, social and political as well as military factors. ''At the margin,'' he says, ''the United States gains more security through a dollar applied to development assistance than it does to apply that same dollar to military expenditures.''
Mr. Reagan may well encounter similar arguments at the Ottawa summit meeting. However, while the Europeans and the Japanese are loath to respond to American pressures to increase their defense spending, they appear more disposed to invest marginal financial resources in their own economic development than in aid to the oilpoor developing countries.
But, if Mr. McNamara is right, the economic and political instability issuing from the poor countries of the third world is likely to be a major threat to the world economy and to world peace for the rest of the century.
